SP.P: Excellent widow. It works like wax to the sea—Bring good books to comfort you. I have the good books to comfort a widow. Marriage settlements. But if she ever hears them read, she may bless her ears for the opportunity. [Eliza enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: C Flash.
SP.P:
Your Servant Miss Eliza you have seen me at
, where I had the honor once of dancing with you▪ Come wo are a little acquainted give me that sweet little hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: I shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Why, what sort of politeness is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Because you are Captain Flash, and that is reason enough.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: And what has Captain Flash done, that a lady cannot even pass an ordinary compliment with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Nothing with me nor ever shall: Persons of undoubt∣ed veracity have told me that this same Captain Flash leaves his duty in the amy, and makes t his whole busines to steal the hearts of unguarded ladies, and then sacrifice them to infamy, or consign them to comfortless solitude. I wish for no acquaintance with such a man.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Does not a lady of your good sense know that the world commonly asperses men of merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: I know also that men of real merit can clear them∣selves of the aspersion—will you upon my charge confront Mr. Tukely.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Yes, or any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: I suppose you may challenge him when absent, but not when he is present. He knows you too well.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: He knows me not nor I him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Would you utter a deliberate falshood? It will not recommend you to me—do you not court at once Maria, Tukelys sister, and her aunt Lovecase the fat widow— and how can you say that you do not know him?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: It is all from the beginning to the end— I court Maria that fond disgusting sl▪ I would as soon court a mess of plumb porridge—as for the widow—did you know —she is an intolerable snuff aker, and it sticks in the down on her upper lip; that she looks like a Turk in his whiskers. Upon my truth she looks like the grand Mogul dressed up in petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: To scandalize other ladies, captain, is not the way to find access to —It is also said you have designs on Lisetta the little Prude.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: That is as great a lie as all the rest. Why, she uses volatiles to such a decree that she scents of them a mile's distance—give it all up, Eliza, it is mere invention, give me that sweet little hand, and take a little walk with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: I shall not do it.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Then excuse the presumption of a lover driv∣en to despiration by her who is the object of all his desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Let me go, Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: I cannot quit this inestimable prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliz.
SP.P: Unhand me, insolent wretch, this instant, or I will call my footmen, and they shall give you proper dicipline. (He unhands her and she says going out) There, go now, and herd with your own sort. [Exit Eliza.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—TUKELY and Capt FLASH.

SP.SPEAKER: Tuk.
SP.P: WHAT is the matter with you, captain, you look confounded?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Only a little girl here behaved with rather too much prudence and propriety—She is a sensible gir1, I wish to marry sometime or other, what if I follow her, and by means of her relations make honorable proposals in good earnest. (Follows her out.)

DIV3.STAGE: [Two ladies enter on one side—Tukely steps aside and listens.]

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: MISS Philenia, I am astonished at your confi∣dence—To contend for your interest in a man. You might be ashamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You do exactly the same—I say the truth, if he invited you to Whites at the Ball, he invited me to Miss Mohairs

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: I have a dozen letters of his in the most passionate stile, the language of the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I have fifteen in such a stile as to show him the sincerest of lovers.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: I hope you will not lie, you mistake the man. The true Capt Flash lodges at Ms. Simpson's in Threadneedle Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Mine are from Capt. Flash of the third regiment, their station, Gibralter. He is recruiting in this city and lodges at Mrs. Simpsons in Threadneedle Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: The Captain is a man of the strictest truth. He has sworn his love to me a hundred times on the salvation of his soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: He would not deceive me I know, he has sworn his love to me a thousand times, so what says your mad∣amship to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: Some person has imposed on you. Let me see one of your letters, the handwriting and the seal.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I shall not betray the letters of my friends—show one of yours, it will do as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: I know that those he wrote to me are genuine.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: There is no imposition certainly in those which he wrote to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: I am sure to confound you now—I have his pic∣ture in miniature set with diamonds.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: And I have a picture set with diamonds of the true identical Capt. Flash.

SP.SPEAKER: Nar.
SP.P: I advise you to desist—you will become the ridi∣cule of the town.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You are the ridicule of the town already, you have taken a phantom for a lover; I am content with the reality.

SP.SPEAKER: Tuk.
SP.P: (stepping forward) Ladies if you will take your station where I will place you; the whole affair will be explained to your mutual satisfaction. (Leads them out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: It is a matter very interesting to me. I desire you will inform me whether Capt. Flash makes love to every lady of his acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SP.P: I believe he does not make love to every lady of his acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Then he does to many.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SP.P: He oftens boasts of his exploits to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Please to inform me then of his whole character and conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SP.P: Let us know how far you have gone with him; it may not be safe to inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: His addresses have been honorable. I own I have admitted his visits freely at home, and have been with him in public places, and he has appeared to me a man of merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SP.P: So he has made proposals of marriage, to which you have consented▪ then he has absented himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: He does not visit me so frequently as he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt
SP.P: You should have known his character before you admitted his visits freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: If he be true I ought to have the happiness to know it f e be false I should be undeceived—Either way you are inhuman and cruel if you do not inform me.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SP.P: You would not believe any thing from me; u less it were agreeable to your wishes—But here is a gentle∣man (He presents her to Tukely.) who will put you into a situation to inform yoursees.

SP.SPEAKER: Tuk.
SP.P: (Leading her out.) Here madam take a station which I shall point out to you and your affairs will be cleared up in a few moments. [Tukely and Amoret go out.]

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: THAT little jewel Eliza has escaped me. She has too much good sense to be caught with chaff—I shall marry her if any of them. But see, are there any more of the quarry? (Peeps in his glass at the ladies behind the curtain.) Yes my sweet little prude Lisetta, she loves ex∣treme delicacy and keen scandal. I'll dose her well with both—my friend Lisetta. This is a happy day because I meet you. (Addressing himself to Lisetta as she enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: My heart loves virtue and good sense, I am enraptured with the beauties of Lisetta's mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: I cannot endure flattery, Captain—It is odious as wormwood to the bee, who rambles among the sweetest flowers of the field.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Think not I have any tho't of making love to Lisetta—I know her averse to love, that mad passion which deprives human beings of reason and virtue—Friendship and esteem, are all the affections I could expect to excite in the most virtuous Lisetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: The love of virtue for virtue's sake. I despise any thing that has connection with interest, or the senses.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P:
I abominate the barbarous custom of marrying.
I should be aed of a faly if I had one—Let me res∣pect you without the least profit, and serve you without the least hope of reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: How pleasing it is to talk with a man of sense; But you are devoted to the interest of Philenia.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: That is impossible—It is a fact that she drinks strong waters—Did you never observe the tip of her nose how red it is? Split me to atoms, if ever I could bear the smell of brandy.

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: But then she sings so sweetly.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Blast my constitution if I think she sings sweet∣ly—There is a screech in her voice which resembles the whetting of a saw. It always sets my teeth on edge to hear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: The little Amoret perhaps may please you.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: That simple little ideot—She is the shallowest of all womankind—She could not smell a rat if it lay dead before her nose—What are these to the pure, the delicate, the divine Lisetta?

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: I should admire the man who could love like an angel, and be content with mere adoration of his mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Then here is the man for you (Laying his hand on his heart.) admit me tomorrow evening to converse with you at home, at 10 o'clock. You shall see how we will pass the time in the most distant and enraptured admira∣tion of each others perfections.

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: You may come, but be sure that your mind be pure as moonlight before you presume to enter my house— At present I must withdraw. [withdraws.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Capt. FLASH alone.
DIV3.P:
WELL how many ladies have I on hand. (Takes out a list, and comments upon it.) There is Maria—I must spare her, or her brother that fireskull will kill me—I'll tell her story however, over a bottle of wine—The widow, the prude and Amoret, I mean to sacrifice to the Goddess pleasure, the only Deity, Vanity excepted, that I adore. Narcissa and Philenia, they must thank themselves for their folly—If I once gain liberty of a private interview they will hardly escape me finally—They will do to make stories of, to divert my brother officers on a dull campaign. Eli∣za is the only one I can think of marrying—She under∣stands
the Trap and avoids it, one might take her and not fear.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.— [BLUNT, TUKELY, and all the LADIES enter at once—and the Captain appears extremely confounded— remains silent some moments—at last speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: WHAT all in a company!

SP.SPEAKER: Tuk.
SP.P: The Captain used to reconnoitre—the ladies have been reconnoitring the Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: But what brought you here all together?
We begin to smell a rat even before he is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You seem to be dull, captain. How should you like a song that would set your teeth on edge, or shall we raise your spirits with brandy?

SP.SPEAKER: Liset.
SP.P: Volatile spirit might keep him from fainting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sometimes when persons are failing it has served as a good restorative to give them a mess of plum por∣ridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: The ladies insult you Captian but never mind it, please to take a little Spanish snuff out of the grand Mo∣gul's box, it is the best thing in the world for low-spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Blunt, you rascal—you have betrayed me.

SP.SPEAKER: Blunt
SP.P: I have not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tuk.
SP.P: He is harmless—But I being apprehensive for my Sister, placed the ladies in the post of observation—Now you may resent it if you dare. (Pauses, but C. Flash makes no an∣swer.) Ladies how shall we punish him? shall we throw the rascal into Rosamond's pond?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: No, let me give him his doom—We will bring his character on the stage, and expose him to public ridicule— for the instruction of women, and the terror of all his kind.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Flash.
SP.P: Well Ladies I have as good an opinion of you now, as I ever had—so good bye. [He goes out—and all the performers withdraw soon after him.]

DIV1.HEAD: The Growth of Rumors. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN ONE ACT.
ABSURDITY OF MAGNIFYING REPORTS.
DIV1.P: Next to the folly and wickedness of framing deliber∣ate falsehoods and propagating them concerning honest people, is the pernicious disposition, which inclines some persons, if they hear any disagreea∣ble report, to magnify and spread it. An ill im∣pression is sometimes made in an hour, which it will require years to efface; and perhaps it can never be effaced—a good man "taketh not up an ill report against his neighbor."

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: LONGHEAD—a man who makes the worst of every thing.
MADAM PIPER—an aged woman who hears their Dialogue, and speaks as she is affected by it.—Madam Piper sits and works at a distance thro the whole Dialogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: DID you hear of the melancholy affair which happened in this Town, this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: I have heard nothing new of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: Neighbor Greetwell's family is in the utmost con∣fusion—Never was a more tragical scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: This is the first lisp I have had of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: I wish I had never heard it, it really makes me melancholy to think of it—Did you know his daughter Eliza?

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Yes, a beautiful and amiable girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: She is ruined, and I fear the happiness of the whole house is gone forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: You don't say so — I am frighted: I loved that family about as well as I loved myself.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: That is a tolerable lie to begin with, neighbor Catchword.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: She was courted by Mr. Brightman you know— and it was tho't to be a fine match.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Have they broken off? Well if they have done it by consent—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: You will hardly ever get a woman to do that —It's a losing game.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: But they did not do it by consent; and it is a melancholy affair indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: People said their love was ardent and sincere— Why! they were to be married this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Then I don't believe a word about their break∣ing off, not I—Would they be fools?

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: Aye but they have, and the bride is all in tears— and the bridegroom in the utmost distress and despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Pray tell me on what account.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: You know she was to have been married this evening—what grand preparations there were for the wed∣ding—and it was found out this morning, and not till this morning, that she was desparately in love with another man.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: That was a pity indeed—But is it fact? Is it fact?

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: O yes, it must be, Eliza Greetwell was seen to caress with tender endearments, and with tokens of passion∣ate fondness, another man, who was not her lover, at least not her intended bridegroom—So both families of the bride and bridegroom, are in the utmost distress and con∣fusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity—'Tis a pity certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: Aye but it is too true. We all thought her a girl of the firmest principles—But there is no trusting women now a days.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Any more than men, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Long.
SP.P: I could tell you more, but I'm in haste, and bid you adieu. [Exit Longhead. Breedbate enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: WELL brother Catchword what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Very surprising—You have heard how Eliza Greetwell and her spark have parted. The matter is a up about their being married this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: That is curious, they seemed as if they were made on purpose for each other, and only wanted to be one in interest, as they were one in heart and soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Alas, how shall men and women put confidence in one another any more? And it is the women's fault you see—There is no trusting them.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: If I were near you, you wretch, I would box your ars well.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: The young bridegroom was much offended at his bride, for giving such evident preference to another man, the very day she was to be married—he forgave her, and would not forsake her: for he's a generous fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Now I would have you laugh at women for telling stories about ghosts and apparitions—Yours are not half so probable.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch▪
SP.P:
always was a fine lad truly a fine man. I
am sorry, it will mortify him, as long as he lives. I am very sorry for him. It did not use to be so when I was young. No man would make a woman half a dozen visits unless he meant to marry her. And the ladies never ad∣mitted more than three visits, to any gentleman, unless they had a liking to him.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Then I should have turned you out of doors long before I did; and got more credit by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: Aye, but the times are sadly altered now—I ex∣pect one of these days, husbands and wives will dismiss one another, and say nothing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: I hope not, I am not quite ready to part with mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Catch.
SP.P: I shall be melancholy this whole day. But in∣stead of grieving for other people I must attend to my own affairs. [Exit Catchword.]

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: WHAT do you think neighbor of Miss Greetwell. Did you ever hear the like?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I cannot say a word—I am as dry as the desert of Arabia—I cannot say a word till you let me have some∣thing to drink. [Breedbate goes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: You will make fine work of it I dare say when you have raised your spirits a little. (Breedbate enters gives him a cup of liquor, he drinks, holds it, and talks, and drinks, alternately.)

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: Well, what do you think of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: O this is due— (drinks again) It goes to the very right spot of my inmost soul—This is the cordial that keeps men alive—It does not trip up one's heels you see, but only makes him chey, merry—Now as to Eliza Greetwell, what of her. (Taking the posture of attention.)

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: You'll be just in nice trim to talk about her, when you drink a little more.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I shall talk the better then.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: Such a thing when I was young would have rung thro all New-England—But people make light of these things now-a-days.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: I dislike these matters very much, but I am apt to think, this affair will not turn out so bad as expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Because Brightman treats the matter very lightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: He is a fellow of a fine temper, but he must needs feel very disagreeably—He is of a noble temper, can bear any thing. They say he keeps all his disagreeable feeling to himself. (Redface drinks again.)

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Now the poor women are to have another basting I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: That is generous in him, if that be fact—Yet what reason can we find that one person should be made unhap∣py for the sake of another, who does not deserve it?

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: No, I think it fll enough, to do it then, when it can no longer be avoided. For we take them in marriage for better or for worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: But when people in their courtship quarrel and sep∣arate, how can we judge who is to blame? they will hard∣ly ever tell the facts which relate to the matter, and who can judge without the facts?

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: But it seems Mr. Brightman was not in fault.— Every body says that he was attentive and constant, and ar∣dent, and persevering.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Miss Greetwell would be the best judge of that herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Alackaday the world grows worse as it grows old∣er—It did not use to be so when I was young—The men were as true as the sun—and they would not injure a wo∣man if they knew they might—The girls actually when I was young, depended more on their sweethearts honesty, than on their own discretion; but you see, it is not as it was, when I was young.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Yes, I remember when you was young; it used to rain gingerbread every night. We planted our potatoes and they produced fat turkies ready roasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Breed.
SP.P: If the men were so honest how were the girls pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: How were the girls! They were as kind as turtle∣doves. If you offered to marry one, she would take you up as quick! and hold you to your promise. There was no getting rid of her—for, as I told you before, the young men were extremely honest.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: You do murder truth abominably. The men never were so honest as you tell of, nor were the women ever such fools.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Well neighbor Curious, what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Only about Mr. Brightman and Miss Greetwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: That is indeed a curious matter—I have thought much of it, and cannot account for it. Yes, it i talked of by blacksmiths and barbers, by tradesmen and merchants— The physicians are up in arms about it—The lawyers are buying up blanks and quills—The clergy it is expected will not be silent—We shall have a number of smart ser∣mons on the subject—and some of the senators and rep∣resentatives think it best to bring in a new bill for the pre∣vention of such evils in time to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: ut the public in one respect is misinformed—It was not a proper disappointment on either part.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: How could that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Because they parted in mutual good humor; and agreed to separate.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: Who then can say they have done wrong? If par∣ties have associated ever so long, and agree to separate, who can say they are to blame? It may be said indeed that so much time has been spent in vain, because it can never be remembered with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Ah! I hardly know what to think about the sin of it—But it makes one's heart ache dreadfully to part with a beloved object. But when one gets a little weaned by the discovery of new faults, new deformities, &c. the parting is not so hard—I tried it (sighing) once myself.— Every man is his own friend, and loves to indulge his own humor; but we shall not settle the matter if we talk fort∣night about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Red.
SP.P: That is true; and as I have a customer waiting for me in my shop this moment, I must go. [Drinks off his liquor, sets down the empty glass and goes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Well, that was a very curious affair about Miss Greetwell and Mr. Brightman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: Yes, they had a sharp quarrel; but they were soon reconciled, and were married with great rejoicings.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Hah! was that the case? I thought they had agreed to part.

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: No—there was some little squabble, I believe, but it was soon over, and they were married very honorably, and I am very glad of it, for the separating of lovers who have long been acquainted, is often attended with very disagreeable consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Yes, and I wonder why men in all their wisdom have never found a remedy for that evil.

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: Because they want experience—For that since I have been honored with a seat in the legislature, I have thought of bringing in a bill for the prevention of these evils.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: What pray sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: The first provision in the act is—that no lady, un∣less she thinks her suitor an agreeable man, shall give him more than five audiences and an half, thirty whispers, and fifteen smiles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Under what penalty?

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: That she should receive no attention from any gen∣tleman for a whole month.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: O, sir, alter that part, by all means, that is intolerably severe. They'll never bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: What is to be done with the gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: It will be enacted, that every gentleman shall at least by the thirty ninth audience kiss a lady's hand in tok∣en of respect & tell her she is agreeable—by the fortieth, that she is particularly agreeable—by the forty-first that he shall declare his love in a set speech—by the forty-second, he shall profess eternal amity to her—and by the forty-third, be shall come directly to the point and canvass the subject of mar∣riage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: And what if she does not proceed thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Tell.
SP.P: He shall be liable to all the pains and penalties of a refusal, because his suit will be out lawed.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: I am afraid if liberty were given for every one to delay so long, the women would be in a worse situ∣ation than they are now.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I don't think I should like, with all sorts of women, to be confined to these rules.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Pip.
SP.P: Your scheme will never hold sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: I am of the same opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P:
well then, we must have all things in courtship and marriage, which relate to forming the alliance to the parties themselves, as before, if they are to blame they
must bear it themselves—People are always ungrateful to their rulers. (Looks sorry.)

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: I consent to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: And I too.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: Madam Piper you do not feel interested in this matter at this time of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Cur.
SP.P: Did you ever know a woman give up the idea of gallantry while her breath was in her?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Or a man to part with his vanity till he parted with his last spark of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: WELL neighbor Tellfair what is the news of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: Only that I am healthy, except what is said of Mr. Brightman and his lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: There was never any difficulty between them.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: Aye but indeed there was.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: No there was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: There was to be sure. (warmly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Certainly there was not, and I can tell you how the whole story took its rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: Then you can tell a wonder, for it is told and be∣lieved for a truth thro the whole town—The town has even been in an uproar about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: And about nothing—Mrs. Greetwell, wife to the bride's brother, seeing the son of her former husband, who was brought from nurse to the wedding, was overcome by the tenderness of a mother, caught him fondly in her arms and kissed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: And how came the story to get abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Only a child told it at a neighbor's house and made the common mistake of putting miss for mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Tel.
SP.P: Well I shall never believe such reports again, when told of honest people.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: I told you it was not at all probable that they wou'd quarrel when they were just going to be married. I would not answer for them, months or years after.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: And you may take it for granted that in nine in∣stances out of ten, the common scandalous stories told about people who in the general course of life are virtuous and worthy, are totally without foundation.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Piper.
SP.P: Well I desire the men will never say any more about women's tattling; for they have talked this whole day, and set the whole town in an uproar because a fond mother happened to kiss her own baby.

DIV1.HEAD: The Gamester. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
MILDNESS OF TEMPER.
DIV1.P: Every human being has some vices. Husbands must expect to find them in their wives, and wives in their husbands—parents will find vices in their children; and children when they grow up will find them in their parents. How shall we cure, or alleviate those vices in our near relations—by mildness or severity?—is not mildness most likely to gain the heart, and consequently to give us the greatest influence?

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. VAN KEPPEL—a merchant of Amsterdam and a gamester.
MR. LEERKINS—brother to Mrs. Van Keppel.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MRS. VAN KEPPEL—wife to Mr. Van Keppel.
MADAM LEERKINS—mother to Mrs. V. Keppel.
MRS. PAULUS—aunt to Mr. V. Keppel.
MISS LEERKINS—sister to Mrs. V. Keppel.

DIV1.P: The scene of action is supposed to be a merchant's house near the bank at Amsterdam.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. I.—Madam LEERKINS and Mrs. V. KEPPEL.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: YOU see what has been the consequence of your obstinacy. You would not listen to my advice—You shall be an example to all daughters who marry without their parents' consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: It might have been better for me to have fol∣lowed your counsel—Yet I am not absolutely sure of it— It might have hurt me as much to have lost the object of my dearest affections, as to have had a dissipated and inat∣tentive husband.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: I cannot say that I am very sorry—You feel the curse of disobedience and shall be a warning to others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I may feel the effect of folly. But how dear Madam can you call it disobedience? When I was eighteen you told me, I was free.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: But you would have Keppel against my ad∣vice and consent; and now you feel the curse of that sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: The curse of my folly rather. I was free at eighteen and did not marry till twenty five; If I was free I was not bound, so I cannot see how you can make either sin or disobedience of it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: You will be unhappy as long as you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I greatly fear it, and my sufferings persuade me, that girls would do well to listen to the advice of their elder relations more than they do—but either freedom is nothing or we may make use of it in the most interesting concern—the choice of a partner for life.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: You, I see, can be wicked and justify it too. The curse is likely to rest upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P:
I am very unhappy, and I wish that you would
reflect that you are my mother, and not increase your daughter's misery—yet miserable as I am, I am not be∣yond hope—I hope yet to reconcile you to me, and en∣gage my husband to virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: You will have a very hard task to do either one or the other. [Exit M. Leerkins]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mr. and Mrs. KEPPEL.
DIV3.STAGE: (Mrs. Keppel speaks to Mr. Keppel as he is entering.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: O I am glad you are come home. Sit a little with me my dear; and I will get you a delightful little supper in a few moments. I have sent to the market and have got the best things for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I thank you my dear, but I cannot stay. I must go gack to the sign of the Leopard—I have lost about seventy pounds, I came back to get more money that I may play again and recover what I have lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I am rather afraid that you will lose the whole. If I dared I would advise you to leave off gaming; for I am verily afraid it will ruin you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: O bravo, fine times indeed, a woman advise her husband, why, think my girl, you live in Holland. Did you think you lived in the United States of America? I remember, that, while I was in Massachusetts; if I asked some of the most respectable men in the state, if they would do this or that, they would say I will hear what my wife says, or, I will ask my wife. But you live in Holland my dew.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I wish from what you say, that I lived in Massachusetts. I respect that people exceedingly. I would then advise you to leave off gaming, for I verily fear it will ruin you. [Enter Mrs. Paulus.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: A fiddle's end of that. There is not a man in the universe, who can play against me. [Exit Keppel.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mad. LEERKINS, Mrs. V. KEPPEL and Mrs. PAULUS.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: So your husband is gone off to the tavern again, you are likely to be miserable enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P:
I greatly fear the worst—But I wish, Madam,
that you would not seek to increase my misery. It is al∣ready as great as I can bear.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: You see, Mrs. Paulus, what my daughter has bro't upon herself—and I cannot pity her so much as I should—if she had not bro't her mother's curse upon her by marrying without my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: But you surprize me, you did not curse one of your own children!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: Yes she disobeyed me, and I cursed her, and the curse has been fulfilled an I never will revoke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: O madam, I am afraid you are more to blame than she—I shall now begin to take her part.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: Why, had I not a right to curse her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: Perhaps not—You had a right to think she was a silly girl. For it is a great folly in young people to reject that counsel of elder persons which is the effect of experience, and count it as nothing. But your daughter was free, and what avails liberty if we cannot use it in that concern which is dearest to the human heart? So you may say she was silly; and had a right to think so, and place the less confidence in her on that account. But how she could be so guilty as to deserve an irrevocable curse I cannot comprehend.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: But she ought to have heard to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: That is very true, and she was a silly girl that she did not. But perhaps not guilty of any real crime. There are in the human constitution remarkable and un∣conquerable attachments and aversions—The convictions of the mind will not always bear sway, much less take advice from others—What would you do if any person should put a cat under your table or under your pillow—What would you say?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: O horrible! I can't bear a cat, I should faint away, or go into fits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: And you love dogs as much as you hate cats. —I have seen you, when a girl, carry one in your arms, from your father's house to the school, which is, at least, a mile. And I believe you always have one with you when you ride out.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: Yes, to keep my feet warm. Trip always lies at my feet and keeps them warm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P:
What if your parents had killed your little
dog, and had put a cat in his place, or that instead of war∣ming your feet, you should warm your heart with a cat.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: I could not have borne it, I must have died.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Pau.
SP.P: Well, I have seen men whose company I ab∣horred as much as ever you did that of a cat; who yet were esteemed by my friends and by the public—And I have seen one, else I never would have been married, for whom I had as great an attachment, as ever you had to Trip—This was my case I fully own, and might be that of your daugh∣ter. Was she then to be blamed?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Leer.
SP.P: You are a strange woman, and truly I do not know what to say to you—But Keppel is coming in, I will go out for I cannot bear to see him. [Exit Mad. Leerkins.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—KEPPEL enters with a distracted air.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: WHAT a wretched man am I? I wish I had hearkened to my wife. I have not only lost my mo∣ney but every thing else. I despised the counsel of the most amiable of women. What a fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: My dear friend, who has offended you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: No one, but myself. I am the greatest fool on earth. I wish I had followed your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Have you then lost the rest of the money?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Yes▪ every farthing, I never had such ill luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Chance governs the game. It was to be ex∣pected. I am not disappointed in the least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I am utterly undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: No my dear, utterly undone, no; my affection to you is the same as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: That is no comfort to me so long as I have made you wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Made me wretched! I value not the loss of our money. It was no great sum. You may raise twice as much on the mortgage of the house, and regain what you have lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: The house, my dear friend, is already mortgag∣ed and lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: There is the shop, my dear, & all the goods in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: They are mortgaged also and all the money raised on them is lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: The moveables, the furniture of the house— you might raise something on them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I may as well let you know the worst as not. I have mortgaged all my household furniture, carriages, horses, &c. indeed every thing; and the money raised on them is lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Well, and what of that? I can work for my living. I care not for it. But you must be miserable. What, cannot I think of some way? are you sure it was on∣ly ill luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: We may resign ourselves to our fate and die. But I know I can play a game well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Then see, I have a little box of jewels given me by my Aunt Van Rissell; it is worth a large sum—This you could not mortgage, for it was not your property.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: But I shall not touch that. It is enough that I am a fool. I will not also be a villain, and spend the last part of my wife's property.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: But you need have no scruple when I give it to you. (She goes out to bring the box.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Miss LEERKINS and Mr. KEPPEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: IT is no matter of my particular concern but I cannot bear your conduct to my sister

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: If she be contented what is it to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss. Leer.
SP.P: You treat my sister ill beyond all sufferance. You leave her alone these long winter evenings, that you may spend your time in taverns, and gaming houses. The whole care of the family rests on my sister; and you are even a stranger in your own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: If my wife be satisfied, what business of yours is it; that you should lecture me on the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: My sister is indeed a fool. She has not the spirit of a woman of sense in her, or she would manage oth∣erwise than she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: What would you do were you in her case.?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P:
Instead of cooking you with all manner of good things, when you come home from your midnight ca∣bals
—I would lay your whole conduct before you. I would sing you such a song of your crimes; that you should go to sleep, if you slept at all, with a sting in your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I advise you if you ever do marry to marry some person who never wishes to sleep, for I am persuaded your tongue must be a mortal enemy to repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: I would not bear with you, as my sister does— I would not discover the least degree of good nature to∣wards you—And I would let you know that I never would, till such time as you would reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Supposing you wanted customers in your shop, would you set a dog on the first person who entered the shop door?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: No, for that would drive them all away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep
SP.P: You would gain as little by scolding at a hus∣band for staying our late.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: Then you might go and shift for yourself if you pleased. I would not concern myself for you in the least, and account myself happy that I was rid of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: If you were fond of me you could not do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: Do you think that I should care for such a wretch as you—why could I not do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: It would make your heart ache, my dear, and you would not bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: Make my heart ache, a fiddlestick. My heart would never ache for such a wretch as you—I almost wish you were my husband that you might see how I would manage you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I have no thought of wishing you to be my wife at any rate—And mind this, that single women always know how to rule their husbands well—but they fail a lit∣tle in two points; either they never get husbands or los the faculty of ruling them the moment they are married.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mrs. KEPPEL and Mr. KEPPEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: HERE my dear take these, and may you be more fortunate than before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: No my dear wife—no, 'tis yours, do not let me ruin you—no.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I value it not, take it, and do your best—I give it you, tis now yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: The kindest creature that ever lives I believe.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—Miss LEERKINS and Mrs. KEPPEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: SISTER I am ashamed of you. You behave out of all sense and reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: You know that your husband has spent all his own estate and yours, and he treats you with the most shameful neglect. And yet you place confidence in him, and have given him the last remains of your fortune. Are you not very foolish?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Perhaps not, but if I be; how can I help it?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: How can you help it. You are a disgrace to your sex—There is no spirit in you; and let him treat you as he will, you are all patience, and dare not resent it. I'd give him a good lecture upon the subject, such as he never would wish to hear again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Then you would never see him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: What then, I should esteem it a happy rid∣dance. So much the better. I would have the whole house to myself and do what I pleased in it—That would not fright me at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: You know nothing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: I know nothing about it—I know that a bad husband is worse than none. I will have a good one or none —What makes you think that I know nothing about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: I won't tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: What? that is kind to be sure—Not tell your sister. But you shall tell me what is the reason I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Positively I will not tell you; wait till you have a husband of whom you are fond—who yet has some vices, as I suppose they all have, and then you will know.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Leer.
SP.P: You treat me so ill—I will not talk with you. (Exit Miss Leerkins, Mrs. Keppel soon follows her.)

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: Mr. KEPPEL and Mrs. KEPPEL. (Keppel enters first, walks about disturbed—she enters soon after.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: O My stars—what a wretch,—I am— ruined,—there is no help for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: My friend, what's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Let me alone—I'm ruined.

DIV2.STAGE: (Mrs. Keppel looks grieved and speaks tenderly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Not unless you are unkind to your wife

DIV2.STAGE: (Keppel looks hard at her, is silent, then speaks.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: O my dear, my wife—I will not be unkind; but I am distracted; I am certainly undone, I have lost all the money I had raised from your box of jewels—O that I could die with innocence; then I should be glad to die.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: What, die, because you have lost your money: fie my husband, fie upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I have now lost every thing, and have com∣pletely ruined you, as well as myself; we are as poor as the poorest beggars—My dear, were it not that I would live as a mere servant to you, I could wish to die.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Do you not recollect that when my mother opposed our marriage you told me, in one of your ardent raptures, nay you solemnly declared, that you could be happy even in the meanest cottage, and to live by the hardest labor, if you could only live with me—I laid that up in my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: That was not the effect of rapture. It was my serious sentiment, and I think so now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Then we have lost nothing; only leave gam∣ing, and we shall be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Leave gaming, I detest it. I perfectly abhor it—I will bind myself by the most solemn engagement nev∣er to touch a card again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Can you keep your resolution?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I am sure that I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P:
Then only quit bad houses and live reputably
with me—I will maintain you and myself—I understand many little handy matters—If my work sells cheap I will work the more, and I am sure I can maintain us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Excellent woman—Your excellence exceeds all the power of language to express it; I am confounded— But the idea of your virtues gives me the keenest pain, while I think I have made you wretched.

DIV2.STAGE: (Mr. Leerkins enters with a box, to him Mrs. Keppel speaks.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Brother, you promised me for the forty pounds I lent you yesterday to let me have all your win∣nings at cards for three days. This sir (introducing her brother to Mr. Keppel) is my brother, yesterday from the East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Leer.
SP.P: Here madam is what I have won this day, and I find I won it of your husband—But it is now yours. I scorn to violate my promise—Here is the whole in mortgages and bank notes. Take it. (She takes it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep
SP.P: Mr. Keppel this is now mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Kep.
SP.P: Accept the whole then as a present from me, I will not be denied.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kep.
SP.P: I am so surprized I can scarcely breathe—O my excellent wife!—Have I then escaped the gulf of ruin. I do solemnly protest I will never touch a card again. For I do verily believe that gaming, drunkeness, and bad company, have destroyed more men, than the sword, pesti∣lence, and famine. (He takes the box and they all withdraw.)

DIV1.HEAD: The Triumph of Temper. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
KEEP YOUR TEMPER, AND KEEP YOUR HOUSE.
DIV1.P: Which ought have the supremacy of a house within doors—might be a delicate question to decide be∣tween a man, and his wife; but a certain matter of fact helps us out. Whichsoever of the parties has the best command of temper and acts most ra∣tionally, will, other matters being equal, have the greatest influence in the affairs of the family.

LIST.HEAD: friends on equal condition, all new married men.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE by way of prologue—JOHN SLY & Dr. BIRCH.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: SUR your servants—what, don't you know old John Sly?

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: I have not the least acquaintance with you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Why that's dismal strange now—that folks don't know their old friends after they have been to college— did not you knw Tom Sly the chimney sweeper—Will Sly the Tinker, and Thoph Sly the Scowerer—up in the other end—there was a whole lane full of Slys.

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: It was of as much consequence to me as if it were full of crows—

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Well sir you know that I pad up and down to sell little books and pamphlets—I lost one that I liked grandly— it used to make me laff. I think—I think, sir, 'twas called Turning the Screw, or some such name

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: You mean Taming the Shrew—we have found such a one—we have altered its name, we call it the Tri∣umph of Temper—my scholars have learned it, and they are to act it this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Will you pay me for it?

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: I have (feeling his pockets) had lately right school masters luck not a penny in my purse; but a scholar when his purse fails must draw upon his genius—here Mr. Sly, did you ever see a play acted?

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Never, please your honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: How should you like to see one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Grandly—sir I should like it grandly.

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: The house is rather full but here set your box down and see how they go on with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Thank you master, a thousand times—the gentlefolks there—won't take it l—

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: No sir, keep your station, and you will not offend any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: WELCOME my friend Horatio—what are you alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Alive? why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I heard that you had been married.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What then? Does that kill folks? so have you been married too—

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: But I mean on account of the woman you married.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I think I married a very agreeable one.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I heard you married Ketura Roughgrain, daughter of old Robert Roughgrain the Peltmonger.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: True, I married her—'twas my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Did you not know what a perfect tygress she was— when at school?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I do not recollect every particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Many a time she has boxed my ears till they were nearly blistered—at other times she has attempted to claw my eyes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: And served you right too—however I shall let your own conscience answer for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Seriously I wonder you had the courage to marry her; for, to speak my real sentiments, she was a perfect fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You do not act right, my friend Bernardo—you see I am married—If your sentiments made any impression it could only make me discontented with my wife. But I think she is a fine woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: You may think as well of her as you please—the happier you, the more you esteem her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P:
Will you, with Marcello, and your wives, sup
with me this evening—you shall see that we are on happy terms with each other. Come early in the afternoon.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—HORATIO and KETURA.
DIV3.STAGE: [She enters with a riding dress and a whip in her hand—Hor∣atio looks surprized.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What my dear, are you going out?

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: Yes, I am. (In a cross accent)

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I had rather you would not go out, we are to re∣ceive company this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: I know it, you mean to invite what company you please—and I must wait on them even to sink with faintness and fatigue; you will have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: We must receive company sometimes if we mean to keep a house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: Yes, I know what a scrape I have bro't myself into by being married; to keep a house, wait upon company and fatigue myself to death and get no thanks for it—I have tried it long enough, and I mean to get away.
Stay my dear, we shall be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: So you told me before I was married, and you de∣serve to be punished for telling me such lies—But that's the way of the men.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: We have not been married long enough yet, to form a judgment of it—We have been married (Looking at his watch) only five days, fifteen hours, fourteen min∣utes, and five seconds.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: You mean to turn it all into mirth; but you will find it a serious matter, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Let it be a serious matter then. We have been mar∣ried five days, fifteen hours, fourteen minutes, and five seconds—and till these last seven minutes, we have been happy. It is about a thousandth part of the time, that we have been on ill terms—Never mind it, my dear—We shall do very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: I have tried it long enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: No we can have no idea of the marriage state yet— Had we lived sixty years together, acquired and expended a large estate, brought up and settled in lie, about a dozen children, then we might be said to know something about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P:
If that is all to be done I will hear no more of it—
I'll get away as fast as I can— (She appears to be going▪ he catches her by the arm, saying) Stay my dear one moment. (She strikes him on the fingers)

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: O you jade! my sweet bride I mean—You'll come back again in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: No I shall never darken these doors again—I am going to my father's house; from whence I came, and from whence I ought not to have come.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You will let me come in the evening and wait on you home.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: No I forbid your ever coming after me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Then if you will not live with me I wish you may be happy without me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: I shall never be happy if you can prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Keen sponk! I vags for that.

She is gone, but I shall manage her well enough yet— It was happy for me that I was able to keep my temper— Had I lost the command of myself I might have ruined all my plan— But I shall have a good wife of her yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Rough.
SP.P: This has been no bad day's work (Casting figures on his hat.) —1600 wt. of skins at an advance of 2 pence on the pound, is thirteen pounds six shillings and eight pence— Not a bad day's work—How do ye do my son? (Looks about him) Where is Ketura?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I thank you sir, we are all well except my wife, who is gone to your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Rough.
SP.P: I tho't you were to have company to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Yes. but she is gone home.

SP.SPEAKER: Rough.
SP.P: Has she any of her old tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Old or new ones, they are such as you see. When she is to receive company she runs home.

SP.SPEAKER: Rough
SP.P: She means to come back again soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: She says she never will.

SP.SPEAKER: Rough
SP.P:
Never will. I'll see to that— You've bought a wild rabbit and you shall keep her—She shan't come home
to make such a carnal noise and racket as she used to do at our house.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Whatever you do, treat her kindly for my sake—I will go to your house in the evening and see if she will not come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: I'd see her burnt first.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—HORATIO, BERNARDO, MARCELLO, PORTIA, JULIA, all enter in succession.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: YOU are welcome my friends you are heartily welcome—my wife is gone out—But such attendance as we can make with our servants we shall give you with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: We heard sir, on our way, of the elopement of your wife, we began to congratulate you upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: What, are they at seperate maintenance already. They ought, in decency, to have waited till the honey moon was over.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Our friend Horatio invited us here, I believe, to see a curiosity—and his wife, I am confident is the great∣est in America, of the kind—but we are likely to be de∣prived of the pleasure of seeing her.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Well, he was not ignorant of what he had when he took her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I shall have a fine wife of her yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Then you will mould dry sand into pye crust, for I should think the order of nature must be changed before you will see a good wife of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You are extremely severe on my wife—but she is a woman of excellent qualities—and I will have a tender, kind, loving wife of her yet—I'm a connoisseur in women.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: You have shown it by your choice, as all the world knows.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—ROBERT, HORATIO, BERNARDO—the rest standing silent, Robert comes in all out of breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: WELL sir your wife is coming home again.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I expected it: but how do you know it is true.?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I followed your directions and stayed about the house to watch her motions; but kept out of her sight, at last the old gentleman came home.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What said he to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: He was in a perfect rage, when he found she talked of staying, he swore she should return that minute—he took your horse with your wife's new hunting saddle, put them into the stable, and locked them up.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: How could she come home then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: He took an old horse out of the plough, whose back was sharp as a pike; and you might have counted his ribs at twenty rods distance—then mounted your wife on an old pannel that shed feathers—with a girt of red tape and the bridle of twenty pieces of sheep's leather—the crupper, of the straps of an old knapsack thus he set her out on her journey. And the old horse could not be got out of a step all the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: How did she proceed?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: The dogs barked, the boys halloed, and the feathers flew all the way, and when the old horse got against the great tavern in the middle of the village, the horse stopped, and the mob gathered round, and huzza'd, and it was sometime before we got him started again.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What became of her after that.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: When we came down the hill by the brook, the old brute stumbled, and threw your wife off—and it was a long time before we could pick her up, and tie up her strings again.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What became of her then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: She burst into tears, for every thing plagued her heart out—and desired me to go forward and ask you to come, and bring her home.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Bernardo, your chaise is ready, let me take it, and wait on her immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: You may take my chaise, but she should di in the street before I would go after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I am not of your mind, I shall bring her home, in the gentlest manner possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: That looks darn'd foolish; but he knows a sheep's-head from a carrot, I'll lay a mug on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: SO he is gone after her; I'm vexed with him that he humours her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: She deserves to lie in the street all night—To abuse so good a husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He may know how to manage her. He had about 150 quarrels with her before she consented to be married. But he made her consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: We will withdraw into the opposite room, for if he fondles and caresses her, when she comes in, I shall lose all patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Best withdraw, and leave them to themselves a little, when they first come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: SEAT yourself, my dearest friend, you must be ex∣tremely fatigued.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: Oh! I am just ready to faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Shall I bring you a glass of wine. This is soft, and pleasant, a little of it will revive you.— (Gives her a glass.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: You are exceeding good to wait on me home, and treat me so kindly.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I am extremely rejoiced to see you come home again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: O what a rash girl I was to leave you in so much ill humor!

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Never think of it a moment. If you are come to live with me again, all is as it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: O sir, you are generous beyond all bounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Very generous to be sure to gain the heart of so fine a woman—But go my dear and wait on the com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: That's right—flatter her up—It works like wool— She'll melt like wax by and by.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—BERNARDO, HORATIO, WILLIAM and KETURA.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: WELL you have brought her home then?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Yes I knew I had as good a wife as any of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: So you have broke my chaise you villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Only I was going to the ale house sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: And got drunk before you went, and drove my chaise into a ditch, and broke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: Bernardo, there must be no noisy passions in my house. Chide your servant else where. This house is sacred to peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: If one were to see you in this trim only, he would think you were an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: ROBERT I understand you have been speaking disrespectfuly my wie—Tell me your wages, let me pay you, and .

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: So I beg you would not send me away, to a dist∣ance from my wife a children.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: No man shll live with me who abuses my wife —You have sinned beynd pardon so you must go.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: Spare him for my sake—He is a good man, do not send him away from his wife, and children.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: See what a good waman you have offended.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I ask a thousand pardons, and will serve you to the last moment of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Go then to your work, and know that he who in∣sults my wife, more than insults me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I HAVE bro't the riding coat I was making for your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: (Taking up the coat and looking at it.) It is too broad acros the shoulders. It is big enough for a Porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot
SP.P: A woman should have broad shoulders who super∣sdes her husband. Pardon a joke sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What pardon a joke, I'll break your back Do you mean to insult my wife. If I hear such a thing from you again, I'll be measure your back, you cabbage eater, till you never shall think of joking again while you live. (Catches his yard stick from him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: (Interposing) Spare, sir, the good man for my sake. (She then takes up the coat and gives direction for alter∣ing it.) Here take it in about so much, and it will do very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: SIT still my dear. I wish to talk with you, we must find some way to restrain these angry passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: He insulted you, had he insulted me, it would not have moved me in the least.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: But I wish we might agree and make is a habit to live in perfect amity with each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: There is nothing I more ardently desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: I wish for it more as I have been erroneous: I need you for my example and guide.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: You can guide yourself—I am not afraid to trust your own discretion for fifty years to come. Do just as you please in every respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: I do not chuse it. You shall be my friend, protector and guide—how happy your goodness makes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What think you now, my bride, cannot persons be happy in the marriage state?

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: O yes, indeed I have enjoyed more happiness, more heartfelt felicity in one half hour, since I returned to you, than in all the rest of my life, you shall this moment accept me as a pupil, and teach me how to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: I will be your friend unchangeably. But we must see our company.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Now madam your'e gone for't, after this you may set up your Ebenezer if you can.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—MARCELLO, BERNARDO and HORATIO.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: THE ladies wish to be by themselves, what say you my friend to taking a hand of cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Horatio will not play, his wife will come and whip him if he does,

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Yes, I will—but a different game from any you imagine. I will bet—tho I'm an enemy in principle to games of hazard. I will—bet—twelve dozen bottles of the best Madeira wine that upon any trial you please, my wife will be more obedient to me than either of yours to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I'll stand with twenty four dozen against twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: So will I, for my sweet girl, and you are taken in, old gentleman, you may depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: What shall be the proof?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The ladies are very busy by themselves, and will be loth to come away —let each send for his wife to come to him immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: That's a good proof—yes—yes—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (To his servant) Duncan, go and tell my wife to come to me immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: (To his servant) William, tell my wife to come to me immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: (To his servant) Robert, tell my wife to come to me immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What says my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Dun.
SP.P: She says she'll come presently, as soon as she has played out her hand of cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: And what does my wife say?

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: She says she is very busy, and she wonders why you cannot have the complaisance to come to her. [While this is doing Ketura comes behind her husband, unseen.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ket.
SP.P: What would you have of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: (Springing up) My dear, you are indeed come your∣self. Sit, my sweet girl. Well, what do you say now, gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: You've won, you have won.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I wonder my wife would serve me so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I'll know the reason, why my wife did not come.

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P:
Patience gentleman—No man shall say any ill-na∣tured thing to a wife in my house—I should deem it a profanation—The great secret of managing a wife is always to treat her kindly; and keep your temper; then if she be not a perfect fury she will do very much as you please to have her—But a man of harsh temper may kill a woman,
but he cannot govern her—You might as well set a black∣smith to making watches.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Well ladies! Ketura has won the prize on the trial of kindness to her husband. She came first of the three—we have lost only twenty four dozen of Madria each. (The ladies look mortified.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Never mind the wine. I'll give twenty four doz∣en, and we will form ourselves into a society for promoting matrimonial happiness—the wine shall serve us when we meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: We all say amen to that. (They assent.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hor.
SP.P: Well then, our supper is ready, we will pass the evening in the true stile of festivity and joy.

DIV3.STAGE: [Actors go off—each gentleman leading out his wife.]

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: A PERSON has put a shilling or two into my hands, I will pay you now for your pamphlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: No matter no, your play has put me into pure good humor—Nothing at all master.

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: Yes take it, and this too. There's your pay. (Gives him one piece) There's interest for the delay of your money. (Gives him another.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Thank you sir a thousand times—But master, your play makes me think—master it makes me think.—

SP.SPEAKER: Birch.
SP.P: Think of what Mr. Sly?

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: My Jane and I had a snapshort this morning and we have not said a good natured thing to each other all day long—But I have a great mind, not to go to a tavern, and swill away alone like a beast—but to buy something good to eat with this, (Shows one piece of money) and something good to drink with this, (Shows the other piece) and go home, and take a sweet little supper with Jane, and set every thing to rights before we sleep a wink. (Slings his box and goes off singing.)

LG.L: MY Jenny was a pretty maid;
And we did love when we were young—
We wish'd to wed; the Parson said
The word, and ty'd us firm and strong.
My Jenny proved a charming wise;
And still is sweet at fifty-five—
She loves me still, which makes me feel
As glad as any man alive.
For love is just like bottled beer,
'Tis pleasanter for being old—
And it is like a buttered toast;
'Tis much the worse for being cold.
The more we love the more we may,
As turns the wheel of life about;—
This spark of fire, in our cold clay,
Is the last spark that e'er goes out.

DIV1.HEAD: The Mother of a Family. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
PATIENCE.
DIV1.P: One of the most useful of human virtues is patience. To bear afflictions and every event which tends to disturb the mind, with calmness, denotes a highly improved understanding. There is no condition of human life which cherishes this virtue so much as marriage. It is easy, and promotes the highest degree of self approbation, to bear distress for the sake of those whom we love.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MRS. GOODHEART—a farmer's wife with a large family.
MISS KEENSIGHT—her younger sister, a manhater.
NELLY — a romp, the third daughter, aged 14.
SOFTLY—woman assistant to Mrs. Goodheart, in the care of the family.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I —Col. RIVERS and Miss KEENSIGHT.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Riv.
SP.P: YOU must know, Miss Keensight, that I have long paid my diligent respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: If you have been agreeably employed they may still continue.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: But I am tired of uncertainties, I wish we could understand one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Well sir what would you please to have?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: Sometime within the limits of duration, I hope you will be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: How yours?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: I mean by marriage, I wish not for equivocation.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: We may wait a little longer.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: I am tired of waiting and wish to have my fate decided.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: There is no need of that.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: I think there is, I will be resolved, and not pay my respects in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Then withdraw them, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: Why then have you detained me so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: It is well enough to have a gentleman to conduct one to balls, assemblies &c. But as for marriage, I detest it—It is of all things the most odious to me.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Riv.
SP.P: This is the most generous speech you ever made to me. Now I know what to depend on. I thank you most heartily and wish you a good evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Where is Col. Rivers, does he not stay to tea?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: No, and I hope he never will pass much of his time in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Good
SP.P: And have you taken offence all at once?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: No, I never felt mysef interested enough, with respect to him, to do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Have you taken a sudden dislike?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: No, for I never liked him or any other man.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: But tell me plainly why does he not stay to tea? I hoped for the pleasure of his company.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: The plain truth must be known, I have given him his final dismission.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You astonish me. What reason had you to discard him? Is he not an accomplished gentleman? Has he not an excellent moral character? Does be not make offers of fortune far beyond any just claim of yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: More than that, I own that be is one of the most agreeable of men; which you may think a simple confes∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I should not think that a good reason for dismis∣sing him.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: That was my reason, I found that if I did not dismiss him soon, I never should.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You are too prudent; and may hereafter repent your discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: My name is Keensight you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: So was mine once but I changed it for Goodheart; & have ever since been glad of the exchange—I found that was the way to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: You happy! Bless my stars▪ you happy! I would not live the life you do for the wealth of the United States, and that is the reason why I will not marry. I would not marry the finest gentleman who treads this earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: So you say now, when you may marry if you please; when you cannot marry you will think otherwise. I have seen maidens of fify setting their caps at young gen∣tlemen of twenty five and rendering themselves perfectly ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: That you will never see in me, so you may set your heart at rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P:
Why not in you as well as in others, and why
should my situation afright you—Why do I not appear to be happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Why should I not think you happy? I wonder you do not die outright with vexation—You work extreme∣ly hard, and have to pay the severest attention from night to day, and from day to night—Your children are the most disorderly crew that ever were hatched, when they are out of humor they are always a bawling—There will be half a dozen of them tuning up at once—They are ever fighting and clawing one another—When they are in good humor they play with execessive noise and violence as if the house were going out at the windows—Then they are upsetting every thing thro the whole house—They are ever breaking their own shins or one anothers noses—They are ever losing their hats and their shoes—One falls down stairs and is tak∣en up half dead—One is burnt and another is scalded— Another cuts his leg, or his hand, and is bleeding to death. Then you are all in tears—and—

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: And can you think of nothing farther? You have not told me half of the truth yet. I have seen and suffe∣red ten times as much as you have any idea of; and yet I am not unhappy—I have a very kind husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: O, yes, I suppose that kind husband makes up for all—He pretends to be fond of you, and flatters you—He is cunning enough for himself. You place entire confi∣dence in him. Were he to tell you that a bedlam was a palace, you would believe him. After your children had worried you all day, on seeing your husband come home at night I have seen you shed tears of joy—and you had to wait on him two hours. I really felt ashamed for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: What a simplicity you are sister, with all your boasted sense.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen
SP.P: Simplicity I will be then—your husband by being so obstinate has brought a lawsuit upon himself, which ma∣ny people say will ruin him. I expect in a few days to see you turned out of house and home. I see plainly that all this is in consequence of your marriage, and if any man ever sees me catched in that trap he shall bless his eyes for the sight. (Exit Keensight.)

SP.SPEAKER: Goodheart alone.
SP.P:
O DEAR, I am extremely fatigued
But I must attend to the business of the family. I should like to take some rest for a few moments, but my children, poor little roges, they must be taken care of.

SP.SPEAKER: Soft.
SP.P: I am glad to find you at home, Mrs. Goodheart, I have a little with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: And I am no less gla to see you. I had thought of sending for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Softly.
SP.P: I wished to know whether I could live with you— you need some person, you are so taken up with the chil∣dren—I will do the work of the family; but I will be treated as a housekeeper, not as a maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You shall be treated as a friend. I will give you more than maid's wages, because being a relation. I hope you will be kind to the children.

SP.SPEAKER: Softly
SP.P: Then I will begin as soon as may be—I am out of business, and am perfectly tired of idleness.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: It is nearly time for tea; go and set the tea table, and get tea soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Softly.
SP.P: I will go then in a moment, for I am happy to have something to do (Softly goes out)

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: alone. I am glad of this girl's coming; she is good natured, and will have patience with the children. Very few of the maids we hire have any discretion to manage the little ones. [Letitia enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: LETITIA, I am happy to see you; take a seat, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I have long wished for an opportunity to visit you, and am extremely gratified that at last I have found one. Where's Nelly?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: She is traipsing about some where. Poor girl— I wish she had a little more steadiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Does she not go to school?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: She is utterly averse to it. She says that she is so big, and so awkward, that she is ashamed to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: But it is a great pity; as she is naturally agree∣able; her genius is good, and her natural disposition excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P:
Poor girl, she has no advantages. When she is at home she is always busy in some family care; and there
is always so much music at our house, that one might as well study in a tavern. [Keensight enters]

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I doubt not that she might be persuaded to o to school, and were she once placed there she would make good progress in her learning.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I wish you would try, for she is so awkward now that I am quite ashamed of her and she is ashamed of her∣self. Her manners are rough—her words are course and her knowledge of grammar is nothing — her pronunciation is extremely vulgar—she writes very ill—and as to arith∣metic and music she knows nothing of either.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: You ought to say she is a monstrous romp and that she spends half her time in company with Jack Lounger. She has no idea of a proper choice of company.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You need not make my girl worse than she is. She is bad enough in her present state. But it is not so much her fault, as of her situation in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen
SP.P: O yes, she is a precious child to be sure, and one of the solid comforts of matrimony, if it were only the mere possibility of having one such child it would forever deter me from marriage. [Exit Keensight.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—LAURA, SOPHIA, LETITIA and GOODHEART.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I DESIRE Ma'am that you would let me look of some of your work—I wish to imitate it.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I have none here my child—I will go out and look for some—But if I do not find any, Letitia will furnish you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I wish you would let me see yours, I have a great desire to go to your house, on purpose to see how you work.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I can show you here. (Shows her work.)

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: O how beautiful this is. It is elegant. I never saw any thing of the sort so pretty. I will try to do something like it. We seldom have opportunity to do any thing ele∣gant—We have to tend the dairy and make coarse clothes for the younger children.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And I will see what I can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: DON'T say any thing to my aunt Keensight about the young gentlemen's coming here this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Why not to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: She says she will drive away the whole tribe of fops from the house while she stays. She won't have her nieces turn fools, and be married as their mother was.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Now which had you rather be, such a woman as your mother; or your aunt Keensight?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: That is easily anwered—I know my mother suffers extreme fatigue and a▪ Yet she is forever pleasant, and good humored My aunt does very little, but consult her own ease. Yet she fets a hundred times to where my ma'am does on . They are sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: What can make the difference?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: When ma'am means to divert us, she says it is be∣ing married that makes the difference, and advises us all to be married, that we may be kept in good humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
