SP.P: It is likely enough to be a serious truth. People who love only themselves will always be fretful; but they who feel kind to other persons will certainly be otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I cannot find any work of mine; but Letitia can answer all your demands. Where is Laura?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: She went out sometime ago, and is not returned.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I wonder what makes her stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: We will go out and see. [All withdraw.]

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: IS not Mr. Goodheart returned?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: He has not certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: I hoped to have seen him before his suit should be determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Why before that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: Because he stands indebted to me for a small sum, and I wish for good security.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Why for security now, when I have often heard you say his word was sufficient?

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: He will do as well as he can, but he may not be very able when he has done with his suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Why, do you think he will lose?

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: I am really afraid he will, I advised him not to go on with it—but he never would hear to me—Let me know when he comes home.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Plain.
SP.P: Be sure you do it. What a pity it was he did not hear to me. [Exit Plainfield.]

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I am sure I did not desire it, unless you had more sense. [George enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: WHAT my son have you come home to tarry. Is it vacation?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No—but I am like to get into a bd scrape at College—I was in company with a set of fellows, who did mischief in the night—and am called to account.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I am afraid that your father and I are never to have any comfort of you George—you are so irregular— and—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Why Ma'am tho I was in their company, when I saw them about to do mischief, I was gone so quick that I could now bring a man to swear I was in another place; and I want to know your advice whether I shall bring the man to swear or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Not certainly, unless to swear to the truth. Tho I cannot wish you to be punished—Yet I do not wish you to escape by any thing which has even the appearance of falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But I am certainly innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Let truth have its course then and it will appear— and you may yet be a comfort to your mother—Go and stand trial and tell no lies. (Exit George.)

SP.SPEAKER: Softly.
SP.P:
Madam, I am very much concerned for Laura—
She has a pain under her left arm near her heart, very sharp and severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: And does that alarm you?

SP.SPEAKER: Softly.
SP.P: Mr. Woodru had just such a pain about three hours defore he died of the appolexy. (She rises to go out▪ and is met by Sally in haste)

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: O dear ma'am, I'm afaid Billy has broke his arm. He has fallen down stairs—and hurt him dread∣fully—He can scarcely move his arm one inch. (Goodheart goes out and Softly follows her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: (To Letitia and Sophia) Now girls let me give you one piece of advice. Above all do you avoid being mar∣ried. It is the worst of all evils. You see what a deplora∣ble situation your mother is in. Her eldest son is going to be expelled from the college—There is one child dy∣ing of the apoplexy. Another has broke his arm, one girl so awkward and so vicious that she plagues her heart out. Her husband absent, and must lose his estate before he comes back. Now young ladies fix the matter in your own minds that you never will be married. Then let the men coax and teaze, and plead, and flatter, and caress you ever so much, be steady, let them know you won't, and that's enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I am rather too old for counsel. I have made up my mind upon that matter sometime ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: And what do you say Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I am fully determined what to do if I have the opportunity of choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: And which way are you determined ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: That must remain a secret. If I say I will refuse, that will offend my mother. If I say I will accept, that will offend you. If I say I will—not▪ at any event, that is insulting the young gentlemen— I say I will, it is like setting up myself for sale like a cheap ric in the mar∣ket. So I believe madam it is best for young ladies never to answer that question till it be suitably proposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen
SP.P:
You are very prudent young ladies, but I under∣stand the matter. It is all done to vex me, done on pur∣pose
I know. [Goodheart returns and seats herself with a number of papers in her lap.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—GOODHEART, SOFTLY, SOPHIA▪ LETITIA, and KEENSIGHT.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: [giving Softly a paper] Here Miss Softly take this and bruise it very fine—moisten it with spirits and warm it over the fire, and lay it on a soft bandage, to put on Bil∣ly's arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Soft.
SP.P: I will do it immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Stay, take this and dissolve it in warm water—then put to it half a glass of wine, a tea spoonful of paregoric— let it remain in a tea cup till I come out.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: How does uncle Goodheart now? One of our neighbors writ home the other day to his wife, that he was likely to lose his cause; and if he did it would ruin him entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I hope not, I am sure: what will become of me and my poor children?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: And did you know ma'am of brother George. It is said he has got into a very bad scrape at college—and is in great danger of public punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Oh dear! I tho't I had trouble enough before.

DIV3.STAGE: [She rises to go out, a great noise is heard, and Softly rushes in.]

SP.SPEAKER: Soft.
SP.P: Oh ma'am, see, only see what a piece of work here is. The tea table is turned over, and every thing is broken to pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: There is half the ware we had in the house brok∣en to pieces—There's that beautiful china bowl, which we made punch in, the evening I was married—and that curi∣ous mug, which we used to call the enchanted mug—with all the tea furniture. How came every thing on the tea-table?

SP.SPEAKER: Soft.
SP.P: I got some drink for Laura in the enchanted mug—and was going to get some in the china bowl for the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: How came the table overset?

SP.SPEAKER: Soft.
SP.P: The children were not to blame. Nabby climbed the back of a chair; and was going to fall, Tommy flew to save her, touched the tea table, and overset it. He is dreadful sorry ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P:
I could be sorry at another time, but I have so
much greater troubles now.—Sister come and help me about the children; and Sophia—you come—I will send Nelly to wait on Letitia.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Little mischievous brats, I am glad I have none of my own to wait on, I know.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.—LETITIA and NELLY.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: WHAT was the reason, Miss Nelly, that you did not go with us to school▪

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Really now what do you think of these times? Ev∣ery body is going to school, do you think they gets any good by it?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Your every body is a small number—There are but thirty persons in the town, who have any education more than in the common schools, and there are a thousand in∣habitants—Divide 1000 by 30 and it will give you the pro∣portion.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: I could not do that any more than I could fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: [Takes a state and makes figures.] See 1000 by 30 quotes 33—that is even more than the number that pay any uncommon attention to learning.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Why the jingo! I tho't it was more. I wondered what we should do for girls to make butter—Uncle Tris∣tram says he hates to have girls go to school, it makes them so darn'd uppish and so deuced proud that they won't work—Mawther want's I should go.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I believe your mother is right and your uncle is wrong—Good scholars are no more idle at school, than at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: But why do you need so much larning; you study religion, d'ye mean to preach? No I see the trick, you mean to marry parsons, and make us poor farmers girls call you madams.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Would it grieve you to marry a person, whose prin∣ciple, practice, and profession, all lead him to treat you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: No fags! that it woud'n't—When I hear a clean looking young preacher hold forth upon love—I cannot help thinking that he would make a jim husband. It is fir'd pretty to be talked to nicely—But one should not think so a sabbadays.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: You correct your improper thoughts I dare say— But eloquence is very pleasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: And you study ratterick at school; the art of talking —now to women it seems to me quite natural—You studies Phlosophy natural and mortal.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: You mean moral I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: It it all one to me—Brother George says Phlosoph∣ers used to wear long beards—He makes fun of you, and calls you the smooth chin'd Phlosophers.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: George shall treat one with more decency than he commonly does, or he shall one day dread to hear the name of the smooth chin'd Philosophers.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Sometimes he is rather too jolly with the ladies— Fawther says 'tis not worth while to send him to college to larn mischief—But dont you think there are clever men at college?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Yes, many of genuine learning, and refined merit, and some otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: But there is one of your studies which I see no use for 'mongst plain working folks—must a farmer learn po∣liteness to talk genteelly to his oxen?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: He must sometimes talk to his children, his friends, his wife. He says to his oxen—Haw and Jee—and "twig up Whiteface." Would you have him say so to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: No—I'd make him know with a vengeance that he should talk handsomer to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: You would wish to have your husband, if he were a farmer, possess a tolerable share of politeness—do you not remember our going up into the further part of the town— called mud-puddle corner, to what they called a frolic?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: A frolic! 'Twas a right down jamm. The fellors were as drunk as wheelbarrows. The girls were all dashed into nothing and were as dumb and dismal as all nature. Had I known afore how I should have felt I would not have gone any more than I'd have flewed.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: And do you not remember our going to Fairside— did you not like the entertainment?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P:
Yes that was nice at any thing. 'Twas as 'cute as a jewel. They did not say: came along Nell—and here it goes Nell—but shall I have the pleasure to dance with you Miss Nelly. Shall I help you to a slice of orange, Miss Nel∣ly—They would not laugh at, and mortify one, that did
not talk so coupee. They treated me so well that it really made me feel purely.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: The men in Fairside are in the same employments as those in mud-puddle corner. Then education makes an agreeable difference. Did any of the gentlemen visit you since?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Yes several times Mr.—N— (whispers to Letitia) and he bro't me a fine pair of verses all writ out in prose.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: In prose! you mean in verse. Poems are always written in verse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: That's the way I always come off, when I try to talk genteel, sometimes I think I never will try again.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: But were you properly instructed, you might try; and meet with success.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: But don't you think the folks in the right down genteel, nipping way, are more deceitful than others?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Not always; but some think it genteel to treat peo∣ple handsomely when present, and when absent to render them ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Law! mercy on us—I'll never be genteel then▪

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: But could you gain esteem by a suitable behavior?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: That I should like desperately.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: And that is real gentility.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: But how will the young fellows take it if we shine away and don't like their humdrum ways—Won't they be as mad as vengeance—and ashociate with the girls who don't go to school?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Let the ill bred women and the ill bred men go to∣gether—if they leave the well bred men to us we will thank them—Do you not think I am right my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: I obsarves since you went to school that you often calls me my dear, and my friend. Do you really think so, or do you only mean to palaver—some folks says it is all a am, and that you mean nothing by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I mean what I say, and always shall be really hap∣py to have you for my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Well now if I really tho't I could get a nice hus∣band I don't know but I should try to larn—what likeli∣hoods do you think there is that I shall be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: In the country—it is calculated that of 78 women who live to 18 years, 72 are married under thirty—then (figures on a state) as 72: 6: 12—1—twelve for being married to one against it—well bred women have a fairer prospect still.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: They told me Arithmetic was a dry study. I am sure it is quite entertaining—Ma'am will be glad of it— I'll go to school with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: I advise you to maintain that resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: Well now this beats all, that you should tell by arithmetic the likelihoods of being married—I'll learn arith∣metic, I vum I will. Good-Nighty.

DIV3.STAGE: (Drops a low curtesy and goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Let one, if you be going out, walk with you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—GOODHEART, NELLY, SALLY and KEENSIGHT.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: IT is said that if troubles come fast they will soon be over—Mine come fast indeed—I am determined not to lose patience, for then I shall be truly miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Nel.
SP.P: (Rushing in) O ma'am I'm willing, I'm willing to go to school.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I am very glad to hear it; I have been very much mortified that you were so averse to learning—I hope you will make up lost time—you shall go to school next week.

DIV3.STAGE: [Sally enters with a basket of fruit.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: See ma'am what beautiful fruit; I pick out the best for you, because you are so good to me. Are all mothers so good to their children?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I believe they are generally well disposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Then I guess they are quite happy, for it makes me feel nicely when I do things that are good.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Then you feel nicely now I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: O yes ma'am—I am always very glad when I have done any thing to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You are a very good child my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: I hope I shall make papa say the same when he comes home. I will gather a fine basket of fruit for him —William has given me a fine melon—It is yellow as gold, I will save that for pà. The men are very good to work for us, and raise fruit and almost every thing we have.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Yes, and ladies may respect them in a proper manner—at least they may respect their own fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: And if your girls don't worship the men I shall think they have not the least spark of their mother's genius.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: But if pa loved us as much as we do him, would he go away and stay from us so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I do not knew when he will return, nor in what situation of his affairs. (She covers her face and wipes her eyes.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—SOFTLY, GOODHEART and LAURA.
DIV3.STAGE: (Softly enters at the beginning of the scene.)

SP.SPEAKER: Softly.
SP.P: Madam, Billy's arm gets better very fast, he can move it now very easily—It is only bruised and will get well soon, I am glad for the poor child's sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You may take off the bandage then and bathe it in spirits and it will do. (Laura enters.) Why Laura, my good child, are you come? I was afraid I never should see you well again.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes ma'am I am quite easy now—I hurt my∣self by drinking cold water—I dared not to tell while I was ill for fear of increasing your concern—But I am very sure that I have suffered enough to make me careful for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I hope you will be, for many persons have died by such imprudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I have just received a letter from George. He is acquitted, and says he is resolved to live a sober, steady life.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: That is great joy to me if he resolves he will do so—for never was a person more fixed in his purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: There is a person knocking; shall I go and wait?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Yes. [Exit. Laura.]

DIV3.STAGE: [Sophia and Letitia enter showing Sophia's work.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—SOPHIA, GOODHEART, LETITIA, and LAURA.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.P: What do you think of this ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: You did not do this?

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: Yes, she did ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: It is certainly very elegant.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P:
It was almost the first work of the kind that I ever
did; but I paid great attention. Here Laura enters with a bundle and letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: If I know by what means I could reward you for such a piece of work; I would certainly do it, for it is indeed very fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I will do as good a piece as she has done when I get entirely well, and then you may reward us both, for here is a letter of my father, which says that he has got his cause with damages and costs, and uncle Trueman, whose will was not to be opened till six months after his death, has left us two thousand pounds. And here is a bundle too.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: (Opening,) So here's a letter too, and what a beautiful silk, well I believe he has met with good success, a fine silk and a great deal of it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: There is enough to make you a gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: There is enough for a number of gowns, But— (reading a letter.) —But haste, get tea, your father writes that he shall be at home on Thursday at six o'clock, that will be in half an hour. (Looks in her glass.) Bring me a clean cap, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: That is curious, I have not seen you look in your glass till now for three weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: True my husband was gone, and I felt very little ambition to shine, now he is coming home after so long ab∣sence—I own—I should be happy to be agreeable to him.

DIV3.STAGE: (Sophia comes, and she puts on her cap)

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: O yes, and we must all worshp him to please you and we shall have sweets and dears and fond questions till we be perfectly sick.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Now sister that is quite wrong. We ought to re∣joice in mutual good-will, for the sudden happy change in our prospects—I shall give my sincerest thanks to heaven— for our prospects, from the most dark, are alered to the most joyful, in one half hour—And thus it often is in the affairs of a family—and generally, there is an endless va∣riety of events—and if we trust divine providence all turns out happily. (Sally runs in and cries out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Pà is coming; Pà is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: (Rising suddenly.) I will wait on him myself; no one shall deprive me of that happiness.

DIV3.STAGE: [She flies out in extacy of joy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Before I'd be so fond of a man, I'd live an old maid till I pin'd all away to breath and bones.

SP.SPEAKER: Let.
SP.P: That will no doubt be your fate▪ Aunt, and to bones without breath you must pine, madam. But girls I commend your mamma's attention; soft arts and kind al∣lurements are the only ways for womn to carry their points—They never get any thing by angry coests.

LG.L: She who her husband by peverseness pains,
Finds dull neglect and coldness all her gains;
But she who acts the patient, modest part;
Seems to obey; but reigns within his heart;
From all observers merits honest fame;
For every age veres the matron name.

DIV1.HEAD: The Captive. A DRAMATIC PIECE, IN FIVE ACTS.
COMPASSION TO THE MISERABLE.
DIV1.P: This may justly be ranked amongst the brightest of human virtues. Nor is it any part of supersti∣tion to believe, that he who is kind to persons really in distress will be paid in the kindness of Heaven. The liberal soul shall be made fat, and he that watereth shall be watered also himself. —And when our Savior describes the kindness of the good Samaritan, he says to each of his auditors— go thou, and do likewise.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: DAMARTIS—the woman who buys the captive.
TRYPHENA—the woman who sells the captive.
LASYRA—the other captive living with Tryphena.

DIV1.P: SCENE.—A citizen's house in Elis, a city of Peloponesus, subject to the Spartans.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: MELANCHOLY, my dear friend, seems to have taken entire possession of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: And why not—I lost my husband in the bloom of life, three of my sons fell in battle—and in the last siege of this town I lost my only daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Why, of all valuable things, did you not secure your daughter! An only daughter too?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: The town was taken in the night. The inhabit∣ants fled every way—I missed my daughter in the crowd, and saw her no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Do you think she was killed?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I cannot think so—The learned and polite Athen∣ians our conquerers, invited all to return to our homes the next morning. No carcases, no stain of blood, was seen in the streets, no house was damaged, mine was just as I left it. But my little daughter I saw no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: I am very sorry for your distress, and should feel it more if I had experience.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Bitter indeed to a mother is the loss of her chil∣dren—I often run like a distracted creature, and search for my little darling thro the whole house—rummage her cas∣kets and boxes. And finding no relief from my pain, throw myself down on the bed, where he little jewel used to lie; and resign myself to all the agonies of grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Perhaps your daughter may yet be alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I fear that more than her death, that she is alive, and a slave—Good heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: You must miss her in your household affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: That I do. One's own children are worth twice as much as strangers. They feel for the interest of the family. And we are, naturally, inclined to be pleased with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: How can you perform your household work?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: What happens to be done is done, the rest is left undone—Hired servants have vexed me to death—I have none of them▪

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: But you cannot hold out to do all your necessary work.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: My health by sorrow and extreme labor is on the decline—I have tho't of purchasing a captive for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Would you deal in that inhuman traffic.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Not to make any one miserable but to make one happy—I would treat her as mine own child. Then I would pray to the Gods for mine own poor child in cap∣tivity.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: I know a lady who has two very likely captives— She needs but one, I will speak to her on your behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: MY deared Niece, If fortune sent you to me, I am obliged to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: It was not fortune but pleasure—The pleasure of seeing and talking with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I thank you. Do you know any thing of a cap∣tive, which Tryphena has to sell?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Yes. But you would not like the reason she has for selling her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Tryphena's son is in love with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I will not buy her, I will have none of their base amours at my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: He would be angry if you tho't him base. He courts her in form like any fine lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Then I think I would buy her, tho I should ask an abatement in the price.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Would you run such a risk?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: She might prove to be good for nothing, and she might be an excellent girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I have heard many house keepers say that girls are good for nothing after they are courted.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: It is according as their natural temper may be— It alters them certainly—It makes good girls better, and bad girls worse. But my car is ready, I will go and see the woman who has the captive to sell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I'M afraid, sir, you mean to deceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: No my girl, no, not for my life, see here. Do not I always treat you with as much respect as any lady whatever?

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: You do, and I wonder how you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: It is because I know you to be a fine girl, you was certainly born of very good parents and your early educa∣tion was virtuous and genteel—Can you remember noth∣ing of your parents?

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Yes, they lived very well—But they have chan∣ged my name so often, and sold me backward and forward —that I hardly recollect where they lived.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: No matter, I will leave no means untried to dis∣cover them—Till then, I will do every thing for you and ask no reward—only—Remember that lad that loves you. (Exit Philander.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: What a fine young gentleman—How kind he is to me, and treats me with as much respect as if I were a god∣dess. Now if I were not a captive how happy I could be.

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: MELISSA what makes you cry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Your mother means to sell me, what have I done?

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: It is not because she dislikes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Does she know of your brother's kindness to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: I believe she understands that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Then I am undone indeed. I do not wonder she resolves to sell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: You are not to blame, you never sought his ad∣dresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I never did, but I was born to be wretched. I was taken from my mother in the night, sold for a slave, have had my name changed a number of times, have been sold this way and that way. Here your brother, by his kindness, softened the rigor of my captivity Now I am to be sold, all my hope is lost, my life ends in wretched∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: I do not believe my brother will ever forsake you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Then I shall ruin him—I shall destroy the youth whose happiness should rather be bought with my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Philo.
SP.P: Shall not I then tell him whither you are gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I ought to say no. I ought to say, Philander you must see me no more—But O Philomede you know noth∣ing what pain this heart has felt. Yes Philomede tell him where I am to live—His wisdom may save him, tho my folly would destroy him.—But I am called, and must go to your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: (entering) YOU may stay where you are, Melissa; we may as well do it here as any where—this is the girl whom I propose to sell, she is a healthy strong girl, I be∣lieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I am principally concerned to know whether she be a good girl. For I mean to treat her as if she were mine own daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I thank you madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: What do you ask for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: She is worth at least twenty five Attic talents.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I shall not give that for her, for a reason that has been told to me, (Melissa hides her face) and for which you want to get rid of her—I will give you twenty, and no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: Were it not for the circumstance you mention—you should not have her for thirty, and ten more.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: But you must keep your son at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: I shall find means to do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P:
You may send her this very afternoon, with her
little property that must come with her, and the money shall be ready.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: (The scene changes to the house of Damartis, the captive enters in her working dress, and lays down a bundle of cloaths.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: (alone) WHAT a miserable life is allotted to me— born to an easy life, but hurled by war from my peaceful habitation—I could almost wish eternal perdition' on ty∣rants and ambitious men. How many sweet maidens, the hope of prosperous families, are sold into slavery—how many widows mourn the loss of their husbands, cut off, in the very bloom of life. The blood of the finest youth fat∣tens the fields of Arcadia. As for me, wretched I am, and wretched I must be. Since I became sensible of the loss of liberty—every thing looks dark about me. Earth is a dungeon, and the sky frowns on me from above—bo't and sold like a beast— O wretched, bitter slavery—Is there no remedy but death—the generous Philander only makes me wish to live. But now I lose him—O welcome, most welcome would be the sleep of death, to a poor captive who has lost her liberty—lost her fortune, lost her poor broken heart and is weary of the world▪— (Melissa sits down and covers her face and weeps, and remains silent for some min∣utes then starts up suddenly.) —Captivity itself has some good in it, it teaches invention—my new mistress' niece comes to appoint me my employment. What if I tempt her to let Philander have access to me with the offer of favoring her on like occasions. (Lemone enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: (courtsying) MY sweet lady I was waiting for your orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem
SP.P: Well I can tell you what will please you, my aunt if you please her, means to treat you as her own daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I have been told so a great many times, and had to work extremely hard after it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: You will not be deceived here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: There was a young gentleman who treated me as a brother at Tryphene's house—will he be permitted to see me here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I have heard that he was more than a brother to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Perhaps you know what it is—if you can give him liberty to see me, perhaps I can requite the favor in kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: No, Melissa, I can do nothing in that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: But if I should let him come, would you expose me to the family?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Perhaps not—people of our age do not commonly think so bad of those matters as older people do—but come with me, I must show you your work in the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: MY good madam will grant me one very small favor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Not till I know what it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: That my friend Philander may come to this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: He shall not come, I know what he wants, to in∣dulge himself with Melissa.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: No madam upon his honor he only wants to speak with you—he will say nothing to any other person unless you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: He shall never have access to Melissa, I can prom∣ise him.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: That shall be as you please. [Exit Artamon.]

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: MADAM, your most obedient servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Sir, I know what makes you so complaisant, you wish to have access to Melissa. (Coldly)

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You mean to treat her as your own daughter. She is worthy your care.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Yes, sir, that is my determination.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: And as you would have your daughter treated in captivity—Your sentiment is excellent. It is uncommon and generous.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I think it is not bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: And I think it a mean thing for a young fellow to creep into a house unknown to the owners—I ask liberty to visit your daughter Melissa—I think of her as you do, I wish to treat her in the same stile.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: You are a sly rogue—It is your maxim I believe to court the mother instead of the daughter—I won't break my word, you may come.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Madam I thank you. (Bowing respectfully he withdraws.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: That wretch! I was predetermined to refuse him, but he was so bold, and so sly, and so polite—and I being a woman, how could it be done—that I should refuse him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: YOUR project appears to me quite a wild one.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: So does every thing that is generous to a person of a cold heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Let us then hear the whole of your sweet project.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Her clothes shall be made just as if she were my own daughter, and she shall have the same education.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: I fancy the little thing has moved the feelings of your compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: She has, and I am not ashamed of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Our philosophers would laugh at you for such a sentiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P:
I care for our Philosophers in general as I do for a set of old broomsticks—They study four or six years in some academy or university, and come forth with all their
paradoxes about sensation and ideal existence—Liberty and necessity—But friendship, domestic care, and tenderness of heart, are to them inexplicable mysteries.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: They would think you mad, in your project con∣cerning this girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Those who expect good things of the Gods must do good things themselves—By these very means the hearts of those who have my daughter may be turned to pity her, and I may discover her yet before I die.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—TRYPHNA, CLIMENE, DAMAKTIS, and MELISSA.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: IF my son comes to your house you must send him back again immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Clim.
SP.P: Will you not let him see this lady's daughter?— She adopts her captive as her child. I am sure every body will laugh at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.P: My son shall not associate with her. He have her for his wife? I'll find other employment for him, I prom∣ise him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: I shall do what I think reasonable and proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: (From behind one edge of the curtain.) That's right▪ my new mistress is better than my old one.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: HAVE you dressed her up as my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I have, and she looks sweetly. She is a pretty girl, and as genteel as one of the first rank.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Introduce her then. (While Lemone is gone out Dam∣artis talks to herself.) How the conscience feasts itself on good actions—Never did I take pleasure in doing a kind∣ness, as I do in relieving the miseries of this girl—There is something very interesting in her appearance—How dread∣ful it is to think of Women, born of respectable parents, sold f slaves.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P:
Here madam is your pennyworth. (Introducing
Melissa.) I think you have good judgment in buying girls —If I tho't you had as good a taste for boys, I would get you to buy a sweetheart for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: O you sweet little nymph, I want to kiss you this minute—But I won't be quite a fool—Come miss, and sit down by me. You seem to look quite smiling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: It feels good to be well dressed. I have not had on a good suit of clothes these six years.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam
SP.P: (To the girls.) There is company, girls, go and wait on them in.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Since I concluded to treat this girl as my daugh∣ter, fancy is busy to find a resemblance of her—She feels to me like my own flesh and blood—What lively eyes, so much like my husband! Her forehead and eyebrows too are like his! But alas! it is all a delusion—Had my daugh∣ter been in all Geece, by the pain, I have taken, I must have found her.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—LASYRA, DAMARTIS, LEMONE, and MELISSA.

SP.SPEAKER: Lasyra.
SP.P: So miss you have got to be a fine lady—you won't speak to a body I suppose: I wish this lady would buy me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: My aunt does not wish for two girls.

SP.SPEAKER: Lasyra.
SP.P: When you come from our house you left your key, and a little casket. Madam do you not think this to be a very curious key? (showing it to Damartis)

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: This key? (looking at it) is mine: where did you find it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lasyra.
SP.P: It belongs to the little casket she always had— I bro't the little casket too, which she left at our house.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: The key is mine certainly, and I suspect you to be my own child, O heav'ns!

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Well madam if I be your own child; will you not let Philander come and see me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: O yes, if you be my daughter you shall have a sweetheart and every thing else, that is good—But we will be sure of that first; run, and fetch the casket. (Lasyra goes and brings the casket in.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lasyra.
SP.P: This is that she always had with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P:
This casket is mine certainly—But my daughter
had the scar of a burn on her left wrist. Let me see. O how my heart beats with anxiety. (Looks at her wrist). O my soul she is my own child. (Here the curtains should close.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: (Clasping Melissa in her arms.) O my sweet child, let me fold you in my arms, and be the happiest mother in the whole nation of Sparta.

DIV1.HEAD: Ronscevalles. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
SELF GOVERNMENT.
DIV1.P: To govern one's temper, inclination, and passions, comprehends almost the whole substance of virtue. It gives any person great security against the in∣trigues of the vicious, and the stratagems of the artful. This self government chiefly depends on a comparative slighting of temporal concerns, when set in opposition to the solid recompence of virtue, and the rewards of another life.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: SILVANO—an officer express from the camp.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: DONNA CLARA—aunt and governess to the young Princess.
ISABELLA—rival of Maria, with regard to Alonzo.
FIVE LITTLE GIRLS—who enter in one scene only —The action the drama celebrates is supposed to have taken place on the day of the famous battle of Ronsce∣valles.

DIV1.P: SCENE—A pavilion, on a hill near the plain of Ronscevalles.

SP.SPEAKER: Xim.
SP.P: DONNA Clara, I esteem it my duty, to warn you of a danger, which threatens the princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: What do you mean in particular? There are a thousand dangers which threaten young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Xim.
SP.P: I mean the attention of Alonzo to her. The pre∣sumptuous boy is heir to the Castilian government, only in the third degree.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I have observed their motions. There is scarce∣ly any thing in this court which can escape me.

SP.SPEAKER: Xim.
SP.P: I do not deny your vigilance; but would, as a faithful servant of the public, discharge my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I shall be always guarded, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: MY good princess, there is a certain point of dis∣cretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria
SP.P: Bless me! My dear governess, have I failed in any point of discretion?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: No, you never have failed, my fear is only that you may fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Have I not always, my dear governess, listened to your advice▪?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: It is only—this. You, if any person, must one day be the first lady in Spain. Remember that. A word has been dropped about the General's son.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: And can that bear any reference to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I hope not, and it is my duty to tell you, it must not—Because you are one day to be the first lady in Spain. You must not consult your own happiness; but love and hate only as the court directs you—Alonzo is related to the government, only in the third degree—you understand me, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Then I must have no affection for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: That is it exactly. What a fine princess! How quick and ready you are. You will remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: (Alone.) REMEMBER it! well indeed I may, from the pain it gives me—They call me princess, but— in my kindest affections, I must not consult my own hap∣piness, but merely the interest of the state. Is it so indeed? Then I had rather be a shepherdess. (Louisa enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My excellent princess, why so sad to day? That mind is too delicate to bear the pangs of grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I hope I am not more sad than usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Positively, my dear princess, you are. Would I be sad to make another happy: what a fortunate boy is my Lord Alonzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Shame on you, Louisa, to talk such nonsense, what is my Lord Alonzo to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Nothing as yet, only I suppose you wish he may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Louisa, who has given you power to take such liberties with me? I shall not be so harsh as to order you out from my presence, but if you proceed, I shall absent myself, and leave you to your own medications.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Nay but my dear princess be not angry. I ask pardon, I only enquire why you cannot always be light, and easy like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How can I be light and cheerful? This day a battle is determined. In yonder plain it will be tried, in three hours, or less, whether the Christians or Moors are to be masters of Spain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: And what of that? The men love to fight. Let them have enough of it. Whoever be the conquerers, it concerns not you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Whoever be the conquerers they will pay attention to the ladies, I suppose—Pleasure is my maxim; I live to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Can you not feel the loss of your friends? Can you part with your religion, and become a slave to the slaves of Mahomet?

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Much the same—Whoever governs, the fate of woman is subordination—Yet still, had I a lover in the battle, and he led the van, ah! Alonzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Leave me, Louisa, leave me. You are so imper∣tinent that I must desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: As I cannot love, myself, I delight to plague those who do, I know. [Exit Louisa]

SP.SPEAKER: Maria
SP.P: alone. Why all these hints at Alonzo? Have I a tenderness for him? Let me examine my own heart. It never yet deceived me. I admire his virtues. So does every one beside. Is the whole nation in love? I think his ad∣dress is elegant. So do all others. I rejoice in his suc∣cesses. They are useful to the public. His attentions please me. So they please my aunt, old, and grave as she is. His absence makes me uneasy—Is this owing to tenderness? No—He is valuable to the nation: and it is a pity that so fine a youth should be lost. So, Maria, this heart is sound yet, and I am glad of that. [Enter Isabella.]

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I AM come to you with a matter, which is very se∣rious. It is spread thro the whole court.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I am afraid your reputation is ruined forever. I could not have tho't such a story would have spread so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What story?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I am ashamed to mention it; but perhaps it is the only way to prevent its spreading.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pray, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I am ashamed to tell. But they say that you, re∣gardless of the nation's honor, and interest, as well as your own; have married Alonzo privately; contrary to the ad∣monitions of your friends, and every principle of right.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: A likely story, I wonder who made it. Have they not something to say about Alonzo too?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: It is said▪ and every body believes it, that he is a most debauched fellow and associates with the vilest wom∣en in the Court and Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And nothing more? That is not half scandalous enough Were I at the cost of a lie, I would tell a big one.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: They say he is the meanest of all cowards: that in the last battle, he ran away from the head of his division, and hid himself under a baggage cart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That is scandalous enough I find the matter to be very serious —Who do you think invented these lies?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: That must be a secret▪ at present: But I am sure it concerns you very much, to put a stop to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What, in the warmth of your friendship, do you advise me to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Forbid Alonzo your presence entirely. That is the only way to stop every one's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Then he will be wholly at leisure to give his attentions to you. I thank you madam for your good advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: You will do as you please. If you will not take my advice you must abide the consequence. [Exit Isabella]

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: YOU did right to affront Isabella. She is the most impertinent girl that ever existed.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: She has no cause to be offended.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: She means to injure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: And I had almost said, who does not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: You may depend on my secrecy.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I have no mysteries to trust to you, or any one else.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Only with regard to my lord Alonzo. That is all, my dear princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Not with regard to him. The public is pleased with him, so are you, and Isabella, and twenty others, and I among the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: So you are afraid to trust me—If so I shall attend to other matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P:
(alone) So here are the pleasures of being a princess. I must love and hate only for the public good, and give up all idea of my own happiness—I am envied
by one, rivalled by another—maligned, and teazed by them all—yet never did harm intentionally in my life—how dearly do they, who govern nations, pay for their pre-emi∣nence. [Exit Maria.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: I HAVE done all you desired me?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: And with what success?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: She owned every thing so frankly, that I could discover nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Do you suppose there is any concern of importance between her, and young Alonzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: I know not: she professed the same regard for him that others had, and behaved with the utmost com∣posure.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: She is a strange girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: And you might say, she is a good girl, she is a person of as delicate a mind, and as perfect self command, at I ever saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I should like her virtues better if they did not op∣pose my happiness. And if I can discover any intrigue of hers; I will improve it to my own advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: In what manner?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I will inform the court—Alonzo is only heir in the third degree to the government. Should I only know that she was attached to him, I could have her shut up in a convent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Then perhaps Alonzo would be banished, and what would you gain by your intrigue?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: I may have the satisfaction to find that he is not attached to another, and that he cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: I should esteem that a very cold comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Cold as it is, it is the best that I now have—but I will try this matter further. [Enter Lorenzo.]

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: AH! Lorenzo—what news have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: The battle is determined, and the troops in great spirits—young Alonzo has a great honor conferred on him this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: He is to lead the van, as he requested.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: That is a post of honor: but is it not a post of great danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: It certainly is, and few envy him his station.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Be sure to tell Martinez of that; she will tell Maria.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Martinez, you have heard of young Alonzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: He will make Maria's heart ache to day, for he com∣mands the first attack, and in all probability he must be killed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: The princess shall know of that, and then we will see how madam will keep her composure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What is the reason that all you ladies seem to be envious of the princess Maria? Is there no man about the court worthy their notice but Alonzo? (Exit Lorenzo.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—MARTINEZ and MARIA.
DIV3.STAGE: (Maria walks pensive across the stage—turns, and Martinez pursues her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: MOST respectable princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why, Martinez, do you pursue me every where? Can you not suffer your respectable princess to enjoy her∣self one moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: If my presence be in the least troublesome I with∣draw. [Withdraws suddenly.]

SP.SPEAKER: Maria
SP.P:
alone. What is this. Chilly horrors run thro my nerves, and veins; and I am cold as if dipt in the Stygian lake. What is the cause? Only that I have heared that Alonzo commands the van in this day's battle. His life
will be the forfeit of his bravery—I have watched my heart that it might not oppose duty—The least spot of indiscretion has never tainted my imagination—Why then should I dread the fate of Alonzo—Alas Maria, thou hast thy af∣fections too—But they are pure, and pure they shall be.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—ISABELLA and MARIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: (Assuming coolness and composure.) MY princess, the battle is determined and Alonzo begins the attack.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That I believe, for you look as pale as a ghost.— Are you afraid he will be killed?

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: He is very brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He is! O, I tho't the last time I saw you that he was a great coward—But he is truly brave, and he con∣quers, or falls this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Do you think he will be killed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I expect nothing else, I depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: (Falters and walks trembling away—then speaks faint∣ly.) Martinez, bring me a cordial, and some water.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (Observing her.) So in attempting to catch me you have caught yourself. But why does the girl delay to re∣lieve her—I will go myself. [Exit Maria.]

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: (Faintly behind the curtain.) Martinez bring me some water.

DIV3.STAGE: (Louisa coming to her assistance, brings her back to the stage and seats her, and offer her a cordial and some water.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Take this, and it will revive your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Has any one come from the field of battle?—Have you heard any thing of Alonzo?

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Not a word. But suppose he is killed—There are a thousand other coxcombs in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: You never lost a friend I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: I never had one to lose—All that I care for is to live easy. I never loved any person in m life.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: That is the reason why no one ever lved you

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P:
Probably enough; bu why should I entangle
with the cares of half the world. Come cheer up. One party no doubt will win the day—And they will take notice of the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: There needs something more than nonsense to com∣fort an afflicted heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Come Louisa, lead her to my apartment, and let her take some rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Rest I fear is no more for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: I heard this moment, but I did not tell Isabella, that the Spaniards have gained the victory, and that Alon∣zo is killed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: It is just what I expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Then you never had any partiality for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How do you know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Because the hearing of his death does not disturb you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You sharp folks know nothing—You may tell whom you please that I had. And now he is dead I will show all the respect to his memory I can. You can search bad hearts; but you know nothing of good ones. Go and call my little girls. (Five little girls enter and pay their hon∣ors to Maria▪) My little girls, your Lord Alonzo is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: A Girl.
SP.P: What not my Lord Alonzo!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, he was killed in battle this day, while he de∣fended us all, and beat the Moors. (The little girls put their handkerchiefs to their faces.) Don't cry my children; it will do no good. Go, and get your little baskets, and gather red baum, meadow-pinks, marjoram and other sweet flow∣ers— So when they bring up the corpse and lay it out in state you shall go with me, and we will dress the bed with flowers. (The little girls go out curtsying to Maria)

SP.SPEAKER: A Girl.
SP.P: We will do it for we always loved my Lord Alonzo. (Speaking as they go out)

LG.L: Now could I weep. This day proud Spain has lost,
Her seate's blossom, and her martial boast;
But why should sorrow fill these melting eyes,
For one whose merit lives beyond the skies.
The hard commands of power, the source of woe,
Barred all our hopes and prospects here below.
By generous death, Alonzo now is free,
And the same fate the heavens design for me.
No joys for me, can wretched Earth supply;
And my heart dies in me, I feel it die.—
I'll meet Alonzo in the realms above;
Where angel-minds are not ashamed to love.—
There shall the generous passion be supplied,
And heaven shall give what envious earth denyed.
Meantime with him it soon shall be my doom,
To fill the cold recesses of the tomb.
Nigh his cold corpse shall my cold ashes lie;
Till the last trump shall call us to the sky.—
Nor yet shall envy blast my spotless fame,
Since in the grave, there's neither sin, nor shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: NOW Alonzo is gone, Maria and you will contend no more about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: But how does she bear it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: She says she is not uneasy that he is dead — she never could have enjoyed his society in this world, she means to enjoy it in heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: A saucy toast; I could tear her eyes out—I have a great mind to die first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: You will not have the courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: True, I never could bear to think of any thing but the pleasures of this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: These sublime characters have the advantage of us—they expect to be happy in whatever manner they exist. I have tho't so much of it that: I am almost deter∣mined to quit dissipation, and be a sober considerate girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: So have I, but some amusement has always put it out of my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: LADIES you know the loss of Spain this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Would you command us in any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: You must assist the mistress of the wardrobe in procuring the necessary dresses, for the court must all go into mourning. (Isabella and Martinez go out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: WHAT have you been doing with the little girls, Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I sent them into the park to gather flowers to dress the bed of the deceased young general.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: It is suitable to his merit; no one will blame you now he is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Blame me or not, I shall do it. Persons in public station cannot honor their friends while living— Must they be restrained from it when they are dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: They will not be. But you have a new duty— To forget Alonzo in less than a month.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: In less than a month!

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: It would be a disgrace to a princess to mourn longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I knew we were restrained in our joy, but I thought we might mourn as long as we pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No you must neither love nor hate, laugh not cry, sleep nor wake, eat nor drink, but for the public good, and by leave of the nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What reward have we for this?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: The trouble it costs them who govern except now and then to be shot at or pelted—as they ride the streets—assaulted by a mob — libelled in public bills, or burnt, or hung in effigy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Are these the blessed effects of supremacy?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: The precise fate of all the great characters I have heard or read of: tho some have obtained reputation after death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Then I resign the succession.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Asking your pardon—that will throw the nation into a quarrel—it must not be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I will die then.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: You must not die unless the State pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I wonder you can be witty upon so dreadful a subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I am as serious as the subject itself. Twenty phy∣sicians may be employed to keep you alive to a certain period—then you may die by the public executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I shall deceive their hopes, I am now threaten∣ed with a decline.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: But the Duke of Lemos means to demand you in marriage in a few days.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: The man whom of all beings I most detest—I trust I shall do as I please in that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Nay you must marry him if the court pleases; and love him too, or all the nation will hate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Now I shall die certainly—The loss of Alonzo, and the marriage of the Duke of Lemos will soon bring me to an end.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—LOUISA, who enters here; CLARA and MARIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: There is the strangest story told here that ever was heard—Alonzo is not dead. He was wounded, but has recovered his senses and they are bringing him back in triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: They are indeed! I will know the truth of this affair—Maria what will you say now?

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I am petrified with astonishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: It is true, an officer reports it who comes express to the court.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Alonzo had rather have died, than see me mar∣ried to the Duke of Lemos.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: Now you see that you had better have done as I; lived in dissipation, and loved no one but yourself,

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: No, I had rather suffer every moment of my life, than be of such a temper. But let us go and enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: TELL Silvano, how is this affair of the young General's coming to life again?

SP.SPEAKER: Silv.
SP.P:
The fact is—He engaged Abdallah king of the Moors, and was by him struck down by a blow on the head, and was left on the field—But after the battle, when
the friends came to view the slain, it was tho't he discover∣ed signs of life. A surgeon opened a vein; he bled freely, and in a few moments recovered his senses. And they are bringing him back in triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: How came the Spaniards to gain the victory, after the young General was dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Silv.
SP.P: His father, knowing his son was struck down, and supposing him dead, enraged to the utmost degree, encoun∣tered Abdallah, king of the Moors, killed him; and took Alonzo, his second in command, prisoner This is all I can tell you, madam, I must inform the rest of the court.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—CLARA, ISABELLA, LOUISA, MARIA, and MARTINEZ.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: WHAT Louisa said is the truth. They are bringing him back in triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: Then I must be hurried back to misery again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: No; the heads of the nation assembled, immedi∣ately after the victory, and the recovery of Alonzo; first agreed to a thanksgiving. Then finding that the prince of Asturias and Duke of Lemos had been both killed in the battle; and that Alonzo is heir to the government, it is proposed that he be married to the princess Maria the evening after the feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Well madam I hope you will be contented with life now. I see you are gratified in every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lou.
SP.P: I should wish that I had some affection besides the love of myself, if I could be so fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: To receive my honors by the loss of the great he∣roes of Spain is no great consolation to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: But it is as much your duty to be happy for the nation's sake, as to be miserable—Come, my dear girl, it is now your duty to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I shall yield to the call of duty. Yet truly I am disappointed to be a queen on earth: I had much rather be a saint in Heaven.

LG.L: The blaze of grandeur lasts but for an hour
And danger treads upon the heels of power.
The greatest power involves he greatest care;
The highest fall the deepest in despair.
Yet since 'tis duty's call I bear the sway,
Content to live in sorrow for a day.
The greatest good shall be my greatest aim.
I'll build on justice all my hopes of fame.
Then if grim death my wordly bliss annoy,
I'll gain that heaven I must not yet enjoy.

DIV1.HEAD: Panthea. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN A SUIT OF SCENES.
THE EXCELLENCE OF MODESTY AND OF VIR∣TUOUS LOVE.
DIV1.P: The antients wrote that there were two loves. One the son of Jupiter, by the Goddess of Beauty. This was the cause of modest amours, of love which ter∣minated happily. He was perfectly harmless; his darts were headed with gold, and dipt in balm and honey. The other, the son of Erebus, by the Queen of Night. His darts were headed with lead, and dipt in gall and poison. The moral of these al∣legories is very useful to young persons of both sexes.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.
DIV1.P: SCENE—The camp of Cyrus on the borders of Babylonia—im∣mediately after the first battle with the Babylonians.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I WILL immediately give orders to the Priests to instute to Eternal Oomasds, the source of light, of being and happiness, a solemn Thanksgiving for the victory of this day. (To Mithras who is entering.) Long live my brave counsellor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Most excellent Cyrus, live forever. This victory will give splendor to the Persian Commonwealth, and im∣mortalize your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I regret this destructive war. But the Babylon∣ians will be content with nothing but making mankind the slave of their luxury and avarice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: The sword of Cyrus will bring them to reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Do not flatter me, Mithras—Rather freely tell me of my faults, and point out those vices of which I am in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: It would be a hard task to find out your faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I do not wish to think myself sure of success. Many causes may ruin a young man of twenty three at the head of a great army. I tremble when my friends call me great. What is your opinion, Mithras, of a great man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: It is not surely he, who eats and drinks and sleeps more than others—or who lives in idleness on other men's labors.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: No, such men are rather objects of contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Nor he, who is learned without usefulness, rich without profit, liberal without judgment, courageous without caution, or witty without prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: No, reason must govern. The manner and use of every thing must be considered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: On these principles might not one describe a great man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: He must be a great man who is ever doing the best things in the best manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: There is one point more to be considered.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I cannot conceive of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Not conceive of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: No, you must tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Must he not do all from a sense of duty, from a free choice, and disposition to do good?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: My good old friend, you are perfectly right. The will to do good makes a man resemble the great God— There is an advantage in age, it brings experience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: You will grow old too soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: My worthy friend you shall not go yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Some private affairs call me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Private affairs must submit to the public—You shall not go, till you have told me, how I may escape the odium which commonly falls on princes and rulers of states—You may tell me briefly, but tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: The first point it to avoid indolence and luxury —Chuse to labor for others rather than that they should labor for you. And excell all others in those things in which they most excell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I never could bear to be outdone in any thing. I can live without sleep. I watched three whole days and nights with my grandfather, when he was sick in Media. I can endure the want of food—I have hunted often from break of day till evening and ate nothing but a piece of dry bread, and a bunch of cresses pulled out of a brook.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: These are true signs of future greatness. But chastity in love affairs is very necessary—If you would be happy you must ave but one wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Why so? Most of our eastern princes have from a hundred to a thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Yes and that is their ruin—nature makes for one man only one woman. The sexes are almost precisely equal in numbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: But might not one man engross more to his own advantage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: A poor man can maintain but one; and it is still more necessary that a rich man should have but one.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: If he have more it will be the interest of each to plunder her husband the most.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Princes regard themselves more than their families.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: It is not good for themselves. Love is most hap∣py, when directed to a single object—as a river flowing compact is noble, and dispenses a thousand blessings; di∣vided, it sinks in mean rivulets, and dirty puddles—divid∣ed love has ruined most of the princes of the east.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I thank you, kind Mithras, attend now your private affairs—but I shall often send for you, and you must not be sparing of your advice. [Exit Mithras.]

SP.SPEAKER: Arasp.
SP.P: NOBLE Cyrus, live forever—I can tell you some∣thing which will please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Speak then Araspas if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Arasp.
SP.P: I have taken a most beautiful woman. I found her among the slain, on the field of battle, sitting on the ground, in obstinate silence, and her eyes streaming with tears. I with another officer raised her by the arms, and bore her to my tent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Alas! how war tears asunder the dearest bands, and breaks those ties which are twisted with the fibres of the heart. It is some woman, probably, who lost her hus∣band in the battle. The story does not please me, but gives me pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Arasp.
SP.P: It was her beauty which I expected would please you. Her complexion is fine; her features soft and reg∣ular—Her eyes are lively blue—Her brown hair waves over her neck, which is white as snow. She has a delicate shape and easy manners; and the finest expression in her countenance—Her motions are like those of a goddess, and the graces attend all her steps.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Do you think she is handsomer than my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Aras.
SP.P: She is very handsome, and I expected would be an agreeable present to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I thank you, I wish but for one woman. But are you not afraid to have her near you, if she be so beautiful?

SP.SPEAKER: Aras.
SP.P: Not I—You see I am growing old.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Keep her then; you are the most proper person— I do not wish to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Aras.
SP.P: Your temperance, illustrious prince, is astonish∣ing—May your success be equal to your virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Have you, Sacas, seen the lady taken by Araspas, in this days's battle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: I have; every body went to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyrus.
SP.P: Is she handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Yes indeed—That she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyrus.
SP.P: Is she as handsome as your mistress? I mean Mandanè my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Why—ay—as to that—if she is not, she is the next handsomest woman in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Did you talk with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Yes, she speaks very good Persian—She is the wife of Abradatas, Prince of Shushan, a brave officer: her name is Panthea. She wishes to send to their army to en∣quire for her husband. She says she is afraid, living only with the men—enemies too—and that Araspas does not always behave becoming.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I will call Araspas to an account, and protect her; but do not bring her here; I do not wish to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: What shall I do then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Pitch a tent for her behind the armoury. Let two of our best maids wait on her. Then enquire for her hus∣band—if he be killed, is a prisoner, or with the Babyloni∣ans.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: I shall gladly do it, for I want to see her again.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—MITHRAS, CYRUS, SACAS, and KADMIEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Illustrious general—I have brought you a curious old man, a captive, who complains of your soldiers—His name, he tells me, is Kadmiel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr
SP.P: Kadmiel, I wish you health and happiness. (Kad∣miel keeps his distance.) Kadmiel, fear not to approach me— The nmed soldier is my brother. (Gives Kadmiel his hand.) You were taken in this days battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Have my soldiers used you ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: They have neither killed nor wounded me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Did they offer you any indecency?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad
SP.P: They refused me water to wash; they said it was scarce in the camp. They offered me vinegar—But that's not the law.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Did they injure you otherwise?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: I told them I was hungry—They bro't me the legs of fowls dished with parsly sauce—My blood ran cold at the sight!

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: And were you hungry too—strange!

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: That was not the worst—They offered me half of a roast pig, dished with gravy and sweet herbs. What an abomination!

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Excuse me Cyrus, this is certainly a mad man.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Peace, Sacas, peace. I'll ask your advice when I want it—Mithras, what shall I do with this man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Let me examine him a little. Kadmiel, what injury was there in offering you the legs of a fowl dished in butter; or a piece of a roasted pig?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: I have kept the law from my youth. I have nev∣er eaten of the sinew that shrank, of swine's flesh or creep∣ing things, the abomination, or the mouse, or drank the breath of abomination.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: (Laughing) If this be not a crazy fellow there never was one.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Peace, Sacas, peace, or you shall feel my displea∣sure. (Directing his speech to Kadmiel.) Of what nation are you Kadmiel?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: I am a Hebrew.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: The same whom we call Jews?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: Yes, the Lord's people.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: As they say. Have they not a most singular law, which forbids the eating of swine's flesh, commands you to wash often, and so on.

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: That is all true.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Addressing himself to Kadmiel. Be comforted my old friend. Your religion makes you singular. I love a man who is firm to his principles of religion—You are no longer a captive—You are my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: May I be sure of your protection?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P:
You shall have water to wash—You shall go to the
ordinary and prepare your food in your own way.

DIV3.STAGE: (Mithras, Kadmiel and Sacas go out—Mandane enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: WHAT my dear wife brought you here so sud∣denly?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Have you seen the beautiful captive?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I have not, nor do I mean to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: But you can do as you please in that matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I trust I shall always do as I ought with regard to my wife—My vows are sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: It was reported that you had received her with great attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Be assured I will receive no woman but yourself— The wife of my choice is the sole object of my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Thanks to my excellent husband—The great are apt to neglect such obligations. But why I know not, un∣less there is more dignity in vice, than in virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: Permit the most unfortunate of men to lay him∣self at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Relate your misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: I fled to the army to save my wife, the most beau∣tiful of women, from the impious views of Belshazzar the Babylonish King—In the late battle she followed me, thro affection, to the field. Since which time I cannot find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: What would you do here?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: I will unite my forces with yours. My estate shall be my pledge. At the end of war if I be faithful, they shall be mine. If I be unfaithful they shall be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Well then if I receive you as an ally, I must pro∣vide for your comfort—There is a widow who lives behind the Armory, who lost her husband in the battle. Your mutual sorrows may console each other. For, regard my words, they are true, there you will find the beautiful Pan∣thea.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: (In rapturous surprize.) Panthea! O heavens, Pan∣thea! I fly to my sweetest life, O Panthea! (flies out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: That fellow left your noble presence with very little ceremony

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: I can forgive him, I have a young and handsome wife as well as he.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: THERE is a centinel at the door, with a prisoner. Shall I bring him in?

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Gad.
SP.P: The fame of your clemency, illustrious Cyrus, has reached our ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: May fame never say any thing of me but what is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Gad.
SP.P: I come not illustrious Cyrus to aggravate the pic∣ture of my injuries—I am governor of the fertile province of Gaditana—The impious Belshazzar has stolen from me, my most delightful wife, within a year of our marriage— He took her by force of arms, and armed men. I followed the ravishers to Babylon, and petitioned the king to restore her. But he ordered his servants to take, and abuse me, in the most infamous manner, and then dismiss me—I live, Cyrus, for revenge, for justice. And my sword is impa∣tient to employ itself against the king of Babylon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: What kind of man must this Belshazzar be?

SP.SPEAKER: Gad.
SP.P: The most voluptuous of men. Wine and women employ him forever, the women have him as the gates of hell—He is drunk every evening, and his guards are drunk quite to the city gates.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Stay, you shall serve me—This Belshazzar is raising recruits for me last out of his own dominions.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: ILLUSTRIOUS Cyrus—The enemy are in mo∣tion —It is now a good time to bring off the Suin Char∣ioteers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: You shall take the command of the chariots your∣self—I retire to give other orders. [Cyrus goes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: My noble husband—What, i armor already?

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: I am impatient to perform some noble sice for our deliverer.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: But you may fall in battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: True, yet that is no argument against my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Certainly you are right. Go, and be virtuous— regard not the tears of Panthea.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: If anything could make me value life above glory; it must be the possession of so amiable a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I shall not detain you from the field of fame—Go, and if you die, I will die with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.P: I go without reluctance—Let the incense of your prayers ascend to the Gods and I am sure of victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: WHAT did Cyrus intend by sending for Araspas?

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: To punish him I suppose, for being rude to my mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: How queer that is, that my master should think of punishing him for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: Why not punish him for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Because if a woman defends herself, no harm is done—if she does otherwise, two cheats make an even bar∣gain.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: Do you mean to abide by that principle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: Yes, that I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: Very well, abide by it—But I hear that Araspas has sent for your pretty sister, as you call her, to come and live with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: A dog—I'll horsewhip him, he's a vicious old rogue as ever lived.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: What makes you angry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sac.
SP.P: A sister is one's own flesh and blood. If she gets disgraced, the infamy comes to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz.
SP.P: Suppose he should attempt any thing against her interests?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: I'll stab him.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz
SP.P: Suppose he should utterly ruin the happiness of her life?

SP.SPEAKER: Sacas.
SP.P: I'd kill him—I could not bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arz
SP.P: O, I thought that two cheats made an even bar∣gain. Upon your own sentiments you ought to be horse∣whipt, stabbed and killed. Well, I suppose it is no more than you deserve. [Exit Arzina.]

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Go, Sacas—Araspas is in waiting—tell him to come to me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sac.
SP.P: I obey your orders, sire. (Araspas is brought in.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Well, Araspas, how does your philosophy bear it; you was not afraid to be with Panthea, tho she was so beautiful?

SP.SPEAKER: Aras.
SP.P: O Cyrus, illustrious general, I have been faulty— but did you know my case you would pity me. I plainly perceive that I have two souls—one good, one bad. When the good soul prevails, then I treat this woman well; when the bad soul prevails hen I use her very ill. Did you know my case you would pity me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Other men, I believe have as many souls as you. But you must follow t dictates of the better soul. All honest people do; and because the bad soul is apt to be most mischievous when people have least to do, I order you to go on duty every day for six months together.

SP.SPEAKER: Aras.
SP.P: I should suppose that six months hard employ, would make any knd of soul peaceable. (sorrowfully.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Go then and make the experience. [He goes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: I find my old friend Kadmiel a curious man. He pretends he has a book which old of you, one hundred and seventy years before you was born.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Where did you find that, Kadmiel?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: In the writings of Isaiah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mith
SP.P: Isaiah, who is Isaiah?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: The greatest of our prophets next to Moses, a man of fortune and family—But the best of him was that he was a good man, and a prophet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: How could he know any thing of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
