SP.P: Aye that's the point—But he writes thus. (Shows an old manuscript.) "Thus saith the Lord to Cyrus, to his anointed, to Cyrus—Whose right hand I have holden to subdue nations before him, and I will give him the hidden treasures."

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Mght not this be said of another Cyrus?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P:
What other has there been. Besides, do not you
worship towards the sun, consider light as the divin presence and darkness as the influence of the devil?

SP.SPEAKER: Mith.
SP.P: Yes, these are parts of the Persian religion.

SP.SPEAKER: Kad
SP.P: To these our prophet ades—That they may respect me more than the rising of the sun; because there is none beside me—"I form the light and create darkness— I make peace and create evil. I the Lord do all these things."

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: What says your prophet of me in particular?

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: In the name of the Lord he says. Cyrus is my shepherd, he shall perform all my pleasure; saying to Jerusalem—Thou shalt be built, and to the temple, Thy foundation shall be laid. Jerusalem was our Capital, destroyed by the Babylonians, the temple, our chief place of worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Well, Kadmiel, this is a fair trial of prophesy, to see if it will come to pass. If I take Babylon, and get the hidden treasures, then I will build your temple again, and restore your city and nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Kad.
SP.P: The Lord of the Hebrews bless and prosper you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XII.—GADATAS (enters with looks of deep sorrow) and CYRUS.

SP.SPEAKER: Gad.
SP.P: NEVER did my eyes before see so wretched a sight —The fair Panthea followed her husband, at a small dis∣tance to the field of battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P: Surprizing how love will overcome fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Gad.
SP.P: Her husband by a preconcerted sign brought off the Ssian charioteers. The Babylonians irritated at this, poured all their archers upon him—an arrow pierced his breast—Panthea, seeing him wounded, flew thro the ranks and supported him in her arms—till in anoth∣er shower of arrows, one pierced her side—Both then fell together, and the streams of their blood were mingled in their fll—The Babylonians by our swordmen were soon dispersed, and when we came to look for our friends among the slain, we found Abradatas and Panthea, the husband dead, and the wife just expiring, fast locked in each others arms, and their bosoms filled with their mingled blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyr.
SP.P:
These then are my orders. Let Abradatas and Pan∣thea be buried on the very spot where they died—Let a monument of the most durable marble be erected on the spot, bearing this inscription, THE MARRIED LOVERS.
There to the latest posterity, the respect which Cyrus, and the Persian Commonwealth, have for virtuous , and the sacred compact of marriage —and of their detestation of those unmanly vices which have not only ruined families, but nations. And for which the vengeance of heaven, now remains, scarcely suspended, over the devoted city of Babylon.

DIV1.HEAD: The Foundling. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
THE CONTEMPT AND MISERY WHICH FOL∣LOWS A LIFE OF PLEASURE.
DIV1.P: From the scenes of gross voluptuousness nothing is to be expected but misery, infamy, and baseness—And the man of pleasure, often less scrupulous than any honest man should be, sows the seeds of the bitter∣est remorse, when he imagines himself gathering the fairest flowers of delight.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: FIELDFARE—a rich man, a man of pleasure.

The Character of Puffpaste cannot be too much burlesqued every point, except of honest good-nature, which is the only plea¦sing quality the character is intended to represent. PUFFPASTE—a singular man a baker.
SAM. MOORE—reputed son of Dr. Moore.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—MELVIL and FIELDFARE.
DIV3.STAGE: The stage presents the two gentlemen sitting, and a row of boys before them.

SP.SPEAKER: Melvil.
SP.P: I DO not know how you relish our domestic scene—I love to live with my children.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: It is a pleasing sight to see a number of spruce young fellows sitting together, and the is one of these boys whom I fancy very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: People have often smiled when they have seen you give him apples, and gingerbread.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Is he no your son?

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: No, nor my wife's son.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: You have a very pretty company, and I have tho't more of late than I used to do of the amusement of an agreeable family.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I have often wondered that a man of your genius should not wish to marry. You Bachelors form wild ideas of domestic life.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: I always tho't it a state of confinement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: It gives just as much sense of confinement as the soul has in being confined to the body—or as a man has in having an estate of his own, or living in a house, or on a farm, of his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: What is the drift of all that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P:
Should you esteem yourself free, because you had nothing to eat at home, but must buy a meal at an extrav∣agant
price, at a tavern? If you had no house, but must hire a wretched lodging in a garret—If you had no money but what you borrowed or stole, kept no table, but dined where you could, or went without a dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: No, but a wretched dependent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Yes, such is exactly the freedom which a man en∣joys who refuses marriage, except that it is neither so in∣nocent, nor so reputable.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Then you think the acquisition of valuable prop∣erty makes no man the less free.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Much less does the acquisition of valuable friends. All that liberty is worth is that we may gain such possessions, and serve them; but the evil of want of principle, is great. It hurts many persons who ought to be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: If women would take care of themselves, no per∣son would hurt them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: Simplicity will not justify roguery—Suppose a merchant should take of a child dollars instead of shil∣lings.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: You'll beat me perhaps in the argument, I never was much of a reasoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I never knew a man of pleasure that was.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Let that be as it may—I seem to like that boy. But that he is not your son puzzles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: He is not my son, nor my wife's son. He was brought up by Dr. Moore, and is an apprentice to Mr. Puffpaste the baker—I can enquire concerning him.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: DOCTOR, your servant, I hope you are well.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I thank you and am surprized to see you alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Why not alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Because I know nothing more likely to shorten a man's days, than such a life as you lead.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Doctors can give advice and physic but take neither of them, themselves—But can you tell me who that boy is who is apprentice to Mr. Puffpaste the baker?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I do not know, his birth is a secret to every body but Mrs. Moore.

SP.SPEAKER: Field
SP.P: Do you not conjecture whose child he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P:
All that I know of him is that Mrs. Moore,
after an evening visit brought home a beautiful child in a basket; we bro't him up and bound him out apprentice to a baker.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Whose child does he pass for in your family?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: For mine, and were I conscious that he were my son, I have not a child who would give me more pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Then he is a likely lad.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Very likely?

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Does he not, thinking himself your son, complain that you bound him apprentice to a baker?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: He said he tho't it was odd—But he quieted his mind in thinking that he was our own child.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: He must be a good tempered boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: He is! The more is the pity, that he can∣not have a suitable education—and certainly, I think his father, whoever he be, must feel as much remorse on that account, as for any injury done to another person.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Ah, there is no doubt of that!—But do you ask Mrs. Moore, perhaps she may tell—I will enquire of Mr. Puffpaste; and find out the truth if possible. [All go out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: DICK where's Sam Moore?

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: He is gone to get his new skates.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: He will be so proud now, there will be no touch∣ing him with a boat hook.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Sam is quite ambitious. But he is a good-nat∣ured fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Somehow I feel saucy to day, I suspect I shall affront him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: What makes you saucy. Have you been drink∣ing hard?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: I don't love rum. But the girls like Sam Moore better than they do me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: How do you know that they like him better than you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Because I walked home with Miss Mincer, be∣cause it was dark and slippery, and you would have been af∣fronted had you been in my place.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Why affronted?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Mel.
SP.P: Because when I was walking, she would say—shame don't be rough—Sam Moore would not behave so. Nothing is right, but what is done like Sam Moore.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: You must not blame girls for being quite nice— You know if they are not pretty exact we are very apt to laugh at them when we are alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: I do not know that Sam Moore is better than every body else neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Nor are you quite right, you appear to be a little envious.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: He will be here in a minute, and you will see enough of his self importance. [Enter Sam Moore.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—YOUNG MELVILL, DICK and SAM MOORE.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: WILL you go a skating with us to day?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore
SP.P: Yes, I long to try my new skates—if they per∣form as well as they look I shall go like the wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: You always can beat every body—we shall be nothing to you. I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: I never said I could beat every body, but if my skates were well fixed, I believe I should try to beat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: I suppose you think you could do as well with me, as with Miss Mincer.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: I do not know what you mean by doing well with Miss Mincer. I always meant to treat her decently.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Is that the way to make the girls like one. I tho't the way was to be very bold and smart.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: It is according as how bold, and how smart you are—girls of no delicacy are as mean as the dirt in the streets.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: It is a hard task I believe to please them.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: If you think so, you will not please them—most certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Tell me then how it is done.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P:
Why if there be any thing kind or good to be done for them, do it quick and make no excuses—never do
or say what they dislike, or speak bad of them—and they will soon find out one that likes them.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Then you think I don't treat them well I sup∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: I said no such thing, your jealousy must have told you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: My jealousy! that's well for you, a poor basket bird.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Who's a basket bird?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel
SP.P: You sir, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: [Seizing him by the shoulders] You villain! I'll tear your heart out.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: You shan't punish him for saying truth.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: What do you mean, gentlemen? I was as well born as any of you—and whoever maintains the con∣trary I'll fight him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: Who was your father, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Dr. Moore, and I am prouder of his blood, than I should be of the blood of the twelve Caesars.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: There you are mistaken, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: And who do you think your mother was?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Mrs. Moore—whom, because she appears so grand, all the people call Madam Moore. I am prouder to be born of her than to be born of an empress.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: There you are mistaken again.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Who were my parents then?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mel.
SP.P: No body knows—you was made a present of to Madam Moore in a basket; that's fact and disprove it if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Let me alone and I'll whip him well—I'll teach you to talk of baskets in presence of gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: He has told no more than the truth, you shall not punish him.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: You insult me beyond all patience, I will throw off some of my clothes and then I will whip you both well. [In stripping to fight, Dr. Moore enters.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Dr. MOORE and S. MOORE.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: SILENCE!—Boys what is this rout here? what stripping to fight, for shame Sam! I could not have ho't this of you.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: Why sir, any man would fight to be insulted so. He says I am not my own father's son; and that my mother never bore me—He lies, I know he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I should have been more disposed to have laughed at him than to have beat him for that.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: He said it in malice, sir, and it is more than flesh and blood can bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: He said it in malice! I will enquire into that▪ Do you stay, the other young gentlemen will withdraw.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—DR. MOORE and SAM. MOORE.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: NOW tell me Samuel, tell me, what has been the cause of this quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: They began to talk about skating and about Miss Mincer—They took offence at what I said—called me basket bird—and said that you was not my father, and that Mrs. Moore was not my mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Well you must not beat them for that.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: It is not true I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore▪
SP.P: Not far from truth. But you must not be kept ignorant—You are not my son, nor is my wife your mother—And I know not whose child you are.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Moore.
SP.P: O my grief—you not my father, Mrs Moore not my mother—O my heart will burst! (Laying both his hands on his bosom.) I shall die, I shall die.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—FIELDFARE, DR. MOORE and MELVILL.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: (Looking concerned.) That boy went out in extreme anguish—I always fancy he resembles me. I always love to see and observe him—I feel very much for him now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: He may be very near to you. But I know nothing of the matter

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Go after him Doctor, and take care of him; I will pay you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P:
You heart, my friend Fieldfare, is not half hard enough a ake—You ought to be insensible to the groans fathers, the sighs of tender mothers, the tears and ago∣s of distresse sufferings and cries of desert∣ed
infancy, the undeserved infamy of deserted children— nay his heart, that he may not feel remorse, should be hard∣er than the Baltic steel.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Good heavens! what a description! Such a man must be unfit to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: A proper rake is I suppose always unfit to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: This lad is dangerously ill—His symptoms are very bad—The fits are violent, and the spasms cenre about the pericardium—I wish you would look out for a good nurse for him

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: I suspect this lad is my son—would to heaven I could find out his mother; she must be the properest nurse for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mel.
SP.P: I cannot tell you. I would not for ten thousand pounds undertake to track you in all your ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: That is true, but I have extreme anxiety for this boy—Should he die, I find I must suffer extremely—would to heaven I knew who his mother was.

DIV3.STAGE: (He goes out and the others follow him.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mr. and Mrs. PUFFPASTE, (entering together.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Puff.
SP.P: CAN you tell, my woman, any thing about this boy. I find there is likely to be a noise about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Puff
SP.P: Ye, I could if I tho't it safe and proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Puff.
SP.P: You would not conceal any thing now from old spark▪ that's as true as a die—I won't tell tales; burn my whiskers if I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Puff.
SP.P: I will tell you if you will undertake to plague Fieldfare a little—I'd make him feel with a witness—He has used the mother of this boy very ill—And men who use women so ill ought to suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Puff.
SP.P: That's right, I like to see a woman good sponk to stand up for her sex, burn my whiskers if I think there is a man in a thousand who blames them for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Puff.
SP.P:
Well I know who she is well enough, you
remember that woman in a Bengal gown who was here yesterday to buy biscuit—you observed how melancholy she looked. That was the very woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Puff.
SP.P: Shave me up, if I ever tho't of that; I've got my clue now. I'll plague him well. (Exit Mrs. Puffpaste.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mad. Moore.
SP.P: MR. PUFFPASTE, has Mr. Fieldfare been enquiring of you about Sam's mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Moore.
SP.P: Well, tell him not a word—we will contrive the matter so as to do her justice yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Madam I do not mean to tell any tales out of council—but I mean to give him a hearty sweat—Trust old Spunky for that.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Moore.
SP.P: Swea him well with all my heart. If it were in my power I would sweat such fellows one half of an eternity at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Leave that to me—I'll plague him well; people say I'm a queer fellow; but I like the women right well. There's my wife now, fat, easy, and contented—As plump a Joan as there is in town.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Moore.
SP.P: She does credit to your good nature Mr. Puffpaste.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Aye that she does, and I'll keep her yet as fat as buttered bunns, trust me for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: WHAT excessive pain it gave me to see this boy sick—I wonder if I should feel the same degree of joy on his recovery? It is possible—this boy then, if it be in the lie of possibilities, shall be raised up again—till I suspected this boy to be my son, I did not know what feelings my heart was capable of—Mr. Puffpaste—I am on the rack of anxiety till I can discover the truth concerning this boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Why there it is now—I'll wager you fifteen to a quarter—that a married man can learn more in one year, than a rake can in ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Why? you take me up drily—and what can he learn?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P:
Why that it is better to do right than to do wrong, by a large slice—and to be married to a good wife is bet∣ter
than to be single—that a wise man is btter than a fool —and to be a father is better than to be nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Don't any man know such things, who has com∣mon sense?

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Then you have not common sense, you are ignor∣ant of every notch in the paste; you don't know a mince pie from a sea biscuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Do not I know tis easier to do right than to do wrong?

Naw—that ye dânt—you've been this whole day looking after your boy, and you don't know you've found him now, sttin. Naw you come to me to ask for your wife—I'll be buttered if I ever come after you to ask for my wife. Let a man only use his wife well, and he can find her the darkest ght that ever was.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Finish, since you've begun. Any man knows that it is better to do right than to do wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Na ye don't know it neither. You dined once at a nasty tavern, you said, and was drea-a-dful sick after it. Keep a table of your own, and then you may dine nice—and you'll find it better by a large slice.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: A fiddles end of your observations. I want to find out Sam's mother, and set her to nurse him.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: There 'tis again—What a carnal fool you are; ask me what you should know yourself. I know Sam's mother, I believe I do; but I will not tell you unless I please. Think'd I come to you to ask for my wife? If your wife was where she should be, you could find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: I have no wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: Burn me if I don't think you lie now, honored sir. Suppose you and I take a biscuit—You hold one side and I t'other, and we break it right in the middle—Don't we hold equal halves? Burn my whiskers if I don't think your son's mother is your proper wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: A truce with your nonsense then, and tell me where to find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: I should have a great mind to tell you if I thought proper—No I wont—It will get abroad that I told tal— It will be for her benefit—Now I'm a good mind to tell you—But I may make mistakes—Now I wont tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Come old friend, tell me without any roundabouts, where she is—I'm all impatience to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P:
All impatience. Then I won't tell you—I long to
punish you—cruel to your wife—I saw her the other day— so thin!—so pale!—eyes so red!—cries so much!—Now my wife you see—folks say I hav'nt half the wit that you have—fags, I would't swap heads with you for a pistareen to boot. See my wife, how fat she is in the face, and as fresh as a four penny cake. A wise man knows more than a fool. A wife man keeps his wife, and a fool forsakes her, d'ye see!

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: You are the most impertinent rascal that breathes —There! (shakes his cane over his head) tell me, or I'll cudg you well, you old shepherd. [Puffpaste springs across the stage, and stands at the entrance]

SP.SPEAKER: Puff.
SP.P: There sir, I can outrun you; or if you do knock my brains out, I'll never tell you where your wife is, smoke me if I do—I won't be forced to do as I please, so good night, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Now I'm as far from my purpose as ever. I have abused the women, and lost respect among the men—Old squaretoes, to treat me so—How low I must be sunk! How the wretch tormented me! What I feel for this boy! I love him—I should have loved his mother. Could I have lost my liberty by living with those whom I loved—Could I find her she must be more ugly than sin, or I would have her—My son live with old Puffpaste! Sam is made for better things. I'll find her out yet and do her justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Your son, sir, is in a fair way of recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: He is? I thank you sir—Never did the speech of man give me such sincere raptures. I thank you for this happy news.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: His sickness has brought out the whole se∣cret. The mother, hearing he was on the point of death, came half distracted to my house—

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Let me see her, let me see her; for heaven's sake, let me see her!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: She will not be seen, unless you first engage to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: What, marry and never see her? She may be the most disagreeable hag in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I am sorry if you have had such connections. But he lady positively will not be seen, unless you will first engage to marry her, and take her into immediate main∣tenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Field
SP.P: Why so secret about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: She says she has tried your word and she cannot trust you upon that; then if every body knows what is hitherto a secret, her character is utterly ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: How does she mean to hold me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: You must sign a bond to forfeit ten thou∣sand dollars, if after you have seen her you do not have her. She will also secrete her son that you shall never have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: I cannot blame her. Yet to what a wretched di∣lemma I am reduced. She may be some low dirty slut.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Or an abominable scold; and one might as well marry a thunder cloud.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: A notorious liar.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Likely enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: A thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: So much the better, she will steal enough to maintain you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: She may be bad as—the furies!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: I am very—very miserable, and can blame no one but myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: I ask you but this once whether you will sign—if not I put up my papers, and you neither see the woman nor the boy forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Field.
SP.P: Alas! what shall I do? I may ruin myself at one stroke— But better outward misery than inward remorse. Thus we, in our riper years, atone in deep remorse and anx∣iety for the follies of youth. Thus I sign perhaps my own death warrant. (Signs the paper—rises in agony, and dashes his pen on the floor in a rage) There, tell me now, have I cut my own throat or not. If I have, let me lie down and die on the spot. [Throws himself backward into a chair.]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Moore.
SP.P: Rise sir, and know your destiny—no sir you are pledged to a very worthy woman—the moment a

DIV1.HEAD: The Female Gamesters. A DRAMA IN THREE ACTS.
DANGER AND CURE OF VICIOUS HABITS.
DIV1.P: EVERY vicious habit subjects the mind to a real sla∣very. The most sacred relations of life, with the duties annexed to them, are contravened by a vicious propension which has once mastered the reasoning faculty—This in no instance is more evident than in that of women, otherwise delicate and well bred —addicting themselves to GAMING—Few vicious habits are cured but by some very powerful cause, such as extreme sickness, or fear of present death— we should not therefore complain of life on account of frequent dangers and fears. They are medi∣cines of providence to cure us of our vices.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. OMBRE—a merchant, and a very indulgent husband.
ALLWORTHY—a very methodical, but very genteel man.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MRS. OMBRE—a female gamester, conductress of a party.
MEACHUM—a wife in slavish fear of her husband.
SMART—a high spirited wife, counterpart to her husband.
ARTFULL—a wife who values herself on her canning.

DIV1.P: SCENE.—A merchant's house in the city of Bristol in En∣gland.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Smart.
SP.P: WELL, I hope you have no objection to my going to Miss Bridget's this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smart.
SP.P: Certainly I have; and must tell you that you positively must not go.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Smart.
SP.P: Very pretty indeed! so as soon as we be married we must be laid under positive commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smart.
SP.P: Posiive, or not, I mean to be master in my own house, and you go at your peril.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Smart.
SP.P: Lordly indeed, Mr. tyrant—But why may not one see a little company?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smart.
SP.P: Company is not your only object, it is well known that Miss Bridget keeps a gaming table for ladies. You might as well be unfaithful to my love as addicted to gaming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Smart.
SP.P: I guess you will find that I shall go where I please nevertheless.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smart.
SP.P: You shall go where I please, so prepare yourself to go in a chaise with me to Gloucester.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mrs. SMART and Mrs. ARTFUL.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: I protest I won't bear this—To be led by the nose by a husband—I scorn it.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Can you not flatter him into good humor?

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: There never was such an obstinate despot as my husband. There is no bearing with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Poh! The least said is soonest mended: you cannot disgrace your husband without discracing your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: I wanted to go and see cousin Bridget, but my saucebox says that he has engaged me, and I must go with him to Gloucester.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: And why not? The journey is pleasant, with an agreeable friend too—I always delight to ride abroad with my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: But they are to have a card party at Miss Bridget's this evening—And my tyrant refuses, and I am determined I won't bear it. (Exit Smart.)

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: (alone) THIS woman is out in her politics, an ob∣stinate husband is never reclaimed by raving.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: 'Happy to meet you, my good friend, I wish to know of you, how you manage your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Why do you need such counsel—I tho't you and your sweetheart lived in the promised land of matrimony flowing with honey, and all sweets imaginable.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: We never quarrel, but it is all owing to me. If he frowns upon me I tremble—I am afraid of him as of a lion—He is very sovereign I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: I believe you are a piece of a fool for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: How would you prevent it?

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Prevent it! a woman may have her due influence with her husband if she acts right.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: That is just what I wish to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: For a general rule, never seek any thing but to make your husband happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: What shall I gain by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: When you wish to carry a particular point, you will have great influence.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: And is that alone sufficient?

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: When he is in good humor never put him out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: But I crossed him a good deal when I was first married to let him know I would not obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: There you was not cunning. You put him on his defence, and he was obliged to carry his point, or be your slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach
SP.P: Now I wish to go to Bridget's, but he says pos∣itively he will not live with a gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Does that affright you?

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: I am but a child to take care of myself: were he to leave me, I should be the wretchedest woman in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: So he has found out that—But what arts have you ever used with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: I was determined once to scold him well; but he always left me to enjoy my own music.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: What did you do then?

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: They told me that a husband of feeling could not resist my tears—I cried for every thing I wanted, and it answered very well for a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: But did not last I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: I sometimes feigned it, and so when I cried for trifles he would not regard me.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Then you did wrong; you should never cry but in matters of consequence, as for example, for a new gown, or to go out against your husband's will. There is great art in crying properly.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: You do nothing but blame me—But they say your husband indulges his wife more than any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: What if he do?

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: I wish to go to Bridget's but my husband will not consent; and without that I might as well die as go.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Tell him he is the best husband in the world, and that you will be the goodest, and the kindest, and the sweetest, wife to him that ever was, if he will let you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: Will such silly coaxing have any effect?

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: Try it and see: and remember never to scold at your husband at all; and never cry, but when there is rea∣son for it—and not often when there is. [Exit Artful, and Smart re-enters, but Meachum does not see her, because her face is turned the other way.]

SP.SPEAKER: Meachum
SP.P: (with herself.) WELL if coaxing will do I'll coax him to perfection—I have some talents for that—

SP.SPEAKER: Smart
SP.P: (interrupting her.) Coax him. I would choke him first; I suppose you mean your husband. What brutes these creatures are!

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: And do you coax him? I'd let him know I would do as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: And how can you do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: I never enquire how I can do it; but do it with∣out enquiring of my sauce box—To day he was as high as my lord because I talked of going to the card-party.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: And how did you get away?

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: I told him I would go to the card-party and would not stir to Gloucester—And I went out of the room, topping high—went up stairs—He looked very angry and rose to follow me—I went up stairs very fast—he went up a few steps and stopt, then went up again, then stopt; I watched him; at last he came up slowly, I slipt down anoth∣er pair of stairs, stept into the carriage and drove away.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: And what will be the consequence?

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: I care not, he may go to Gloucester on foot or hire a carriage if he pleases. [Enters Allworthy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: Ladies, you seem all to be engaged on some ad∣venture, pray, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: Yes, Mrs. Allworthy you will go with us to the card-party.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: No▪ indeed I shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: Why not, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: I will not dissemble my sentiments, I do not think it proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: Not think it proper?

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: No, I do not for a woman to leave the company of her husband, and the care of her children; to go to some public house, and pass the evening at cards—where, if suc∣cessful she stays late—if unfortunate she comes home peev∣ish—and the worst company imaginable to her family.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: You are an old fashioned creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: Good fashions ought to last forever, and I think it a very good fashion in a lady to refuse gaming.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: Well that is clever now. You are just like your old grandmother. I remember how she used to put her spectacles on, and sing it out, Cards and dice, are the Devil's device. If you'd enjoy your day, abstain from play. So you think too.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: You have given a ridiculous turn to the sentiment. But let me express it and see if it can be despised. It is dangerous for a woman to be a gamester. She will lose her character, her husband's affections, and the respect of her children, and then she cannot be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: You are the most old fashioned creature that ev∣er was, so, I say no more to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Allworthy alone.
SP.P: If these woman be not rushing on their own perdition I have no reason—It is full bad enough for men to game at public houses, and keep late hours—If wo∣men do the same they appear divested of the proper delica∣cy of the sex. [Exit Allworthy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. All.
SP.P: I WAS sorry this moment to meet my friend Smart very angry at his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. All.
SP.P: His wife may have given him just provocation. But I observe that in cases of this kind, you always favor the women.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. All.
SP.P: The cause may be that I have ever been ac∣quainted with women who are virtuous and reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. All.
SP.P: Your extreme complaisance almost makes me suspect you of flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. All.
SP.P: Think, my lovely friend, that when man trusts his honor, his interest, the keeping of his heart and happiness to a woman, this is something more than flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. All.
SP.P: It certainly is, and the surest mark of confi∣dence. I esteem it a great honor to be entrusted with such a precious charge. But supposing I should wish to go to the card party?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. All.
SP.P: You may if you think proper—I leave you to your own reason and discretion. [Exit with a low bow.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. All.
SP.P: One thing I am certain of. No woman can be happier than I, with respect to her husband.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mis EIGHTEEN and Mrs. ALLWORTHY.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: You say your life has been more agreeable since you married than before—Yet I am determined never to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: You may alter your resolution.
No, never, you may depend upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Bravely resolved. But such resolutions have often failed.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Mine shall not—shall not—unless I could have such a husband as yours, I admire him.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Why that is frank indeed, to confess a particular re∣gard for my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: I did not say that neither, but it might be the case if it were not a crime.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Worse and worse—But what qualities have you dis∣covered in my husband, to attract your notice?

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Because he is always so generously complaisant. My mamma says, that you behave together not like old mar∣ried folks, but like a couple just going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: True, I know no difference but on the best side.— Mr. Allworthy has ever been more kind and more attentive to me since we were married than before. The truth is, he always was a proper gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: It is said that he always lets you do just as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: He does—I never knew him, in any case, to give me a direct refusal.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Would he let you go to the card party?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: He never forbad it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Now I wish to know how a woman can make a complete gentleman so attached to her.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: That is needless, as you never intend to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Why, perhaps I might, could I be as happy as you, and have such a husband as one chuses.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Certainly I would chuse only such as I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: But how could you make him like you so? that is the thing I want to know.

SP.SPEAKER: All
SP.P: It was not my beauty, certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: No, it is not extreme, but well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Nor my gaiety, or frequenting public places.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: No, for people say you go about much more since you married than before.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Yes; you see then it was none of these matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Well, you torment me, I want to know what it was.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: To be serious then, all I know of it is this, that I first considered whether Mr. Allworthy were a reasonable man. I found that he was—Then I made it my constant aim, to perform whatever was agreeable to him, and avoid whatever was disagreeable to him, both before ma age and since.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: But they say a rose is no rose without its thorns— and that all sweet, and no sour spoils the appetite.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Human life has thorns enough without making any artificial ones—And is it not a fact, that both men and wo∣men are most attached where they feel most happy? They are most easy in their minds where they are best treated, and enjoy the pleasure of self esteem. I consider vice and folly as out of the question.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: But it is not delicate to take such pains to please a man.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: It is as delicate as to torment him. A dove is at least as delicate a creature as a snake—Besides, who needs to know your views, you simple sense?—You may find out what a man likes or dislikes, by himself or his neighbors— say nothing of your designs, but avoid the offence, and per∣form what is agreeable. In that consists the whole secret —and tho you do it by design, a man who loves you, will always think you do it from the native goodness of your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: If that be the way I shall let him pass, I am determined they shall love me for my beauty and my fine accomplishments: and if ever I be married I will do as I please, that is positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: That is no more than I do, who never was positive about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: But I won't have it in that way; and to be sure I will not be restrained in gaming—I intend to begin before I am married, so that my husband shall have no face to find fault with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: Husband! Husband! I thought you never meant to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P:
O I forgot myself; I do not intend to be married
—but I can have a husband if I please, I would have you to know; so I will dress myself for the card-party this min∣ute. [Exit Eighteen.—Mrs. Smart enters again.]

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: SO I am going you see, and my husband, poor tod, may go to Gloucester on foot like a saucy wretch; think to restrain me!

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: What if he should take a coach and go with some other woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: He is too honest for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: That is a very curious reason for using him ill. But honesty may sometimes meet with his match. Noth∣ing is more likely than ill treatment, to make him seek the graces of another.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: You are a wretch for starting such a thought. Heav'ns how it pains me here! (Laying her fan on her bosom.) I will haste to the card-table and forget it as fast as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Allw.
SP.P: You will have enough to do to forget it even there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Om.
SP.P: HERE my good girl, see how I leave mat∣ters. There is money with the housekeeper to buy provis∣sions for the family, and to purchase you a suit for your wedding day; I give this to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Om.
SP.P: I know it, and there is money left here by Mr. Oldfield for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Om.
SP.P: I do not need it, I have enough to answer the demands of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Om.
SP.P: I hope you will not forbid me to go to the card-party.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Om.
SP.P: Forbid you, no, tho I do not love cards—and should be very well contented if you did not. It is a very insipid game to me—but you will be robbed if it be known that you go—you have money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Om.
SP.P: That is only to terrify me from going to the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Om.
SP.P: But I will escort you for fear of harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Om.
SP.P: You may save yourself the trouble: the men are very fond of showing how necessary they are to the women—I shall be as well without you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mrs. OMBRE and Miss PINCH'E.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: WHERE is the money which my husband left to buy provisions?

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: It is here; but why does not Mr. Ombre buy provisions himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: because he trades remote from the market in the further part of the city—so he leaves the money with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: I would help myself out of the money very freely —I should love a careless husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: O I shall not forget that, you may depend on it. But how much may we venture to take?

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: Well if I help you to this money you must keep me safe from harm, for there is no way but to pinch it out of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: It grieves me for the poor children, but then it must be done. It is genteel you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: Well here are thirty guineas which we may save —your husband left sixty to buy flour, but brown bread will do for the children, and it will not cost more than half so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: Well, and to make it pass, we will eat the same—so if Mr. Ombre should enquire, we can tell him that the chil∣dren eat as good as we.

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: No madam I am not going to eat brown bread neither—while I do the work, I will live upon the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: Then set brown bread on always for the children, and for me, when my husband is absent. But there is no other way that a saving can be made?

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: We might mix the strong beer with water half and half, and by that means raise a considerable um.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P:
There is the money which my husband left me to purchase a suit of clothes to celebrate my wedding day— I will borrow a suit of your clothes and wear it that day, my husband will never mind it—so do you give me what
you have saved at present, it may pay this day's debt—but there is another thing which I have thought of.

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Om
SP.P: There is the sum which Mr. Oldfield left for my husband. I will take that to save the chance of being out of cash by a bad run. I shall win in my turn enough to make it up. Go, for the present, to the business of the fam∣ily, and see what further savings may be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: alone. Now many persons would have made these savings to increase their own private estate. But I to pay my debts of honor, mine is the noblest motive. Indeed it went against my conscience a little to shorten the allow∣ance of my poor children. But what is to be done—one had better be out of the world than be singular in good company. [Enters Eighteen, and after her Mrs. Allworthy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Eigh.
SP.P: WELL I am determined to go—I won't have my husband say after marriage that I cheated him. I'll bring him up to cards.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: The husband you are resolved never to have.

SP.SPEAKER: Eigh.
SP.P: I will not be insulted any more with that Mrs. Allworthy—I can have a husband if I please, but I won't (makes a long pause) unless I please.

SP.SPEAKER: All. to Om.
SP.P: Your husband is very kind, he loves not cards; but he never troubles you about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: He is very kind and he loves not cards, but who that has learnt the fashion, ever pretends to care for that— I shall go, (Exit Ombre.)

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: NOW my dear girl you are not yet hardened in vice. I advise you not to go to the card party this evening. It is a dangerous practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Eigh.
SP.P: I determine to go, and there is nothing that you can say which will hinder me. But I am waiting for Miss Idle, as soon as she comes I shall go. But you may say any thing in the mean time.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P:
You are uncommonly generous for a woman who loves cards, and for that reason I tell you, that if you pur∣sue
this practice of gaming you may give up every prospect of a happy settlement in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Eigh.
SP.P: I care not for that: I wonder what makes Miss Idle stay. I will not wait for her any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: alone. What a strange infatuary vice! The most af∣fectionate pairs are separated, and alienated from each other. Girls give up the prospects, which are dearest to the youthful heart—mothers can deprive their families of their food, and be hard hearted against their own children —nay can even give up their beloved dress, all for that wretched insipid game of cards.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—PINCH'EM running in to ALLWORTHY who re∣mains.

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: O mercy!—what shall I do? mistress is murder∣ed I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: What makes you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: As I came from the Grocer's shop which is at the head of Bembow street, I saw three very ugly fellows in close conversation at the corner of a coal house. I got as near to them unseen as possible, and overheard them say that they knew of a card party at Miss Bridget's, and that, the ladies would have money; and they meant to way-lay, rob and murder them. Poor mistress, I am frighted out of my wits, she is gone for it, I believe.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.—All the ladies rush in with noise and con∣fusion▪ except Mrs. OMBRE.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: THERE was the dreadfulest noise of quarrelling in Bembow street; and they cried out murder, murder! Somebody is killed, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: All
SP.P: I am astonished, as every one must know they had money, that they should go thro Bembow street, as they must know it is famous for robbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart
SP.P: It was the shortest way to Miss Bridgets, and we were in a hurry to get there.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: The love of gaming is even dearer than life.

DIV3.STAGE: (Mrs Ombre enters—They lay hold on her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: Are you alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Ombre.
SP.P:
Yes, I am alive, but had it not been for my kind and generous husband, I certainly had been murdered— He knew that I must go thro that street, and tho I per∣versely
refused his protection—he▪ expecting the robbers would assault me, placed himself in a proper situation to defend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: 'Twas a great chance that you was attacked near where he was placed.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: It was: first two ugly fellows laid hold on me with great knives in their hands; and a third was coming up with a cutlass. My husband felled one with his cane and run another thro with a sword, he grappled with a third, and left him helpless, he received five wounds himself but none dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: So Mrs. Meachum, you was there.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: By Mrs. Artful's direction, I got leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: 'Twas I put her in the way of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: But I wish I had not gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Art.
SP.P: But if no harm is done we may take another course and go yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Meach.
SP.P: No, mischief enough has been done already. I saw your husband, Mrs. Smart, in a hackney coach, with a noted woman going to Gloucester.

SP.SPEAKER: Smart.
SP.P: O heav'ns, my husband—I shall die— (She flies off the stage in a passion.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SP.P: And the mischief does not end here—The gen∣tleman who was courting Miss Eighteen, coming to her house, and learning that she was gone to the card-party▪ went and took up her rival, and is gone with her to Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: Eight.
SP.P: Confusion seize them—Oh I'm distracted, oh!—

DIV3.STAGE: (Appearing to go off the stage in agony.)

SP.SPEAKER: Omb.
SP.P: Let us never take a step that way again. I must have perrished had it not been for my generous husband— and shall I employ my time to the utter ruin of his affairs? I had almost ruined his family before—his generous kind∣ness saved me. I will abuse it no more.

LG.L: Thus dangers are the cure of human crimes,
And present death awakens fear, betimes.
Then blame not Providence for human woe,
It is the medicine of our lives below. [All go out.]

DIV1.HEAD: Scanderbeg,The Epirots called this remarkable person, Alex∣ander. Among the Turks he was called Scander-Beg—that is, "Alexander the Prince"—But his true name was George Castriot, and the title he gave himself in his letters, was, "The Soldier of Jesus Christ"—For about 30 years he was the champion of the Christian States against the Turks. Temperate, dextrous, indefatigable and active, he ever met with success. He was mild in his temper, almost to a fault—and three times pardoned his cousin Amesa, a voluptuous youth, the crime of high treason. He died with glory—and the Turks wore pieces of his bones, set in jewels and rings, as am∣ulets against danger. His height of glory was about 1440. OR THE PRINCE OF EPIRUS. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE—IN VERSE. IN THREE ACTS.
DIV1.P: VOLUPTUOUSNESS DANGEROUS TO YOUTH.

LIST.ITEM: ACHMET— Visier of the Turkish army.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: ZEPHORA—Eliza's nurse, both having been captives to the Turks.
PAULINA—a grave lady, captive, and servant to the Visier.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: HAIL sacred Pastor, may this happy day
Refresh thy soul, and banish grief away.

SP.SPEAKER: Hel.
SP.L: Ah no! illustrious prince, high Heaven decreed,
That half my flock, my precious sheep, should bleed.
Heaven was the object of their warm desire,
I bade their zeal to heavenly joys aspire.
Yet half this much loved people now are slain.
Their bones are whitening still on yonder plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Yet Heaven with victory our arms has crowned;
Myriads of Turks have marked their length of ground.
There proudest Bashaws, Beys, and Visiers lie;
Whose haughty souls dared Christian arms defy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hel.
SP.L: Whole armies slain, vast armies still arise.
The Turkish empire endless swarms supplies.
Their boundless wealth can ceaseless wars defray;
Their endless troops renew the fatal day.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: The great Eternal Power, who rules the skies,
By his own strength the wrath of man defies;
He gives the victory and vengeance due;
And saves alike by many or by few.
Then I, to save the state, still lift the sword.
No Christian soul shall own a Turkish Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Hel.
SP.L: Heaven bless your hopes, and give your arms suc∣cess;
May Heaven's high justice give our wrongs redress;
May you adorn the bright triumphal car;
Yet still I weep, and dread destructive war.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Thine, worthy pastor, are the arts of peace:
The virtues by thy labors shall increase▪
My heart impels me to the martial field;
There the proud Turks shall to my Christians yield.
Thine be the milder work, to preach and pray;
But mine the glory of the well fought day.
Go, and for us, thy pious vows be given;
No work succeeds but by the will of heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Com'st thou thus idle, midst dire war's alarms?
Where, cousin, is thy brilliant suit of arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: Had I but hope, I still might seek the fight,
And thousands see my deeds, and do me right.
Can our whole host, a handful at the best,
O'er-power these mighty conquerers of the East?

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Yet have I seen, when others blood ran cold,
Thee, keen for fight, and as a lion bold,
Seen thee performing deeds, in foremost line,
On which the sun might even be proud to shine.
But love resistless lays thy glories low,
The best or vilest passions, mortals know;
The fair Circassian slave in yonder fields,
Melts thy fond heart, and all thy courage yields.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: True; I have seen the fairest female form,
That ever did a hero's bosom warm.
To none of all her sex her beauty yields;
And true, the fair resides in yonder fields.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Yes she is there, and there you wish to go,
Make peace with Turks, and lay our glories low.
Wouldst sell thy nation, and wouldst wed thy shame,
And bury every spark of honest fame.
Wouldst bed in bagnios with a Turkish slave,
A better bed for thee, would be thy grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: But have not all the bravest poets sung,
Of love? to tender lays their harps have strung.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Yes—sung of Samson's locks, and Helen's shame,
And every son that ever bore a name.
The fruit of lawless love, the boundless crimes,
Of earlier periods, or of later times.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: Tell this to our rich dames, who point the dart,
Full proud to fix it in a hero's heart.
object loves,
To virtue like a burning seaph moves.
All is alive to bless the lovely prize,
And catch the virtues kindling from her eyes.
And such the fair Circassian slave may be:
None bless the sun but who have eyes to see.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: No—no—a base born slave for sordid gold,
Bought for some brutal Turk, decayed, and old,
The lothing partner of his sordid bed;
To ignorance and to imposture bred.
I'll hear no more, prepare to tread the plain;
On heaps of dastard Turks, despoiled and slain.
Spring to thine arms, fly swifter than the wind,
This sword is for the knave who stays behind.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—HALY, a Turkish spy, enters. HALY and AMESA.

SP.SPEAKER: Haly.
SP.L: WHERE is this wretch who longs to sell his soul:
Already listed in the infernal roll
Of traitors? Here's the poison, precious bane!
That must destroy what virtues yet remain
Lingring in his galled heart. But hush, 'tis he,
He's coming—Now let prosper villainy.
SP.STAGE: (Steps aside till Amesa enters, then addresses himself to Amesa.)
SP.L: —Illustrious Hero of the far fam'd line!
Whose deeds in song, and sculptured marble shine;
Descended from the famed A chillean Boy,
yrrhus, who laid in dust the towers of Troy.
Why shouldst thou serve a petty tyrant Lord?
Can his bald realm a recompence afford?
My master has the prize that's worth thy toil,
Long treasured riches of imperial spoil.
Beside, the loved Circassian slave is thine,
Whose beauties far the light of heaven outshine.
All these, if you desert the Christian bands;
Shall be delivered safe into your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: The gold is nothing—What is dust to me?
Jewels and vests, mere sordid trumpery.
The fair Circassian maid alone I prize,
Joy of my soul, and comfort of my eyes.
When late in our proud court a captive she
Appeared, a princess fair she seemed to be.
Not one of all our great imperial line
Could young Amesa's captive girl outshine.
The prince, O cruel Lord, forbad my love.
To conquer fate, alas! in vain I strove.
Then, by exchange, my captive maid returned,
To her rough Lord—My heart her absence mourned.

SP.SPEAKER: Haly.
SP.L: Now then young prince the captive maid is thine,
To morrow thou in Turkish gold shall shine.
If thou a chosen band this hour wilt lead;
To bring impaled, the Christian hero's head.
Thou well the hour of safe attack may'st know,
Wronged in thy love, thou well may'st be his foe.

DIV3.STAGE: [Takes the bribe—Haly goes out, and Amesa makes his reflections with himself.]

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: O fatal! fatal power of lawless love!
Nought could his gold, nought could his presents move.
The fair Circassian maid alone I prize;
Joy of my heart, and comfort of my eyes.
For her alas! I to his offers yield.
And now, a blasted villain, take the field.
Sunk, and disgraced, my nation I betray;
Blast all my glories on this fatal day.
Sell all that's dear—O yet can I return!
And in my soul this torment cease to burn—
Ah no, the flame accurst torments me still.
And scarce the villain quivering on the wheel
Of varied torture, feels such pangs as mine—
Sure fruit of crimes, the meed of ill design—
O had I ne'er been born, or those fair eyes
On this dull earth were never seen to rise.
Heaven, earth, I lose, and vanquish glory's charms;
To sink entranced in fair Fatema's arms.
Yet such my pain, if all the world could see
The vilest wretch on earth—they'd pity me.

DIV3.STAGE: [Haly enters again—Visier Achmet enters—with Mustapha as Amesa is retiring.]

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: THIS then the place must be, from whence we scan
The Christian camp, and learn their mutual plan.

SP.SPEAKER: Haly.
SP.L: Amesa told the whole, and you may see,
Well with his words the facts espied agree.
Below yon cliff (points as if observing a camp, looks thro a prospect glass) which threats the arching sky,
Proud of their state, the bold Venetians lie.
Their numbers few, with silver mounted arms,
Each man a hero, fired with glory's charms—
The fierce Hungarians on the left are placed;
Large leathern belts encircling every waist,
Whence hang these heavy swords with which they strike,
And deal out death, to horse, or man, alike,
Next these on either part Epirots lie,
Men who in fight our fiercest troops defy.
All cloathed in iron, In the midst they place
Militia of Epirus' hardy race.
Behind the whole the troops reserved recline,
Two aged generals rule that valiant line.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Speak out, then, warriors, shall we, as they lie,
Attack them, and the force of battle try?

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.L: Illustrious chief, from battle I dissent,
Shame waits the man who is on battle bent:
Never saw I, an army ranged so well,
Both to attack a force, or to repel.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Base woman hearted Bashaw, canst thou fear
A boy scarce reached his twenty second year,
A youth, not half a man, whose face can show
Scarce beard enough to fit him for a beau.
Shall I then tremble at his name, and fly?
Rather would I, with my whole army, die.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.L: A coward, visier! say not that again,
Or thou no more shall fill the list of men,
A coward I, who from my youth hate bled,
In battles more than thou hast seen, or read.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Why then deny the christian force to fight,
Or think'st a boy can put us all to flight?
What will the Ottomans at Pera say▪
That Visier Achmet shunned the glorious day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.L: Say what they will. fight wh thousands cost;
What will they say when our whole army's lost?
Consider chief, the man whom we oppose,
Not written in the list of common foes.
Descended from a grand heroic race,
Whose deathless deeds song, history, marble, grace.
In all the purest christian morals bred,
No fumes of wine becloud his princely head.
No lawless loves his manly nerves unbrace,
No wanton feats his youthful day disgrace.
Aspasia, mistress of unrivaled charms,
Fires him to virtue, and the deeds of arms.
Heiress of all Epirus, if he gain
The victory, on this tremendous plain.
The chiefs decree to that heroic boy,
T state its lovely heir and every joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Why speak of that? Let them decree again,
I'll not recede an inch from yonder plain.
Mustapha go, and rouse the troops to arms,
Bid martial glory spread her awful charms.
Say not a word of fear, but say aloud,
That all may hear as thunder from a cloud.
"This is the day the christian cross shall fall,
"The Turkish crescent rise and conquer all."

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: What says my secretary? not in fear,
I hope, as Heaven shall hold my safety dear.
Shall I retreat from that soft christian boy,
And not both him and all his slaves destroy?

SP.SPEAKER: Eff.
SP.L: Ah if thou canst I wish he were destroyed,
But the young prince hath all his skill employed,
To range his army in the ttest plight,
Either to wait th' attack, or meet the fight.
If you attack, they in defence remain,
And force of fire, or thunder might sustain.
Huge cloud capt rocks on either wing arise,
Who hide their summits in the darkened skies.
A deep morass extends along their rear,
And half their flank, and shuts out every fear▪
If we attack, they're safe from every blow,
And hurl unpunished death on troops below.
Or if they should the fierce attack approve
The moment when your troops begin to move
In bogs and fens both horse and foot must fall,
Slow they must march, if they can march at all,
Then to this spot if Scanderbeg should come,
Entire defeat and slaughter is your doom.
Your troops incumbered in that marshy ground,
May yield him victory without a wound.
There whatsoe'er our court of us shall say,
'Tis by not fighting that we win the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: O wors than women, let us leave the field,
Allow that Turks to Christian arms must yield.
He camps with skill—he will that skill retain,
And he as skilfully can camp again.
Is there no woman here, whom we might try?
She would not fear with Christian arms to vie.
SP.STAGE: (Calls Paulina to mortify his officers: Paulina enters.)
SP.L: Say dame, what would you do to check the course
Of Christian bands, and give our arms swift course?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.L: When all their men are gathered in a band,
Send out your fleetest horse thro all the land.
Collect the women, whom each husband leaves,
With all their babes, and sell them all for slaves.
They once dispersed thro all the Turkish lands,
With them Epirus, and her glory ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: A glorious scheme! Effendi is your man,
Or Mustapha, to execute the plan;
To lead the party, who with dire alarms,
Attacks the babes and wars with woman's charms.
Like wasps disturbed they'll fight with tenfold rage,
And every clown will in the war engage.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.L: No other way can ever be subdued
A nation, which is every year renewed.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: What other way can they their race renew;
Than Turks and other nations all pursue?
Like leaves on trees are all the race of men;
Their generations rise and fall again.
Our Father slept in dust and we survive;
When we shall sleep another group all live.
When we shall gain the victory, we trust,
Whoe'er is slain will kindly sleep in dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.L: 'Tis not mere life, but morals form the soul.
The mind will all inferior powers control.
Your women in the haram's walls confined;
Know neither faith nor sanctity of mind—
You keep them slaves, they view you as their foes.
They neither sk your bliss, nor your repose.
if they break their bonds, rage unconfined;
Nor dream of sweet constraint within the mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: And do not other women do the same?
What that vague sex, but bolts and bars, can tame.

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.L: Nay, from their infancy, each cheerful day,
The Christian boys and girls together play.
Nay even in age mature, the girls are seen
In gayest pastime dancing with the men.
They live and love at large, nor ever find,
Restraint, but which arises in their mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Impossible—confusion must ensue,
They soon must be a base and filthy crew.
Some sordid end bids you these tales conceive:
And deem'st thou that such tales I can believe?

SP.SPEAKER: Pau.
SP.L: Could I mistake, who half my life have been
With Christians, have their manners tried, and seen?
To you, who but as slaves your women deem,
Freedom with purity appears a dream.
Yet with the Christians every pleasing day;
The youth with maidens innocently play.
Some chuse their mates and delicately love,
Like the bright Houris—the Virgins of paradise—whose delightful conversa∣tion, the virtuous, according to the Koran, enjoy after death. Houris in the world above.
Such love as by your Koran is expressed;
Among the saints superlatively blessed.
And when they would unite in marriage bands,
The simple vow the parties heart command,
Their sprightly brides retain their freedom still,
See company, when, how and where they will—
The wife and husband mutual cares employ,
Their children are their parents dearest joy;
These bred to virtue flee all vicious sense,
And form the nation's surest, best defence.
And should their army fall a sacrifice,
Another army instantly would rise,
Unless their women be removed away,
In vain their chiefs we fight, their soldiers slay.

SP.SPEAKER: Vis.
SP.L: Mere fables these and fond chimera all!
This day decides, the Christians states shall fall.
My chiefs are cowards, but my soldiers feel
A courage, keener than the tempered steel.
Fly hence, Essendi, instant fly amain,
And hear my orders to the distant plain.
Let then the trumpet sound—To arms, To arms!
Let martial glory spread her dreadful charms.
"This day decrees the Christian states to fall;
"The Turkish Crescent rise, and conquer all."

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—MORATH and HAEMON.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: SAD is the difference of youth and age.
When I was busy on life's busy stage,
My place was ever foremost in the van;
Nor deigned to tremble a the face of man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hae.
SP.L: Our prince indeed is wise; he orders right
Old men in council young men in the fight—
'Twas well for the attack to give command,
Men have more courage moving than to stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Yet still I . The younger prince is fled,
His stratagems and active force I dread.

SP.SPEAKER: Hae.
SP.L: The prince indeed is fled, but fled alone.
Not even a centinel his cause would own.
Caught in the toils of vice, he vainly strove
With pains extreme, to conquer traitorous love.
Lost to himself, his nation, and his friends,
In this vile act his race of glory ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Experience ever proves the dreadful truth,
That lawless leve's the certain bane of youth—
While still the heart is pure from wanton stains
The love of virtue and of good remains▪
But who to brutal pleasures sinks his soul,
Corrupts its active powers, destroys it whole.
But who comes here— (Looking out, sees Amsa coming guard∣ed.) —Sure, sure he's taken, see,
O what distressful spectacle to me!
Amesa guarded, and unarmed he stands,
And tears his golden hair with both his hands.

DIV3.STAGE: [Amesa enters unarmed—his hair loose, his eyes dejected, &c.]

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: O worthy seniors, let me, let me die!
What else but death can bury infamy?
A traitor to my nation I have been—
I've reached, tho young, the utmost bounds of sin.
Pronounce my sentence, seniors, let me die—
What else but death can bury infamy?
I've not a prayer to make, a tear to shed;
O let me but be numbered with the dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Unhappy youth! thy sad example proves
The dreadful dangers of unlawful loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: I've trod those paths where mercy finds no place.
I've sinned beyond the reach of human grace.
The sun ne'er shone upon a guiltier head—
Than this which longs to sleep among the dead.
Yet lost to virtue and to sense of shame—
I cannot wrong an honest woman's name.
The fair Circassian still her fame retains;
And pure from me, and all my crimes, remains,
Detests my treason, and abhors my love—
And her contempt, the last of griefs, I prove.
Then let me die—Perhaps that grace divine,
May pardon sins for sorrows such as mine.
Pronounce my sentence, fix the fatal spot,
Let me as martial rule directs—be shot.
May your keen soldiers take a careful aim—
And end at once my sorrows, and my shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Hae.
SP.L: At once, sad youth, we could the law declare,
The law by right must finish your despair.
But we the fate of battle now expect,
And what the prince our general shall direct.
No witnesses we need, confession ends
The proof, and answers all the law intends.
The prince himself pronounces angry fae,
May he be prosperous as he's good and great.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.— (A single centinel enters with a woman pris∣oner) —ZEPHORA and MORATH.

SP.SPEAKER: Zeph.
SP.L: O where the valiant prince? Heaven be his guide,
The will of Heaven must o'er his ways preside.
Eternal counsels aim his deeds to bless;
Whatever he attempts will meet success.
What pleasures must his godlike bosom feel,
When I the wondrous secrets shall reveal.
She's wrongly deemed the fair Cicassian maid,
Twas I who watched her in her infant bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Then tell year wonder—your assertion prove,
The noble general will reward your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Zeph.
SP.L: If yet the glorious chief I cannot find,
I'll keep the secret locked within my mind.
Unless the good Helenor know my face,
And place good faith, in my full ripened days.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Are priests the only men that women trust?
Can you not think a valiant soldier just!

SP.SPEAKER: Zeph.
SP.L: Aye—yes, but then the priest most suits my mind,
Or else the chief most brave and not less kind.
To him a mystery I shall disclose,
Which shall our joys complete, and end our woes.
But till the prince or sacred priest I find,
I keep the secret locked within my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Go, cntinel, conduct her to the priest,
And be the secret from her soul released.
If from its public fame such blessings flow,
To fill our joys, and banish all our woe.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—SCANDERB (entering with martal music.) MORATH and HAEMON.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: The battle's done, the glorious day is ours,
Thank, reverend seniors, to th' eternal powers.
O wrongs are all redressed by heaven's decree,
This day the christian lands again are free.
Yet what a field of blood, what waste of men,
May I ne'er look on such a scene again.
Bashaws in heaps there end their martial toil,
And slaughtered Visiers swell the dreadful pile.
Just was our cause, and well our lbor ends;
Just is the war, which truth and right defends

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.L: Ilustrious chief, to heaven our nation owes,
Victory and safety from our mortal foes,
This glorious day, shall every heart rejoice,
All ranks and ages shall unite their voice,
To praise in raptured strains th eternal name,
And waft thy glory on the wings of fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Hae.
SP.L: Now may these eyes contented close in death,
In peace with all the world I yield my breath,
Since heaven from war, shall give our state repose,
And put this glorious end to all our woes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—AMSA reentering guarded, SCANDEREG an HELENOR.

SP.SPEAKER: Sc.
SP.L: [Turning to Amesa.] BUT who is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Am
SP.L: [Answers without looking up] A villain!
That is true?
O cousin thou art lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Am
SP.L: Death is my due,
O let me as a traitor yield my breath,
The only prize of such a crime is death.
Let death atone at once for all my crimes,
Sad warning to the youth of later times.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan.
SP.L: Thou hast deserved thy fate, and it must be,
Yet what a blast on my success and me.
Victorious on▪ the field of fame I stood,
Yet here must bathe me in my kinsman's blood,
Amesa dear to me as vital breath,
Must I pronounce thy sentence, give thee death?
Is this the period of this glorious day?
That very period takes its joys away.
Illustrious pastor, see thy friend returns,
Rejoicing, and in midst of joy he mourns.
On yonder plain, where the proud Othmans stood▪
There has the Turkish Crescent set in blood.
Peace o'er the land, shall her sweet branch extend,
And Christian virtues swift from heaven descend,
But this unhappy youth is lost to ame,
And sinks, a traytor, to eternal shame

SP.SPEAKER: Hel
SP.L: No. Crowns of joy must shine on every head,
Let not a drop of Christian blood be shed.
Thus the good spirit teaches me within,
Th' extreme of justice is a part of sin.
Th' Almighty will the chief of sins forgive,
The chief of traytors by his goodness live.
Forgive the youth, with cheerful grace, nor lay
One stain of grief on this important day.

SP.SPEAKER: Scan
SP.L: Would I forgive for heaven's sake, and thee?
Yes, blameless priest, thy thoughts with mine agree.
Take then, dear nephew, take my hand and heart,
Again from virtue never may'st thou part,
This crime hath cost thy cousin tears of blood.
The grace of Heaven can change and make thee good.

SP.SPEAKER: Am.
SP.L: My crime is infamous, I wish to die.
The cheerful light is painful to my eye.
Fain would I hide in dust from human view,
And take for all my crimes the vengeance due;
Yet since my death so dear a friend might grieve,
With sad reluctance I consent to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Hel.
SP.L: Live youth, and let thy better sense be shown,
Let future virtues for thy crimes atone.
And thou, illustrious chief, prepare to hear,
What scenes of glory in our land appear.
This day, by truth▪ I saw the opening skies,
And heaven's bright visions rushed upon my eyes,
Saw thee, young chief, benignant, good, and great,
With mildest order bless our happy state.
Peace smiled o'er all the realms, and plenty flowed▪
And every soul was smit with LOVE OF GOD.
A course of triumphs o'er the Turkish bands,
Defends thine own, and all the Christian lands,
For safe by thee, the Christian states remain,
Nor shall the world itself thy fame contain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: Cease holy pastor, nor thy rank disgrace,
By grossest flattery to thy prince's face.

SP.SPEAKER: Hel.
SP.L: 'Tis true as heaven shall help me, Prince 'tis true,
Then rose thy fair domestic scenes to view,
I saw thee blest in love. Thy princess fair,
To make her virtue and thy joys her care,
I saw thy cousin, temperate, good and great,
Bend all his mind to bless his native state,
I saw him meet the fair Circassian bride;
By strongest ties of blood to thee allied,
She, deemed Circassian, on her infant day,
Was from thy native frontier borne away.
Nursed with the Turks, is now a captive here,
Know, prince, she is thy German sister dear,
Whom as a stranger late thou didst despise,
In thy own palace meets her brother's eyes.
This silver cup has shown this very day,
Which was with her when captive horne away,
From this same cup, in sign of heavenly grace,
I poured baptismal waters on her face,
And see this mark shall justify my fame,
ELIZA CASTRIOT, see! her Christian Name.
Great source of bliss! what blessings dost shower,
What boundless grace upon this happy hour.
This day to virtue, I have gained my friend,
His glories now commence, his crimes shall end.
This day full victory o'er the Turkish bands,
Gives smiling peace to all the Christian lands.
This day from heaven, refreshing vision clears,
The brilliant prospect of our future years.
This day my long lost sister I regain,
What lively joy succeeds to anxious pain.
Let now, my friends, loud gratulations rise,
To fill the world, and rend the vaulted skies.
Tumultuous joys I change for softer charms,
And spring exulting to my sister's arms.

DIV1.HEAD: The Maid of the Groyes. A DRAMA, IN FIVE ACTS.
A RESPECTABLE CHARACTER IS MORE VALU∣ABLE THAN RICHES.
DIV1.P: RICHES only make a person contemptible without virtue and good breeding—the man of virtue is in∣finitely better calculated to make his friends happy than the man of wealth—and if a person shall only be firm in the ways of virtue, there is scarcely an instance in a hundred, in which the event will not be prosperous—the arm of providence sustains the heart that is honest—virtue can acquire friends, and wealth; but mere wealth can neither procure virtue, nor friends.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: CAPT. BLOOMSGROVE—an officer of the army of the United States.
MR. MANLY—a subaltern, of the army, engaged in farming.
O' CONNOR—servant in pay of Manly.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MRS. IRONSIDE—wife to Mr. Ironside, aunt to Julie.
MAYFLOWER—a coquette—rival of Juliet in preten∣sions to beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: WHY Miss Bloomsgrove are you so uncom∣monly pesive?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I shuld appear very awkward, were I to tell you my dreams.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Your dreams must be elegant as well as your wa∣king ideas—tell me one dislike it, never tell me another.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: My imagination last night represented in the most lively manner my father returning and approving of my whole conduct in his absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: That vision is my property —it decides a very im∣portant question—if you are to be mine—This heart c never know tranquility till completely blessed in your love, or frozen by the blast of despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I can decide on no one's suit till my father returns: you must have patience or quit your pretensions.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Do you remember your father's looks?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Very faintly—when he went into the army I was but four years old—they say I look very much like my mother—I cannot remember her.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: You are extremely like her, and a fine woman she was.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I was so pleased with the imaginary sight of my father—that when the pleasing vision was fled, I could not refrain from tears—How happy must childen be, who dai∣ly see their parents and enjoy their protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: How did your father appear in your sleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P:
A man of middle size, a plump round face, black eyes,
his eyebrows rather thick—his look sedate and steady— and I imagined he showed me a scar on his right arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: That was the very look of your father; and he was wounded in the right arm in the battle of Princeton.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: But it were foolish to place any dependance on dreams.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Dreams are liars—yet they may tell the truth and tell me, Juliet, who always tell the truth—whether I be disagreeable to you—If I be I will not trouble you any more with my presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: O sir I esteem you virtuous, well bred, and a valua∣ble acquaintance—and on this account, especially because you always let me be mistress of myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: He must be detestable who could think of injuring so amiable a person.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Then you must withdraw—for if my aunt should see us together, I should have no peace for one fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Nothing is so delightful to me as to converse with you, my dear Bloomsgrove, but if my presence be in the least troublesome, I absent myself in a moment.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mrs. IRONSIDE and JULIET.
DIV3.STAGE: (Mrs. Ironside takes up Juliet's work, and looks at it)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: LET me look of your work, Jule, see here, you have sewed this on wrong.
