Pray what have you been thinking about? about Manly I suppose; han't you been crying and whimpering about him—hold up here—an't your eyes red?—why no, tolerably bright, brighter than common I think—he can't have been here surely.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Why should you think of his being here? you never heard me speak a word in his favor in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: And think the more—you are not spiteful to him, I know, for he is always tagging after you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Why ma'am I never feel spiteful to any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron
SP.P: Why can't you find some one to your liking? I only forbid you Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I cannot determine soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron,
SP.P: I knew it; you have a notion for a man of fine taste and tiptop breeding—why can't they suit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Some are so rough with me that they break my fingers, and pull my dress all to pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: They are not all so rough I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Some are so officious that they will not let me take care of myself—I am always n picket guard with them— they are the most unsufferable coxcombs in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Some girls like fellows that can talk and rat∣tle away like any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Yes the monied blades to be sure—I like the silent ones best — I love to have them sit still and say nothing; then I'm quite happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: You are peculiar in your notion.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul
SP.P: I love propriety, if we cannot act rationally we had better not act at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: What do you think of Mr. Butterford?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: He is very large, and fat, and rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Then you will not like him any better than the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I never said a word against him. I have admitted his visits, and certainly would o betray him—He shall still be admitted if you desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: That's my good girl now, you will like him I dare say when you are used to him. He's grandly rich, and rides the finest horse of any man in town—He's got a coat branfire new on purpose to court you in, he's coming to day: do you prim up and look smart: he'll cut a grand flash I'll warrant you, come, go to your glass and rig up immediately. (Juliet goes out and Ironside after her.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mrs. and Mr. IRONSIDE
DIV3.STAGE: Front curtain draws and shows Mr. Ironside at a table with a part of a loaf of bread and a cheese—Mr. Ironside is eating —Mrs. Ironside comes up to the table.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: I REALLY think, husband, you have eat enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Why wife I hope you do not grudge your hus∣band his victuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: You have been eating this great while and grain, husband, is very dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: If you could pin enough u of me to prevent a general samine it might be worth your pains.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: I know you have eat enough. (She snatches away the bread and cheese, he catches off one end of the cheese then follows her to the middle of the avenue, and snatches off a piece of bread and returns eating, to the middle of the stage.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Rather saucy, fact, but a prudent wife. Rather saucy—but a very prudent saving wife (gets away)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Well husband I have been talking to Jule and she seems quite willing to let Butterford come and see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: I would not let him come, he'll eat up some of your bread and cheese.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Jule has so much company that they are likely to eat us out of house and home. I long to have her married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Let her marry then: I suppose she is willing enough—I must beat the anvil and puff the bellows, man∣age within doors as you will, I cares not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: But Juliet has a great opinion of parson Treadwell, I have a great mind to get him to advise her to marry Butterford.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Much you'll get by that: you'll have to give him a dinner and break one of our best jugs of beer, and then he won't give his advice unless he has a mind to. He is the plaguiest fellow for a parson that ever was—you can't make him do any thing but what is right. Hee—e —e—m—h.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: from within. RUN, Jule, Mr. Butterford is coming. Put up and look as smart as you can—put on your new moroker shoes, and a clean shawl, quick, quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: There is no cause for hurrying. He is so fat and short-breathed, that it will take him a great while to get to the house—yet. [She goes out very deliberately.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—BUTTERFORD, Mrs. IRONSIDE and JULIET.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: [Making a very awkward bow] GOOD evening, Madam, How do ye do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Well I'm glad to see you—Why I hardly know how I do do—but I'm fain to do whatever I have to do.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Where's Jule, is she to home?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Yes she is stept out, and will be in, in a min∣ute—I don't know what makes her stay. Juley!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Coming soon ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Well how does Jule do now—I'm going to make her my offers. Do you think she'll bite sharp. No man can give a better astayte than I. —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: You are well in that, Juley!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Coming ma'am very soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: She's not quite dressed I suppose. These girls have a despot notion of rigging up—when they are to meet a spark: that's quite natural d'ye see — I told Juley you'd got a new suit—It seemed to make her quite merry. —Juley!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Coming soon ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Then she was merry to think I had got these clothes —I hope that is a good sign. If I could make Jule have me I should be possed glad—Then I'd sit in my great chair and tell her to bring this and carry that—Then I'd laugh in my sleeve to see how obedient she'd be—and when she waited on me like a little spaniel — and I'd speak sharp and make her tremble and fly—and a man would come in and say what a sweet pretty wise you have, Mr. Butterford— Then I give him a tuck in the ribs—Hah! old fellow, why you fool, way could'nt you get such a wise hoh! hoh! hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Jule!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: (Faintly.) Coming ma'am— (Mrs. Ironside go to the entrance of the stage—sees Juliet weeping—and doubling her fist threatens Juliet.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Iron.
SP.P: What! crying again. Wipe up your eyes in one minute, and come here, or I'll know the reason why.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: An't she willing to come, or is she only a little dash'd about being courted?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron,
SP.P: She'll come by and by. (Juliet comes to the entrance of the stage, attempts to present herself—bursts forth in tears—steps back—wipes her eyes, and then enters with a very genteel courtely.)

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: (Nodding his head, still sitting in his chair.) Sarvant Miss Jule. How do you do? Jule.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: (With a silly affection of cunning.) Well I may as well go away. Young folks at such times don't want old folks about. [Mrs. Ironside goes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I am sure ma'am I am very willing you should stay.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—BUTTERFORD and JULIET.
DIV3.STAGE: (Butterford sitting, hitches his chair towards Juliet, partly backwards.)

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: WELL Jule. I think now we have a fair chance to make a bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Mrs. Ironside does all the trading in our family— she has bought in her stock of butter and cheese—and

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Poh, I did not mean so—you're joking Miss, let us have some fun? (Slaps her on the shoulder.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I do not love fun, it is the mirth of low bred peo∣ple.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Whew, why won't you let me talk with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Yes sir, if you will not say any thing that is im∣proper.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Well then, I tell you what miss, I expect you'll be a little shy at first just for the notion on't, tho you won't mean so—But I tell the right down truth—I come on pur∣pose to see if we could not trade and be married; that's plain downright stuff now.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Do you expect to conclude so great an affair at once.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Why not as well as in a thousand year— I'm wil∣ling to have you, why shouldn't you be willing to have me?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I must first know if we be suitable persons to be united—I must consult my heart to know if I have a proper regard for you. I must act seriously: for mar∣riage is one of the most important changes of human life.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P:
O you can have no objection— I have the most
money, the most cattle, the finest horse, and dress most costly of any man in this town, what would you have more?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: A man may have all these and yet be a very bad husband.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: But how the duce can that be? money makes the man, girls love rich men, who can let them have as must money as they can spend.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: If I marry you for your money, I must know whether I may spend it or not—If that be the only motive I must spend the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: You are all upon the joke now— (Slaps her on the arm and chucks her under the chin.) hoh! hoh! hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Positively, if you will not be decent I will with∣draw from the room.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: How shall I be decent, hoh! hoh! hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Sit peaceably in your own chair, that will please me most—then answer to such questions as I ask you—or ask me such questions as I can answer with propriety.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: (sits confused a few moments, then bursts into a great laugh.) Hoh! hoh! hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: What makes you so merry sir?

SP.SPEAKER: But
SP.P: 'Tis dan'd clever, hoh! hoh! hoh!

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: What is that which is so clever; will you not let one partake of your mirth?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Fayther's got all the advantage of uncle Sye.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: What advantage has your father got of your uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Uncle Sye's land lies on the hill, and fayther's land lies all below. Uncle Sye carries out all manner of nasty truck on his land for manyure, and fayther's land gets all the wash of it. So fayther has clean the advantage of un∣cle Sye.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: (with expressions of contempt.) Is that of any conse∣quence to you and me?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: O yes! Fayther's on his last legs—He has had an∣other tight snap of the gout—I don't know's he will die this whet—But he can't stand it long at this rate—Then if I have you, and he dies the estayte all comes into my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Suppose I should marry you, and you could get money by it, would you not wish me to die too?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Why that must be a mer of after consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I think the whole had better he a matter of after consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: You will let me come again, won't you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I have not the command of the house. My aunt will admit you for she is fond of you. But you must ex∣cuse me for the present I must be left to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet
SP.P: alone. Good heav'ns! what a husband my aunt is preparing for me!—But he is rich—That is all merit with her—In all his conversation not a word of me, nor even of himself—but of his wealth. And could even please him∣self with the prospect of his father's death—How much virtue or humanity can he have!—I'm positive I will not have him, I will die first. [Juliet goes out]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. — Mrs. IRONSIDE and BUTTERFORD.
DIV3.STAGE: (Entering on the opposite side of the stage.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: WELL, how do matters go on? pretty well? or will she lab you off by and by?

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: Not very bright, tho she wan't very cross. I want∣ed to have touzled and slapt her about a little, but she made me sit plucky still, and was darned tort upon me now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: My niece is very nice in her manners.

SP.SPEAKER: But.
SP.P: O she's cute, I know she's cute—but if I could once get her under my thumb, I'd make her do more as I would have her, I promise her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
But.
SP.P: Pardon a joke—If all were like you, I should think she was—Hoh! Hoh! Hoh!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mr. TREADWELL enters and speaks alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P:
I HAVE read of the trial of fire ordial—A
lady whose character was suspected, walked barefoot among red hot ploughshares, with scarcely room to set her feet to the ground; and if she burned her feet in the least, it was concluded that she was guilty. Such is the life of a Minister of a parish. Manly is a person whom I truly like, tho his estate is but moderate. Butterford is a proper clown, and a vicious fellow. The families both treat me well. The blacksmith and his wife are singular, but they are kind to me—They wish me to advise Juliet, my amia∣ble pupil, to marry Butterford. Can I in justice do it? Certainly not. This is an ugly affair—Let me think— won't this do? Mother Ironside loves to talk morals and have all the talk to herself—Suppose I let her go her own length, till she his confuted herself—Will any call that priestcraft? Let then if they will—Nothing is more hon∣est than to let those, who are in the wrong, confute them∣selves.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—TREADWELL and JULIET.
DIV3.STAGE: [Juliet enters with a bundle of Books.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tread.
SP.P: Juliet! my good girl, how ready you al∣ways are to meet me.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I have read the books you sent me—They are extremely pleasing, I am confident I shall be the wiser for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tread.
SP.P: If they be useful I shall be happy. My pu∣pils always keep their rank in my affections next to my own children. But there is a particular reason for my at∣tentions to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: I never knew any reason but that you wish to see every person happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: There is a very particular reason. Your excel∣lent mother, that bright example of all the virtues, in the last moments of her life, affectionately grasped my hand— am, said she, on the confines of the world of spirits—My husband must serve the states in this necessary war—Juliet is left and extremely exposed—look after her; direct her; keep her, if possible, from error and vice. This is my dy∣ing request. Could I fail to regard it? This is the cause of all the attentions which I have given to your affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P:
My uncle and aunt are very anxious that I should
he married. I have had several offers. I wish to live sin∣gle till my father comes home, that I may be disposed ac∣cording to his pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: I think it best for you to be married at a proper time. That kind of life has its thorns and its cares—but it is better than lonely, dismal celibacy—And if you do marry a sensible man, a man of good sound judgment, all other virtues will follow. You do right not to marry, as you are under age, till your father returns. It will be a particular pleasure to him to have the disposal of you himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Your approbation gives me the sincerest pleasure, as it exactly agrees with my own ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Proceed my worthy girl in your virtuous course, I will support you to my utmost ability.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Will you speak to my uncle and aunt? I am anx∣ious to know how they will relish your sentiments.

DIV3.STAGE: (Juliet goes out and he with her.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—IRONSIDE, TREADWELL and Mrs. IRONSIDE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: SARVANT sir, I am glad to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: How do you do my friend Ironside. Are you well madam? you are all well I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Pretty well sir, and we ought to be thankful, we are apt to think very little of what we enjoy, as you told us that was a fine sarmon, you said that if we had no more than we desarve, we should have but little.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: You talk too much, wife—Mr. Treadwell has been here but a moment and you are rattling away and one can't put a word in edgeways.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P:
Do I talk? I will talk—I can talk better than you any day—If we had no more than we desarved we should have but little, yet we are always craving, tho rich∣es are but vanity, young folks think it is grand to make a show, but it is all vexation—Handsome is that handsome does. Let virtue shine and you'll be fine. The best thing in the world is peace of conscience, and to be rich
in good work—An't I right Mr. Treadwell? When we die we carry nothing away and our works will follow. I want you should give me your opinion about our Juliet. I think it is high time she was married—It is quite a charge to keep her and all her company. Mr. Butterford is rich, and can maintain her well, and would be glad to have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Yes madam, but riches are but vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: But he can maintain her well, and they can make a decent show.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Very true, but it is all vexation. Let virtue shine and you'll be fine—Your plain maxims contain excellent truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: Now she has a notion for Manly, who is not half so rich; tho we know he is virtuous and industrious and all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: And is she not right? The best thing in the world is peace of conscience, and to be rich in good works —What signifies it to be always craving—When we die we can carry nothing away, but our good works will fol∣low.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Iron.
SP.P: I would not give a farthing for a minister if he could not give better advice, and such advice as one wants to have. (She goes out pouting.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Mr. Treadwell has given you no advice but your own, that's fact wife, say what you will—I wish you would hear him further, and then you would not pinch us all so about our victuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: There is Manly's servant coming in this mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Iron.
SP.P: Excuse me sir, neighbor Speedwell is at the shop and wants his mare shod this minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: CONNOR, is it you, how does your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Very well zur, only sick to death of love. Love zur has got the grap of him—Bad thing, that love, it has made many a clever fellow's heart ache before yet, master.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: And who is he in love with?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P:
Oh dear zur, that Julie, all our young fellows have lost their fine senses at her, they are as thick about her as
flies round a flop of molawses—they will be sipping and tasting you see, if they die for't

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: And would he consult me on that mter? Is it any thing about Juliet? I hope not—These cases of love are even worse than cases of conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: You hit the right nailmaister—see what a thing it is to be a minister, we sweak at them when the liquors gets here, (touching his forehead) but we can't be sick, nor well, be in love, nor be married, be christened, nor die, without a minister—By my showl were I to grow young again, I'd go to College whether I could get there or no, and when I was out, the first thing▪ I'd do would be to live and die a minister, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Well, and what does Manly desire of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: He would have you come till his house—he wants a—a—master's poorly, tis love, I guess, he's as thin as a shad in reeping time, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Let him come to my house? I have something, of importance to communicate to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I hope sir, I pray you come, Master's a clever soul, he's quite poorly, and if he should die with love, it would be a disgrace to him, as long as he lives. (Connor goes out.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—TREADWELL and JULIET.

SP.P: MISS Juliet will you come to my house in half an hour, to see the letters which I have received from your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Were there none for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Tread
SP.P: There were not?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: That is very strange. But I should be glad to see the letters which y wrote to you.

DIV3.STAGE: [ well goes out, and as Juliet is following, Mayflower enters.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV—MAYFLOWER and JULIET.
DIV3.STAGE: (Mayflower advances slowly and coldly keeps a large distance from Juliet.)

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: SERVANT M Jul

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Miss May, my friend, I am happy to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: I might be happy too if you could clear yourself of the charge of treachery against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P:
Charge of treachery. When did I ever
with any of your affairs more than you desired me to do?

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: I suppose you mean to make me believe that you know nothing of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: It is absolutely true that I know not what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: I meant to have asked advice how to proceed with you. But since you are here I will confront you my∣self—and you may answer if you can—Who wrote this letter to slander my character?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Not certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: How can you deny it—it is your own signing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: It is not my hand, I should be ashamed of such a scrawl.

SP.SPEAKER: May.
SP.P: I have suffered severely, but Mr. Daffodil, whose attentions I own were pleasing, has left me with disgust; an is gone to the town with Fidelia. If you have not done it, it i beyond my comprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: It was not I however—but let me think, yes it is the hand writing of that villain, who writes letters for But∣terford—who is such an ideo that he cannot write himself.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I—MANLY and JULIET.
DIV3.STAGE: Scene is changed to the minister's house, the stage represents his study with chairs, tables, books, manuscripts, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: MY amiable friend, how happy to meet you in person, when the mere idea of you ever give me delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Your sentiments Mr. Manly are even obliging —but to urge a declaration can only give me pain—I shall give no one a decided preference till my father's return, or while the hope of it remains.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Are you not at least my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: Certain I know how to esteem you as a man of merit—But my determination is sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: You are perfectly reasonable, nor can I deny it, these hours of suspense are almost insupportable.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—TREADWELL and JULIET.— (All the party ex∣cept Ironside and his wife.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: MY amiable pupil almost as dear to me as a daughter —I have received a letter, from your father that he shall not soon return. He has received a letter which states that you died the 12th of July last—On which he orders me to sell his estate, and he is about to embark for the East-Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: O my worthy good friend—I was made to be wretched—I never saw my mother that I remember—nor my father since I was a child, except in my dreams. My relations here would throw me into the arms of a contemp∣tible wrtch—O sir, can you not interpose to save me?

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Amiable girl, I regret your distress. But can I be concerned n making, or breaking of matches—or in∣croach on the rights of families, my character would be lost —very soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Now my beautiful, my charming friend consent to be mine—I will protect you tho you may see your father no more—Let me be father, friend, brother, and every thing else to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: I have sent letters several ways informing that you are still alive—I may bring him back for I have writ∣ten to Canton in China—But after all, his return is uncer∣tain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: My heart forbodes that I shall never see him again, my anguish is almost insupportable, I respect you Mr. Manly. But can I think of any thing that is pleasant when I must no more see my father—I live a wretched life with Mrs. Ironside, confined, and almost starved at times. This last stroke is Butterford's work. I am confi∣dent, he hires a base fellow to write for him. He forged a letter yesterday to Mr. Daffodil, to slander Miss May∣flower and signed it with my name to involve me in a quarrel with Miss Mayflower and her family. He means to get me into his power, I had rather suffer death. He is a dreadful instance of the power of an unprincipled rich man over the poor—pity me, most respected sir, assist a poor girl in extremity.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Alas! what would the world say of me, should I take yo from your relations and guardian into my own custody. It would give rise to scandal. Many would resent such an intrusion on the rights of families.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Once more, my dear girl, listen to a faithful friend. I will take you under my own protection, and de∣fend you with my life

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: But can I in such distress, on my father's ac∣count—or can I live with a bachelor. Should my father return, could I ever look him in the face?

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: We are all right and yet are all in extreme dis∣tress—Yet my dear young friends, let us do nothing wrong —Here is a trial of our trust in Divine Providence. Be obstinate. Virtue must triumph, tho we know not how.— I will think for you, and do you (approaching Juliet) re∣tire, my good girl, whose heart is sorely burdened, and pour out your tears to him who numbers the tears of the afflicted. She is conucted by Treadwell to the avenue, and i oarce behind the curtain when she exclaims—

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: O my father! my father!

SP.SPEAKER: C. Bloom.
SP.P: O my daughter—how like my wife—a little girl when I left you—now a grown woman—and how beautiful—my sweet Juliet, alive and well—and O how much like her mother. (Manly goes to the curtain, peeps be∣hind the curtain; sees Capt. Bloomsgrove, and leaps about the stage in a frenzy of joy.)

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Her father is come—Capt. Bloomsgrove is come▪ as you live 'tis he, I know him. The whole company we rushing to the opening of the curtain, out Mr. Treadwell stays them.

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: 'Tis he; I know him by his voice; but restrain your curiosity—give a parent and child a few tender mo∣ments at their meeting—Their transports are too sacred for common observation. (Capt. Bloomsgrove appears at the entrance with his face turned partly back, talking to Juliet.)

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: Come my dear, wipe your eyes, and let us see the rest of the company—Sweet girl; I left you at four years old, and you are now a grown woman—you look just like your mother when I was married.

DIV3.STAGE: [Bloomsgrove enters, nobly dressed, and bowing genteelly]

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: O Captain, my worthy friend, how happy to see you again.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: Next to my little daughter here you are the dearest person to me on earth—and who is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: It is miss Mayflower.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms
SP.P: She was about three years old—when I went away, a little proud Sylph—I remember how she would per when she was dressed up.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: [Catching Mr. Treadwell's sleeve.] This good man has done a thousand good things for me, will you not re∣ward him?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: I will find a time for that my dear child. And what friend is this, Manly? Yes it is Manly; my brave Lieutenant, who selled the Hessian to the ground— who wounded me in the battle of Princeton—He preserv∣ed my life. If there be any thing in this world whereby I can reward him, it must be his.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.P: He has been generous to me and—and—honest.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: I knew him my girl in the army, he is as fine a soul as lives—what shall I give you Manly? (to Manly) Will you take Juliet.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: (bowing respectfully) Will you let me have her?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: Yes if she be willing—what say you my girl— she blushes with eyes partly cast down, looks sideways in her father's face, and remains silent.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: Her tongue says nothing, but her eyes say yes—take her— (Quits her hand, and Manly takes it warmly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Manly.
SP.P: Now I'm the happiest man on this earth and the richest—but I will be happier in a few days by your assist∣ance. (To Mr. Treadwell.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: (bowing.) Any time when you please, shall I delight to contribute to your felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Blooms.
SP.P: O my friends how sweet is domestic pleasure. Riches, victory, and glory are nothing in comparison. It is a pleasure which I have not tasted till now for fourteen years. (Wipes his eyes which flow in tears of joy.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tread.
SP.P: Come captain you shall tarry with me this night. Manly after supper will conduct Juliet home—and let it be known that you are come—all her enemies will be silent now. Miss Mayflower tarry till after supper, and my girls, shall go home with you—come be seated—I will call my wife and daughters, and while supper is preparing we will have a song. (or dance) There is no crime in decent joy. It is practical Thanksgiving to the Author of all our mercies.

DIV3.STAGE: They sit. A song or dance is performed, as the exhibitor pleases.

DIV1.HEAD: The Coquette. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
THE FOLLY OF A CAPRICIOUS TEMPER, AND THE DISADVANTAGE OF COQUETRY TO THE GENERAL INTERESTS OF WOMEN.
DIV1.P: IT is a very good instance of policy in a woman, if she has engaged the affections of any man, with a view to marriage, to avoid the smallest danger of losing them. A woman deserted by a man once engaged to her, is subject to many censures, and dangerous suspicions. Were it not universally known, that there are women, who use men ex∣tremely ill, in consequence of gaining their affec∣tions; the desertion of a woman, after indications of love, would ruin a man's character. Coquettes injure not themselves only—but their sex in general.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. BOOTHBY—an honest householder; Guardian to the two young ladies, Marcella and Daphne.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MISS SEAFAIR—common friend to Marcella and Daphne.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: MY wards, the time approaches when I must act the part of a father to you no more. This evening I must give up my charge. Tomorrow morning you will be at your own disposal—It was so ordered that I should give up the guardianship when the youngest was of law∣ful age.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I regret indeed that I must be left to myself, your kind care left me nothing to wish for, but the continuance of it. If we must be left to ourselves, can we not have some kind of advice from you; some of your maxims which contain much wisdom in a few words?

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I choose to say but little▪ Long discourses are not apt to be remembered—Let the foundation of your character be plain honesty and good nature. Depend principally on your virtue for your happiness—As you both are sufficiently genteel, affect no uncommon character, but be what nature and common sense have made you. If you have a good offer, I advise you to marry; but not suddenly—let a polite acquaintance with the person whom you are to marry, remain for some time, that you may acquire the habit of pleasing, & being pleased with the per∣son who is to be yours for life. Never trifle with a man who seriously addresses you; but by all means marry a man of sense, and think of no earthly things so much as pleasing him, so long as you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You need not have told my sister of that—She never had any company of the gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: My niece, I hope you do not perversely exclude them—If you do▪ I shall almost think you lost to society.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph
SP.P: Sir I never affected gallantry. Marcella outshines me so much in that, that they pass by me, and pay all their attention to her, but perhaps I shall have my turn, and in the best time too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You have a great faculty at hoping, and I advise you, for your comfort, to keep it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I must retire to my own affairs—Good bye, my amiable wards. Remember what I have told you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: WHAT do you think of the advice the old gen∣tleman has been giving us?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I cannot perfectly understand it, for want of ex∣perience in such matters—but as our uncle has experienced all these things himself; and is certainly a man of sense, and honesty; I am apt to think he has told us right.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I mean to do as I please. I am glad that to∣morrow morning I shall be at my own disposal—And as to the gentlemen who pay their addresses to me—I mean to trifle with them as much as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I suppose it, for every person who speaks of it, thinks you treat Mr. Malcolm in a very absurd manner; for they say he is a gentleman of real merit, virtuous, hon∣est, polite, and of decent fortune, a man of good sense in every thing but his attachment to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: His attachment to me. I think that this is all that discovers his good sense! Mark this, that what nature has denied us in courage, and natural strength she has made up in the power, which she has given us, of affecting the hearts of men.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: And if we have that power, ought we not to use it to a good purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
That I shall, I promise you. There is nothing which affords me so much amusement, as to see how I can play with their sensations. When they come trembling to me to ask for some trifling attention, which I am already more than willing to grant—when they hesitate, and stam∣mer, with excessive anxiey. To see how elate they will be, when they are successful; how dismal and forlorn▪
when they are rejected, it makes me as proud as a queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: Possibly one might carry that vanity too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You know nothing of the matter. The men never pay much attention to you. I consider a suitor as worth nothing, unless you can treat him in as many different ways, as you can dress a fish; and still find him humble and pas∣sive—A fish you know may be baked, broiled, roasted, boiled, smoked and dryed—may be dressed with sauce, or without, and every way makes a good dish. So a lover suitable to my taste, must broil with resentment, must be roasted with anger, must be baked by the heat of constant affection, must boil with jealousy, must be smoked with contempt—and his very marrow must be dried up with anxious expectation. If I afford him any attention he must be elated to the highest degree of joy. If I deny him, he must sink into the grave of disappointment—Such a man, always passive as the lamb, is the man to my taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: There are other women of the same taste, but they are not always so happy as to realize their ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I shall take care of myself for that▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P: I WISH you would interpose your authority in this affair. [Exit Marcella.]

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: When I was young I always did my own work, in respect of the ladies—I do not love to meddle with that of others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P: But as you are guardian to the young lady I can apply to no one else.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: My charge expires this evening, and I have given her my last advice. But what do you complain of?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P: She has perfectly bewitched my son. I com∣pare it to nothing but a serpent's charming a bird—I have seen a snake raise his neck to a lofty spire, his seal glisten, and his eyes sparkle. Then he fixes his eyes on some harmless bird, who appears to be in extreme distress; and to make efforts to get away; but the more he endeavors to escape, the nearer he gets to the serpent till he is destroyed.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: Is that the condition of your son?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P:
You may judge, as well as I, of the state of
his mind, when I shall mention a few facts—He associated himself with her—and has been constantly unhappy—He is agitated to that degree that I fear the loss of his reason —Not long since she sent him home, on a rainy evening without a grea coat; tho he met her on appointment. He caught a severe cold, and was confined a fortnight—An∣other time she pretended that she took a new beaver hat from him, and burnt it—but she kept it and changed it for an umbrella. She frequently makes him do the meanest errands for her—send him all over town, to buy a penny-worth of needles, half a knot of thread, and half a yard of tape. Every way she tries to injure him, and make him ridiculous—by his attachment to her. A woman who treats a man so deserves to be punished.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: She commonly is. The husband having such no one in his power commonly pays the old debt, with interest upon interest; but if a young man will be a fool, he must answer for it himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P: My son Harry is as sensible man as any of his age, and as virtuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I doubt it not. But he would resent it, should I attempt his liberty. None can free him; but himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Mal.
SP.P: I hoped that you would use your authority in the case. And that you would endeavor to make her behave better▪ You ought to consider my extreme anxiey for my sn.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I pity you, and him sincerely. But a woman who has that preverse temper is of all beings the hardest to cure: I have given her my last advice; you must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mal.
SP.P: Alas my only remedy is patience; but I do think that a woman who makes use of the art of charming▪ to such a purpose, is the most mischievous serpent in the universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: Your own sex too, I am glad I did not say that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: IT gives me great pleasure to see you so well, you look delightful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am very much out of health however, how ca you to think of seeing me to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: It was by your appointment; but if you say the word I withdraw; I come to invite you to Mr. Sprightly's ball—but if you do not chuse to go—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Who told you that I did not mean to go? I shall dress, but stay, I have not a pin to dress myself with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: I will step over the street and get you some at the next shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: They have none fit to dress a dll with, you must go to Mrs. Merers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: That is two miles & an half at least▪ we shall lose the time▪ perhaps the others may do for the present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's like a gentleman to be sure, to make a difficulty of obliging his lady—if you will get me pins to dress me, I will go—otherwise I shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar▪
SP.P: SO you see, I teach him his duty. A woman who means to have a good husband, must bring him up to her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: You are not certain of his being your husband.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Will he brake his word—I did not treat him so till I got him fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: Perhaps not so fast as you imagine—If he be a man of honor, your treatment of him is very improper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How do you understand these matters. When did a man ever speak to you—how would you treat a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph
SP.P: Common sense tells me I should treat a real gen∣tleman kindly—if that be right—before he is engaged to me—much more so after, else I should be guily of fals∣hood. The caprice of Coquettes is well known, which is the very reason why men do not become infamous by de∣serting a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You would be all honey and no vinegar. I love to torment them for variety's sake—Let us hear your cu∣rious theory of conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Dalph
SP.P:
Female honor demands its proper reserve. Yet my promised lover should certainly have my confidence above any man in the world, he should be my inviolable
friend, and confident—I would study to please him—we would advise and correct each other—our virtues should be mutual, our joys and sorrows united; I would mourn his disappointments and encourage his virtues, I would imitate his virtues, and improve by his learning, I would find an endless variety of kind offices, and never be forced to torment him for variety's sae.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And for what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: He should reward me, by being my constant pa∣tron, defender and friend, and by doing every kind office in his power. Previous acquaintance is the school in which nature trains us up for marriage. It is observed by some reputable authors, that they who quit this school too soon, are often unhappy; that they who torment each other will continue to do so after marriage—they who act rationally will not alter—they who deceive in their previous acquaintance, will after marriage be openly vic∣ious. I have treasured many of these maxims in my mind —to me if it ever fall to my lot, I intend it shall be the school of wisdom—and prepare my mind for the various duties of domestic life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This is queer stuff—think to manage love by rea∣son—do sometime tell this in the circle of our acquaintance, that we may have an infinite fund of ridicule and laughter.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—MALCOLM and DAPHNE.
DIV3.STAGE: [As Malcolm enters, Marcella goes out as if by design.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: TELL me, Daphne, what humor is your sister in now?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: She adheres to her own system—I do not see that she relents at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal
SP.P: I procured the pins for her at the next shop—who had the best, you will not tell her.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: No, for I do not like her ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: I wish she had your ideas of those matters. They are excellent, or that it had been so ordered that I had been attached to you. But do one thing for me, and trust me upon my word, for once. Dress yourself for the ball, and trust me for the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I will. (He withdraws.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—MARCELLA reenters with SEAFAIR and DAPHNE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: WHAT fools the men are—I love dearly to plague them—I have sent my spark two miles and an half only to get some pins to dress with, and I have more than a year's stock-by me now,

SP.SPEAKER: Sea.
SP.P: My friend Marcella, notwithstanding the keenness of your wit—I suspect you are very erroneous on this subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar▪
SP.P: I see you are going into our Daphne's notions, I supposed that no other person in the world thought as she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph
SP.P: My sentiment is, that to treat others rationally, is the likeliest way to be treated well ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea
SP.P: That idea is certainly a just one Why need human beings be ignorant of their own happiness? I know by hap∣py experiment that the season in which young persons are acquainted, previously to their marriage, may not only be rendered very agreeable, but extremely useful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: There you have it again morals, morals, morals, forever, and upon every subject. Do give me volatiles for I shall certainly faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea
SP.P: And why not moral forever? Does not our whole happiness depend on them? To conduct well and success∣fully—i certainly the knowledge we most need—you have lost time enough in quarrelling with your humble swain, to have made you a very prudent woman, if you had con∣ducted yourself property.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, what do Malcolm and I fail in? Tell me, perhaps I may reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea.
SP.P: Instead of quarrelling and uniting, contention and reconciliation again, which have pt you both uneasy and unhappy for three years past; you might both have been improving your minds, tempers, and manners, more than in the best school in America.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How does that appear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sea.
SP.P: A constant tendency to any object, will have its effect in all cases, but that of impossibility. The desire of pleasing, directed to a constantly alluring object—wil make a person social, and polite. Hence persons, attached to virtuous, and sensible partners, almost immediately discover in their general conversation, a better temper, and a more sociable disposition, than before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What can they find to talk of in so many long interviews?

SP.SPEAKER: Sea.
SP.P: You quarrel then, to pass away the time, do you? Are there not other topics, even if you omit fashions, and the scandal of the day? Human passions, and human characters, politeness of manners, and principles of hu∣manity. The polite, and elegant arts; the qualities of books, and friends; and the interesting views, which piety and morality exhibit—might claim some attention. And friends may make any subject interesting by considering it in the relation which it bears to themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I have long believed, that two friends may al∣ways make each other happy if they have only the necessa∣ries of life. If happiness comes so cheap, human beings owe their miseries chiefly to their own follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: For heaven's sake away with this dull stuff—I hope some person will come in, and give a change to this ridiculous conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sea.
SP.P: My conversation if it be disagreeable ceases in a mo∣ment—madam I wish you a good night.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.— MALCOLM, MARCELLA, and DAPHNE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Madam I am ready to conduct you to the ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I will be ready in a moment, (she goes out, and comes in again with a coarse checked apron on.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Now sir, I will go with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Will you? but you will not go with that apron.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why not—It is proper to dress according to our company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: My company, you mean—well, I do not object; will the company at the ball think that they are well treat∣ed? However that is none of my concern. I will go with you as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, I will not neither, the company will be af∣fronted▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: You may change your dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That is too much trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Then keep it and go with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I shall be laughed at.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P:
Then stay if you please—But I mean to go.I'll
wait on another lady; and I would pay no more attention to you, but that I do not love to break my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's brave! Let not that be any hindrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Then if you will discharge me, I quit you forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The difficulty is to get rid of you. I have heard you say so several times before; but you did not keep your resolution. I shall have you tormenting me again in a few days.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: I was not provided with another lady then; but I am now. Come my sweet Daphne, you are now the mis∣tress of my heart; will you go with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: If my sister refuses; but she shall speak first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: Then I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What a droll figure you will make. You scarcely ever saw a ball in your life. I will dress myself this mo∣ment, and go with my uncle, that I may be there to laugh at you. [Exit Marcella.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Well now she is gone, why may we not tarry? I have no great desire to go to the ball; I had much rather remain here with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: I certainly have no great desire to dance. It is what I am very little acquainted with—But let us go, and see that she is gone. [They wihdraw from the stage.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: MISS Laurella, is Marcella gone to the ball?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: She is going with her uncle—she thought you and Daphne were gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: No, and I believe we shall not go. I had rather remain with Daphne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Then Marcella will be extremely disappointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: She must thank herself for it; she might have or∣dered it otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I know it; but she thought she had you so secure, that she might treat ou any way; and you would not dare to resent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: She is not the first woman who has found herself mistaken in such a matter; and perhaps will not be the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I believe it, and am sensible that the conduct of Marcella was extremely ungrateful to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: She thinks now that I shall return to her, but she will soon perceive her error.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau
SP.P: Yet she was really attached to you, and will se∣verely feel the loss of you▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Why then did she treat me in that manner?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Nature made her a coquette, and she could make herself otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Is Daphne of the same disposition?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Certainly she is not. There is so great a differ∣ence between them, that I could hardly suppose them sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Let who will take Marcella, I have long wished for an opportunity to break my chain. She has given me a fair one, and hence forward the mild, the sweet Daph∣ne shall be the object of my attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: WHAT has Marcella done with herself?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: She is gone to the ball with her uncle in full ex∣pectation of seeing you there, and laughing at you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: She is welcome to her all felicity, I have borne her tyranny long enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: No body will blame you, I am confident. Every person said you bore with her too long.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: The point of honor was the thing, I had given my word, she says that need not hinder me from leaving her, so I have a purlough at all points.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Certainly you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Many another poor slave has, I dare say, been glad of his dismission, but I am no sooner free than I am a captive again. I have long noticed your virtues; and now wish to give my permanent homage to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: You must allow me time to consider of that— but if I finally conclude to detain you, I shall not keep you in perpetual torments; as Marcella did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P:
My acquaintance with your sister gave me an op∣portunity to observe your virtues; and it was the kind
relief of my mind, by your gentle and rational conversa∣tion, which made me think of breaking the fetters of the imperious Coquettè.

SP.SPEAKER: Daph.
SP.P: Time, and acquaintance, only, can show whether we be suited to each others manners. But I shall endeavor to conduct myself properly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem
SP.P: SOME business with Mr. Boothby occasioned my calling this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He is in the opposite room.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem.
SP.P: Just returned from the ball; you did not tarry so long as you commonly did with Malcolm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I only went to see them a little while.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem.
SP.P: It is droll enough. You and Malcolm have had a breaking off this evening; and he went with your sister Daphne; you may give him up for lost—the sweet, and delightful manners of your sister will detain him forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What a blockhead he was to break his word with me? I am pursuaded he never will prosper.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem.
SP.P: After you had released him from it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I did it in a pet. I am extremely mortified, and see that you enjoy it—Enjoy it you may; for I am quite in the humor to punish myself. But that he should attach himself to that honest, good natured, awkward thing, my sister Daphne.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem.
SP.P: She is no sister of your's—you was indeed bro't up with her—but your parents are unknown to us—Nor have you any portion out of the estate, which you have supposed to belong in common, to you▪ and Daphne—you have only £. 120 to purchase furniture for a house. The whole estate is Daphne's— She being the only child.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Then I have lost a happy opportunity of establish∣ing myself in life. Was ever girl so unfortunate? I will ask Mr. Boothby. I do not believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nem.
SP.P: I thank you for disputing my word, and wish you a good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I AM most unfortunate, my dear uncle, pray comfort me a little. Is not Malcolm a villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I cannot blame him—You treated him very ill; and challenged him to leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nemesia always hates me. She has told me I am not your niece, and that the whole estate is Daphne's.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: All that is true; but it is a mystery that she should know it— You ruined yourself by losing Malcolm. But you would take no advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: When I have once caught a man in the toils of love, I must plague him—It is my nature, and I should do it again if I died for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Booth.
SP.P: I believe it, I never knew a woman of that per∣verse temper to reform—But they may not begin it, if du∣ly warned—It is certainly the ruin of the woman who is so inclined, and a great damage to the interest of the sx. For what is the very reason, why a man does not lose his character in deserting a woman, to whom he stands engag∣ed—but this; that the caprice of coquettes, is so generally known.

DIV1.HEAD: The Insolable Question. A DRAMA, OF ONE ACT.
PRUDERY AND FORWARDNESS ARE EQUALLY PERNICIOUS TO WOMEN.
DIV1.P: IT is altogether absurd for women to think of captiv∣ating the men—by throwing themselves forever in their way. This mode of conduct will only cre∣ate disgust—and there is as little of charm or at∣traction in the behavior of a Prude.
DIV1.L: "The honor of a Prude is rage and storm—
"'Tis ugliness in its most frightful form."

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. DILEMMA—a Sph of the college, and a Pedan.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MISS WINDFALL—a jealous girl, young and gay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: MY dear Lucinda, what a happy girl you are, your company is desired by all people old and young— and every person speaks of you with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I am sorry for that, the view of too many will be directed to me—It would cost me much trouble—I ever tho't it an unhappiness to be too much the object of ad∣miration.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Why, how can any person be loved and admired too much? I should like to be admired by every body.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Your ambition then must descend very low some∣times.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I did not mean exactly so neither. But there is a certain class whom I should wish to be in raptures with me, whenever they saw me—I should not care much about old people.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: There you differ from me — The sentiments of people who are not of our own age may be of great use to us. They can give us credit and a good name—But I doubt whether it is right to seek the particular admiration of many persons of our own age at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: You, it seems, are very scrupulous.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Were the persons, from whom attention to young ladies might be expected, distributed among us all, there would scarcely be one apiece—Were it then possible, I should suppose it unjust, to engross a number. I had ra∣ther enjoy the beneficial society of one true friend, than be the dupe of twenty flatterers — To flatter a lady that is really deserving, is very much like painting a diamond to make it shine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P:
I am not very fond of flattery; but it may do
when one can get nothing else. It is more pleasing to hear good sense, or what we call good sense; but I had rather men would flatter me than say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: The whole business is commonly artificial. A man uses flattery as musicians do the fa, sol, la, me, of their gamut, to put their voices into tune. When one knows the artifice, it soon becomes tiresome. But tell me, my friend, if you be so fond of admiration, by what means you have attempted to secure it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I have in various ways tried to accomplish my pur∣pose. They may all be reduced to one principle—that of doing things extraordinary But my friends seem to be grow∣ing more & more indifferent to me every day—I should be glad, if by conversing with you I could set my ideas right.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Why so much anxiety on the subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Because you know one wishes to be acceptable, let matters, other wise, be as they may.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I am sorry that you have been so much mortified. It must be bitterness to a woman of spirit. But before I give my sentiments, let me know the method you have hitherto practised. The physician always examines his pa∣tient, before he prescribes a cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Well, to make the matter clear, I will introduce to you my illustrious cousin, Miss Bridget Crowbar.

SP.SPEAKER: Bridg.
SP.P: (asson as she enters) I AM really ashamed of the ladies of these times—They marry as if they were made ly for the happiness of the men—I'm out of all patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: No madam, you must not be affronted; thay will some of them take notice of you yet—The men, I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Bridg.
SP.P: That's none of my meaning—I'll have you to know—modesty wins the love of all our acquaintance. I love to drive a principle quite to a violent extreme.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: That I have thought of, and I have been modest: I have been violently modest, have I not?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I thought modesty always avoided violence and extremes, and brought every action to the test of rea∣son and discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: I profess to be the white rose of modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P:
And beset, I believe, with a double portion of
thorns—You will keep the men at a distance, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: That I will—I will not be courted but adored— My lovers shall worship me at an immense distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: How do you think a young lady ought to behave in presence of gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: She ought to be as cross as vengeance, and not say a word to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Not if they ask her questions?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Then she must answer, no—in a faint mincing voice—and lisp a little—A woman should never say yes to a man—That's very immodest.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Suppose a man should ask her, whether she made a point of being virtuous—what? must she say no then?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: There may be extraordinary ases; in these one may say yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I take it the most extraordinary question a woman is ever asked is, whether she will consent to be married— she must always say yes—in such a ase then.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: You are a wicked creature. I do not know what will become of you —I suspect if you were courted you would be married in less than eight years—It seems as if modesty was banished from the earth—I have tried to keep it up. But all my sex is sunk into degeneracy—woful de∣generacy.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Propose yourself then as a pattern to all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: I am loh to propose myself as an example—But I can find no other—Now I have meant to let the young gentleman see how much I avoided them.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: How did you do this?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Mr. Tiptoe is coming, I will show how it is done.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mr. TIPTOE (entering) and Miss BRIDGET.

SP.SPEAKER: Tip.
SP.P: MADAM your most obedient humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (Receding to the farthest part of the stage.) Sir?— (seats herself prim and bridles up)

SP.SPEAKER: Tip.
SP.P: Madam if my conversation could be tho't agreeable (offers to seat himself by her; she removes, places an empty chair between him and her, with the back towards him, and draws an∣other chair before her, and says)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tip.
SP.P:
I could wish madam— (surveys her around—at last removes the chair at her side and seats himself by her—and lean
towards her—she takes a large pin and stabs it into his flesh near his knee.)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: There sir. (He starts up and exclaims.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tip.
SP.P: O you beast—I meant to say that you was too se∣vere, I ask pardon—But I shall trouble you with my company no more. (Rubs the wounded part as he goes off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (with an air of triumph) There! I have served many a one so in my life time—I have shed more blood in my life-time, than has been shed in twenty duels, such are told of in our newspapers—A fellow went to seat himself by me, the other day; he was intoxicated by my beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: That was extraordinary, what did you do in that case?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: It was a dreadful trial for me. (Whining.) But I overcame. (Triumphantly.) He spake, I knit my brow into frowns, he turned to me his face, I immediately turned mine from him; he came so near to me that I his breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What did you do then?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: I boxed his cars well: and I have done greater ex∣ploits than that.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What? I am sure I never heard of any more ex∣traordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: One particular piece of conduct I can't help brag∣ging of a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: A few evenings ago, Mr. Complaisant, finding me a mile and half from home, in a very dark and slippery night, very handsomely (to do the creature justice) con∣ducted me home.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I should suppose you would have thanked him for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Fye and I am ashamed of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What did you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: What did I do, why when I got home he said I should allow some little decent complaisance, for waiting on me so carefully.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: You tho't it reasonable I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Not I—As he came a little too near me, I put my ten claws right into his face, I warrant I pealed it well.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Then you do not wish the men to respect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bridg.
SP.P: Don't I, that I do—They admire me—They'll break thro every obstacle and marry me by and by, whe∣ther I will or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: They will do otherwise than I expect; certainly, if they do as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: I am afraid I shall not convince you, ladies; so I go where my advice is more desired—But I can tell you, ladies, that Diana of the Ephesians, who was worshipped as a goddess, was the perfect tigress of her sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: The men, I imagine, are not so fond of worship∣ping tigresses in these times.

SP.SPEAKER: Bridg.
SP.P: If I take up a principle, I never give it up. What is right will come to right at last. [Exit Bridget.]

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Now to know how Miss Crowbar's principles re∣late to success in life; we must see whether they made her happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: They have not, the men hate her beyond all bounds—Tho she expects that some one among them will very soon be so enamoured of her superlative excellence, as to break thro all bounds; and insist on marrying her—But there is no appearance of it at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: What counsel do you propose to take next?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I am resolved upon nothing—I just mention Miss Jemima Toogood—She advises to the opposite extremes— to change the tables with the swains, and pursue them in turn—If you make direct advances to the men, write let∣ters, billetdoux &c, unasked—or let them take a good deal of liberty—there is no harm in it; if the interest of virtue be secure—these are her maxims.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: If the interests of virtue be secure—That is a great i indeed—now if this same IF can preserve us from folly, after we have parted with discretion—it shall forever after be printed in capitals, I shall never admit her proposit∣ion while I have my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P:
These ladies are a curious-contrast: their reading is as singular as their conduct. A book which was owned by Miss Crowbar, represented in the burlesque, a man who was in pursuit of a prude—kissing the shadow of her glove on the wall; while she held her hand near a candle —Miss Crowbar gravely observed, that she wondered why
that should be tho't burlesque, for it was being quite to familiar with the lady; considering he had paid her only two years attendance; and she banished the book from her library.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: If such was the reading of Miss Bridget, it would be curious to know that of Miss Toogood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: It was chiefly of Anecdotes, and SECRET HISTO∣RIES, with a small addition of very amorous plays—Her books were all of the cast which melt rather than warm the heart; and confound rather than enliven the imagination. She is not at all to my taste; and you need not fear my following her example or advice—But now it is your turn, you should introduce somebody—or dismiss our conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: There is a man of my acquaintance in the college, a very good man in the main—Indeed he is a little too apt not to hear readily, when one speaks to him; to talk to ladies with his back turned to them; to pair his nails in company, or so—but he is reputed a scholar nevertheless, and is I believe, a very good man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: How shall we obtain his opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: He was to have called here to day—The time is passed that he should have come—heigh—he is knocking now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: LADIES your servant! your servant!

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Will you please to take a seat?

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: It is as hot as mount Vesuvius to day. You have heard of the volcanoes, ladies, I suppose—Virgil des∣cribes one in a very grand manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: We have heard of volcanoes—But we were talking of something very different; of the most pleasing mode of conversation for—Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: How to mix the jucundum cum dulci.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: No 'tis not about jumping or mull'd cider. Some∣thing more curious than that.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: Of what the Greeks, to pronounce the finale a broad, kalo cagathâ.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Oh no sir, it is not about kale, nor cabbage slaw; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: I believe I understand you madam—There is something about it in Aristotle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I did not know that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: Xenophon abounds with it, more than any oth∣er author.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Sir, (smiling) let me tell you my desire if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: O yes, madam, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: It is a question of the greatest importance—And it is this: which is the greatest disadvantage to a lady— to be too forward or too prudish.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: Aye, that is a great matter—it is a subject not unknown to the ancients—much was said of it between the Pithagoreans and Peripatetics—The Lyceum and Ac∣ademus were divided about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Well sir, we should be glad to hear you discuss the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: I must take it up, pro and con, according to mode and form—We must handle it in our own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: As methodically as you please, if we can only on∣ly understand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: For the first general proposition. It is thus— whether that which is generally called forwardness in a woman, can ever be for her advantage. Now upon this question there are thirteen good reasons against it—and Firstly, that if a woman be too forward, the men will al∣ways hold her in contempt—Secondly—

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: O dear sir, you have said enough on that point— you may pass to another. Pray tell us the reasons why a woman should not be a prude.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: They are reckoned fourteen—but the thirteen against forwardness, tho less in number, are thought to be strongest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Will you please to recite them?

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: Firstly—if a woman keep a man at a mile's dis∣tance, he never can be sociable with her—

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: O sir! your propositions are quite decisive—I fan∣cy you are a great scholar.

SP.SPEAKER: Dilem.
SP.P: Why ladies, it has been tho't at college, that, tho prudery & forwardness are opposite causes in the order of nature; yet the effect of them comes to the same thing in Greek.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.— Miss WINDALL and LEMIRA.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: LADIES you mean me, I know you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Mean you, I did not know that you was within a mile of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: It is not true that I held Tom Longshanks a whole evening in my lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I did not say you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: And it is as great a lie which was told about me, that I sent a letter to Joe Moonshine—with our hearts united, for the first salutation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: I never said any such word that you or any body else did.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: I'm glad, ladies, if you are clear: but as you was talking about forwardness among the ladies, I thought you meant me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Not I, by any means, if you have any thing of that kind to settle with your own conscience, you may settle it alone if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: I am obliged to you ladies, but if I did as bad as they tell of me, it was not so bad as Miss Crowbar; who, when a young gentleman came near, wounded him so with the points of her scissors, that the blood spouted to a yard's distance, and they were obliged to send for a surgeon to take care of him. (Enters Madam Sensible.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: No, no Miss Windfall, we meant nothing of this kind—but we were only enquiring what was the surest method of behaving acceptably; we found that the forward woman and the prude were equally unsuccessful we wished to know the right way.

SP.SPEAKER: Wind.
SP.P: I believe that madam Sensible can tell you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.—Mad. SENSIBLE, LUCINDA and LEMIRA.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: MADAM we have enquired of many sensible persons, how a woman may be acceptable to the other sex—She that is too fond of them, in the first instance, sails, and she that is too shy—We should wish for your opinion on just conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Sen.
SP.P: I do not imagine myself qualified to decide such important questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: O madam, you, if any person can.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: You are the only person in the world; teach me how I may be agreeable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen.
SP.P:
I am not a professor of gallantry—But all the arts which I believe to be necessary, are comprehended with∣in a very small compass. Young ladies should have honest
hearts, virtuous principles, and should be educated to decent manners, before they see much company of young gentle∣men. These being granted they need not affect, any extra∣ordinary character. They will please most by avoiding all affectation, and appearing just what they are—They are best to appear what nature, illustrated by a good education, has made them—They who are never rude in their behav∣ior, will seldom be treated with rudeness—women may even be grateful to men, for their generous attentions, if they converse with them sensibly, and with proper, and de∣cent manners—And if men will not converse in this man∣ner, there is no need of quarrelling with them, or offering them any personal abuse. The severest and most effectual punistment, is to leave them to their own society—These are not artifices, but comprehend the simple, just conduct, of a virtuous woman—I would not have any woman affect the extremes of behavior—the medium in my opinion is the safest, because it is the rightest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lem.
SP.P: Madam we thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: WELL, there never was such a wretched author, I believe, as he who wrote this Dialogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: Why the sentiment is bro't to a point and yet there is no change of fortune or sign of a catastrophe in the piece—It ends with a tame moral sentiment—good enough 'tis true but no remarkable event to set it off I am worried prodigiously. I am afraid I shall never make it take. Pray were is the author of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pale.
SP.P: WHAT is your will gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: Only see, what a piece of work you have made— here my scholars you see are all at a stand—cannot move on with the Drama. You have bro't them into the most shocking hobble—I expect we shall be obliged to break off short; and go off the stage with lopt ears—for there is not a sign of a catastrophe to the piece—what put it into your head to leave the Drama without a catastrope?

SP.SPEAKER: Pale.
SP.P: Why, suppose you had played it off without a ca∣tastrophe, what ill consequence would have come of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: Why the critic would maul it unmercifully.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: The people would clamour against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Think
SP.P: The democrats will say, it was done on pur∣pose to introduce monarchy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: The aristocrats, will say 'twas meant against the Federal government.

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: It will get to the university, and the scholars will declaim against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: The Government will rusticate it.

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: The metaphysicians will say you are non compo.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: The astronomers will say you are excentric.

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: The lawyers will say you ought to be nonsuited.

SP.SPEAKER: Dom.
SP.P: The physicians will detest it as a pestilence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pale.
SP.P: That's a mistake, pestilence is all in their favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Think.
SP.P: The Clergy —

SP.SPEAKER: Pale.
SP.P: Hold sir you shan't say a word about the clergy; they have reproaches enough from other quarters. But here you blame me unmercifully. What? do you think all subjects can be treated exactly alike—There is Dr. Burgo, who is as great a critic as any—I'll leave it to him, if you dare; to say, whether I have done right or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Pale.
SP.P: SIR I am most unmercifully accused by these peo∣ple for not giving this Drama a regular catastrophe—The subject sir, is whether Prudery or Forwardness be most prejudicial to women—I wish you to inform me, whether this subject be capable of a regular conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Burgo.
SP.P: Ladies and Gentlemen. It is my opinion that this author is excusable—Solomon himself could not de∣sire acceptability in love matters—All that we can say, is, that all affectation, and extremes of character, ought to be avoided. But which is the most pernicious to women, that which is called Forwardness or Prudery— will forever remain an Insolvable Question. Between these two large extremes—there is a wide field for the exercise of discre∣tion— So pardon neighbor Paleface, let him give his hand to which lady he pleases, and lead off the stage.

DIV1.HEAD: The Match Dissolved. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE MEANNESS OF FORTUNE HUNTING.
DIV1.P: THERE can be no greater instance of insincerity; than to pretend love for the sake of getting money. Consequently there is no character among men, more properly the object of contempt, than a for∣tune hunter. Disproportionate matches, in point of estate, bring insult on the part of the monied party; contempt and disgust on the other—And why should not the woman be contemptible too, who sets her cap at a man of fortune, when once she has learned to write her name, and is able to buy her a silk gown?

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: AUNT GRISSEL—an old maid, sister to Mrs. Hon∣eycomb.
LEVINA—a friend and confident of Maria.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: MY dearest wife, the condition of our mar∣riage has been extremely pleasing to me; tho it is not wholly without its cares—I believe there is no perfectly unmixed happiness in this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: I have often told you so, and there are troubles now I find—cheese and butter are likely to be very dear, and we have not laid in our winer's stock of pickles.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: That is a matter of very small consequence—but the young man whom we hired to teach our Maria music, is paying his addresses to her most sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: A blockhead, a little impudent coxcomb. He court our Maria! 'Tis impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: You will find it but too true, I am afraid her af∣fections are so engaged to him, that I never shall be able to disengage her▪

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Do punish him well, husband; I'd be revenged on him, I would break his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: What, break his back for being fond of an agreea∣ble girl—My own back on that principle would have been broken before this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: But I can't bear it, that such a fop as he should have our Maria.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: I will prevent it, if possible, without breaking his back, or his head; but I am very much afraid that the af∣fair is past remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: This comes of her learning music.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Let us not have any words, my dear, on that matter—you was as fond of her learning music as I, but we were both much to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Why I have always told her she must not pretend to like any of the young fellows without my leave; and I have never given her any leave about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Girls do not always wait for their mothers leave in those matters. But we were more to blame than she, to hire him into the house and let him have access to her at all hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: But girls need not throw themselves away neither, if their parents do give them liberties.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: It is possible they may be affected with kind, and tender attentions as well as men. I have no disposition to quarrel with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: I'd quarrel with him then, and I say again, if I could not make him leave her otherwise, I'd break his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: It is my serious opinion that the parents who take a gay young man into the family as an instructor to their daughters, are more to blame than their daughters, if con∣sequences should not be agreeable—But I shall use my best endeavor, to remove the evil, and in the easiest man∣ner possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: GRISSEL, do you know any thing of any pe∣culiar friendship between our Maria, and Mr. Semibreve?

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: There is, so far as I can guess, every sign, that she is fond of him. I said nothing about it because you often blame me, for intermeddling in the affairs of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: But when you saw any thing likely to take place, which must hurt the family extremely, you ought to men∣tion it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: How should I know how it would turn? perhaps you would have said, in one minute, that I meddled, be∣cause I was envious; and the whole family would have pointed at me because I was the old maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Hem! we may have carried that matter too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P:
I find married people in general have a dsgust against old maids. But why should they be treated as the worst of criminals. You never would have married a man,
who was disagreeable to you — would you? (To Tartana.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Most certainly I would not, I should rather have died.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: So I think, and tho you urged me so much to mar∣ry Mr. Landworth; he was so disagreeable to me; that I am persuaded, if I had married him, I should have died within three months.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Then I don't know why you should be blamed— but have you never advised Maria better?

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
