SP.P: Yes, but she never would take any notice of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Then I wish you would talk with her again—and school her well.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: Why would you not do it yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: Because I am apt to get into a passion, and if I should, and abuse her, I should be sorry for it afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: Well now, since I know you will approve of it—I will talk with her upon the subject—and I shall give it to her well—I wish to punish her—I shall do it with a good∣will—because she is often vexing me about being an old maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: WELL, Miss, where's your Butterfly? Shall we not expect him flttering about here to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: If you wan't him for your amusement—perhaps he may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: Want him for my amusement! I care not for him the value of his own fiddlestick; and I wonder you can be fond of such a coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: A coxcomb do you call him? Truly he is fond of ornament, which shows him to be a neat, and cleanly man; and attentive to our sex—and you know that kind of at∣tention, is agreeable to all women.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: I wish to know whether you expect to live upon love, and music; without any solid estate? Fa, sol, la, twe∣dle dum and twedle-dee, must be poor consolations in an empty house and starving family.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So you must deal in your dismals. That's always the way with a woman, when she's fit for nothing else.— But I dare say, he'll provide for every thing that is neces∣sary.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: Let him pretend what he will, he never should trouble me with his addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He would not, I am confident for they would be to you the greatest consolation imaginable▪

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: I'd settle the matter quick. He should not court me long.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I suppose not, for you would comply so easily, and promptly; that there would be no occasion for a long court∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: No he should not so much as darken my doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No for his presence in your fancy would be much brighter than the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris
SP.P: You know, you saucy, impudent creature, what I mean, well enough. I mean, that I would not let him come after me at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, for you would meet him more than half way— and follow him to the ends of the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: You are so saucy, there is no bearing with you: and were it not that it is a shame for ladies to quarrel; I would give you a good thumping, that I would.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: MY friend, I cannot think it safe to trust to a future maintenance, unless he is engaged in some business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: It has often given me the most serious concern— for I perceive that I cannot resign him without pain—yet I have had many serious hours of reflection, if he does not apply himself to any steady business how we shall be able to live in any credit, or reputation—and indeed, how we shall be able to live at all—for my fortune is not so great as to last forever, without any further income.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: How strange we young folks manage between our∣selves. The idleness of a young man, who is agreeable, always gives us great pain—yet we treat them as if it were well that they were always idle—by affecting to be above the laborious employments of life ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
And the young gentlemen have the same absurd∣ity in their treatment, of us. They expect every thing of us, of delicacy and propriety of conduct. And yet often
behave towards us, as if they would have us be the reverse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: That is very true. But in both cases reason should bear rule, in spite of custom. And, were I in your case— I certainly, before I bro't myself into any engagement—I would know whether he meant to follow any serious busi∣ness—for the mere profession of music, will never support any person with reputation; unless it brings more profit, than it does among us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am of your opinion, and shall have the discre∣tion to see to that point myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: And, (I must leave you for a moment) I would not pass over that matter slightily. (Exit Levina.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: MARIA, my dear delight, happy, and cheerful, I hope as you always are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You would make me happy were it in the power of complaisance to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Complaisance, my dear Maria! Is the affection of my heart no more than complaisance? Is the most re∣fined, most intense and exalted passion, no more than com∣plaisance? My sweet angel, you undervalue the heart, which is devoted to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I should be happy to find all your assertions true. But you know, that by listening to your addresses, I have affronted my relations. And it is necessary for us, to have something to live upon, in case they should not be kind to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Depend on it, my divine Maria, depend on it, that I shall see to that, I shall live nobly with you, Maria, depend on it, we shall be happy as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Women, you may say, are apt to be more anx∣ious than men; but I must own that I fear the profession of music will not maintain us. I could wish that you would engage in some other business.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: All in due time, my sweet girl, depend on it, if I marry you, I will maintain you well, and leave no scheme or business untried, that I may gain a happy living.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, sir, I wish you will bear it in mind, for it has really given me uneasiness. For I am sensible of your merit, tho I cannot see how you will establish a living.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: All in good time, never fear me my sweet girl▪ you shall find me a man of the strictest honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: WHAT does he say? will he do as you wish to have him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He promises fair and upon the strictest honor what other assurances can I have from him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: Nothing; unless he actually engage in business— but if he promises upon honor, he must be a perfect villain if he breaks his word.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: I can have no firmer ground of truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: True; but I would not be married to him, till he was settled in some good business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I do not intend it, but it will come to much the same thing—I must promise in order to secure him—and if I promise I shall marry him at all events.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: Heaven direct my good girl, I know not what to advise you to.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: WHY my dear girl should you appear to avoid me? I wish to converse with you, on a subject interesting to both of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: If I were sure, I had nothing of severity to fear; you would see no disposition in me to avoid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Severity, my girl, you have no severity to expect. What made you think of it? I wish, however, to enquire in a manner, the least disagreeable to you, if Mr. Semi∣breve has any prospect of settling in any permanent busi∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I cannot say positively; but I believe he intends it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: This business, in teaching music, will hardly be suf∣ficient for the maintenance of a family.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I suppose it cannot be, but I believe him to be a man of the strictest honor. He says he means to go into busi∣ness soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P:
Have you no apprehension, Maria, that he is one of those idle fellows that cheat girls, who only pretend, to have a regard for you, that he may be maintained in
idleness and dissipation? —he perhaps imagine u have a fortue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He is always very decent in his conduct to me, and certainly pretends to be very sincere; whatever his re∣al views may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: And you have no suspicions of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Not in the least. I believe him to be a man of the strictest honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: If you believe him to be such a man; then you will have no objection to my bringing him to the test; and it will only set his virtues in the strongest ight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I would not wish any thing rude, or uncivil to be offered to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: No, that is my nature; I will only converse with him concerning you and let him talk as he pleases — You know that fr our parlor to my study, every word which one speaks in the common pitch of conversation, may be heard distinctly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And what, sir, would you propose?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: That you take your place in my study, while I converse with him, and hear our conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That I will do most willingly; for I am not in the least apprehensive, that I shall hear any thing; but that which is most agreeable, and which will tend to make you and me respect him more than we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: You will be ready when he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tar.
SP.P: HUSBAND, I am out of my wits about Maria— I have been thinking of it, and the more I think, the more I am uneasy. I shall go crazy, if there be not something done about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.P: I talked with the little jade about it today; and she was so saucy, I could hardly keep my hands from her. I never had so good an appetite to my dinner, as I had to give her a beating.

SP.SPEAKER: Tar
SP.P: If she would not give him up, I'd turn her out of doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: That is, to save her, we must destroy her at once— Shall we ruin her, because her affection mortifies us? That's acting on a selfish motive.

SP.SPEAKER: Tar.
SP.P: That's just like you, you never can resent any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Never mind it, my wife. If I do not gro mis∣take, they'll settle the matter between themselves yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: MR. SEMIBREVE, it has been represented to me; that you have sought an alliance with our family.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: That is, as things may prove to be. I believe Mar∣ia has a regard for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: I suspect that she has, and truly, I believe you have taken some pains to gain her affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: It always was my fortune, by some means, or other, to attract the notice of the ladies. I hope they don't blame me for the manner in which they are affected, when they see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Perhaps not, but if you be in pursuit of Maria, or you seem rather to insinuate, she is in pursuit of you; the effect comes to the same thing. You must have a maintainance, in order to live comfortably together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: There is no doubt of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Well, it becomes an interesting matter to me; do you intend to pursue any steady business for the purpose of supporting yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Sir, I mean to live like a gentleman—I teach music occasionally—As for our maintenance, in case I marry your daughter, I suppose you will give her enough to maintain us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: If she marries agreeably to my mind I shall do my best for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: You can give her a hansome estate, and permit me to say, sir, you ought to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Sir, I hope you do not mean to dispose of my es∣tate, till you have it in your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: No—but as I know the hold I have on Maria's af∣fections—I mean to have something handsome with her, if I take her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Well sir, I suppose I could give her as much as eight hundred pounds— you know I have many children.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P:
Eight hundred pounds, sir, I shall not accept.—I
know, you can afford to give more—I have no mind to marry without the means of living genteelly.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: You do not however promise to make the best kind of a son in law; but as I mean to treat my daughter kindly— and I believe she respects you—I will make an effort to give her twelve hundred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: I know the hold I have on Maria's affections—you will not wish to destroy your daughter's happiness—I shall not accept of twelve hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: I will give you fifteen hundred, rather than hurt my daughter, in the feelings of her heart—I have a great aversion to crossing children in their love— I am confident that Maria will prove a very kind and industrious wife— and with her I will give you fifteen hundred pounds; which is as much as I can give.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: No sir, I thank you. I shall not accept of any thing less than two thousand pounds—which is as little as I can think of taking, and be saddled with a wife—tho I believe with a little tutoring, she might be a tolerable fam∣ily piece—tho not a fine woman, by any means.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: What if I tell her what you say of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: She never would believe it. She would credit one word of mine more than a thousand of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: I shall never give you two thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: You are not sure of that; you will be glad to come to my terms yet. If you do not, you may depend on los∣ing your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: MY dear Maria▪ your humble servant seems to be a hard man to deal with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Dear sir, give yourself no more trouble about him, I detest the coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Will you admit the addresses of Mr. Plaintruth, who has long cherished a kind regard for you? I recom∣mend him to you, my girl, as a person of approved worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Dear sir, I have been foolish long enough in fol∣lowing my own inclination—I will be governed by your advice. [Enter Tartana]

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.P: Well wife, Maria has given him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Tart.
SP.P: You are the strangest man that over was; you will make all women folks do just as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: MY divine Maria—I shall make the old gentleman deal out freely to us yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, perhaps I may marry you yet, if any body will give me two thousand pounds. But I would not for fifteen hundred pounds, tho you might make her with a lit∣tle tutoring a tolerable family piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Ha! it seems you have overheard me. I have often heard that people always get paid for listening.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, I am well paid for it. I shall get rid of an insufferable coxcomb—I shall never forgive myself the weakness of having been attached to him. Sir, instead of giving me any more of your fulsome flattery; get out of the house, and if you ever come into it again you shall meet with proper correction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Oh! blast my ill luck, she is certainly angry, and my game is up. What a fool I was that I did not accept the fifteen hundred pounds.

DIV1.HEAD: The Spring for Flowers. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
YOUTH IS THE SEASON FOR LOVE AND MAR∣RIAGE.
DIV1.P: Few of human follies have less excuse to plead, than the neglect of marriage in youth—and the conse∣quent anxiety for it, in later life. A quick sensi∣bility, strength, activity, ambition and power of sustaining family cares—ability to govern and edu∣cate children—with freedom from uncouth habits; and full propension to love; all invite to early marriages. Cold prudence is all the virtue peculiar to later life; and it is generally left without the assistance of the other virtues.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. ALLWORTHY—a gentlemen of excelent moral.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MISS HAWTHORNE—a single lady of thirty six.
MISS FORESIGHT—a cunning maiden of twenty eight.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: MADAM, every thing in life may be trans∣acted accrding to rule and reason; I have a desire to invite you to the state of mariage, and see here, I have stated my proposals on this paper; that you may consider them at your lesure.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Sir I shall consider them; it would be rude not to do it, considering your reputable character. But I can∣not speedily come to a conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: Take what time you think proper, if you will on∣ly give them due consideration. I shall perhaps see you again in an hour or two. But will not insist on a hasty determination,—take what time you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: NOW from my soul I wish he had less reason, then I could suppose he had more love—He is as cool in his courtship as if he were casting up a column of figures— He is a worthy man, but after all not at all to my taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Why, Madam you really appear melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I am so—I find I have left my morning's work to do in the afternoon, I am vexed with myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: I do not comprehend your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P:
The truth is, when I was young, from twenty to thirty, I had a number of very good offers for marriage, but full of the love of liberty & dissipation, I declined them,
and now, to conceal nothing from you—I am heartily sor∣ry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Many a woman I suppose has committed the same error—But for Heaven's sake don't get into the dumps, your prospects are good yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Why, I am ready to look upon myself as a poor, forsaken creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Poh! There's Mr. Goodfort, is as fond of you, as he can be of any woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: An odd piece of furniture truely.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Matter, I am afraid he is all matter and no spir∣it— His courtship it as methodical as a book of accounts— He comes just so often, stays just so long, talks just so, and just so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: He is an exact gentleman, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Exact! All system, method and order; I do not love to be measured by the square and compass.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: He is a very virtuous man.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Yes, I esteem him, and yet after all I don't like him—He makes love by calculation,—besides he is eight years older than I.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: He must be old then, with an emphasis.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: You saucy—I was going to call names, but to own the truth I am on the wrong side of thirty five—But he is eight years older than I.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Has he not made his proposals?

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Yes, he has made them, on paper as you live; and as formal as any bond or deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: You had better comply with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I mean to, unless I have those which are more pleasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: From whom have you any prospect of those which are more agreeable?

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I have had some visits from that elegant pink of all courtesy, Mr. Allworthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Your hopes are delusive.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw
SP.P: He is very complaisant to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: He says openly, he only respects your good sense, and hopes to profit by your experience.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Experience! a saucy fellow. Experience is the result of age—Yet tho he is saucy, he is complaisant and young.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Too young I should suppose, he is eight years younger than you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I do not think that any reasonable objection.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: I suppose not—But he is very much engaged with Miss Emily Howard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: There is an easy remedy for that; I could fright her out of that fancy in five minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: I am not so certain of that—Those modest girls, when they once get engaged, are commonly engaged to purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I can easily fright her out of the project. She is afraid of her own shadow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: She may be afraid of a shadow, and have no ob∣jection to the substance.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: O I can manage the matter with her. There is Mrs. Easy,—She had a most wretched husband, and if she were to talk with Emily about the men, she would half fright her to death in ten minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fore.
SP.P: Much I doubt that. But I have no objection to your trying the experiment. [Exit Foresight]

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: DO tell me Emily, what is that which worries your mind so, and makes you so pensive?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Pray be not so teazing; I would not tell my own mother of such a subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Then there is a subject —you shall tell it me, Emily.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You would only say that I was a foolish girl; and that would mortify me extremely.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Phaw! Emily—you don't lessen my curiosity at all; you know I am a good friend to you, Emily; you own auht too; you shall tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I am loth to give you pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: You give me the more pain by this management —My curiosity puts me on the rack—Tell me, or I shall not enjoy a moment's peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I have a right to kep some things to myself, and I will not tell you—your servant madam. [Exit Emily.]

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P:
(alone) She is cunning▪ and les right for herself; but there is one way which never surprise dicate minds: it is almost too wicked. It is to put them on the
rack, in fears for their honor. Emily deserves this punish∣ment for thinking to outwit my old head. I will accuse her and set her to justifying herself. [Emily enters.] Emily, my dear, excuse me if I detain you one moment. You, I understand, have had a quarrel in your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: That's a total mistake; I have the full confidence of my parents, and the happiest harmony with my broth∣ers and sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Then Miss Fidget was wrong; but Miss Coaxer might be in the right, in saying that you became melan∣choly in consequence of being neglected by the young gen∣tlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I have dismissed three within a month, and I have one now.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: There it is; they are right; you carry on a clan∣destine correspondence with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Nobody who knows me would suspect me of such a thing. Mr. Allworhy never visited me once, but with the approbation of my parents.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: They like him then.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: They treat him respectfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Then the reason must be, that he is not so atten∣tive as—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: More attentive than I desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Then he's a perfect libertine, is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You astonish me—What did I say, which should lead you to that? He is a man of most excellent morals.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Now, you fancy girl, I have got the secret out of you—Mr. Allworthy is very attentive to you, and that grieves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You have been successful—I see you have not lost your faculty to do mischef.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Mr. Allworhy then addresses you—and you are all in fear lest you should lose him.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Not in the least, my fears are all the other way, lest I should be persuaded to detain him.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Aye, there you are right—this marrying is a dan∣gerous affair—By saying yes, a woman may ruin herself forever. Never think of marrying, Emily—Never make yourself miserable for any man. Mrs. Easy will soon be here, and she will tell you all about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: MRS. Easy, I wait on you at the request of Miss Hawthorne, desiring that you would attend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Eas.
SP.P: What does she wish of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Good
SP.P: She says that she desires you would tell Emily all that is bad about marriage, and terrify her so, that she may not venture herself into that state—She says that she is afraid Emily is about to engage in a very improper match.

SP.SPEAKER: Eas.
SP.P: I can tell her all the bad which I know of it—But if she will not be terrified, I cannot help that—Do you know what Miss Hawthorne means by this?

SP.SPEAKER: Good.
SP.P: I do not; but simply to express her desires to you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Miss HAZARD and Mrs. EASY.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: THAT poor old pigeon Miss Hawthorne has com∣missioned me, to fright Emily Howard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: And I am to make a suit of clothes for her; to en∣able her to catch Mr. Allworthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: She may as well try to catch all the larks that wing the air—I can tell her madam ship, that 'tis not for such old croakers as she, to match with the fine young gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Somehow, I always feel a disposition to plague old maids, tho I expect to be one myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Tho I never was one myself; nor ever wished to be—I think them excusable when they could not be mar∣ried reputably.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: But Miss Hawthorne's celibacy is her own fault she owns, and by her own confession, she is proper prize for ridicule.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—HAWTHORNE, HAZARD and Mrs. EASY

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: HAVE you finished my clothes?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: No, I forgot to ask you the fashion of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: The newest fashion—such as Miss Sprightly's.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: That is almost in the fashion of a young Miss▪ clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I would not have you think I am so terribly old neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Why you look very fresh and fair for a woman of your years.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Of my years you creature you; what do you mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Have you forgot how you wished me to tell your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: No Madam, no—I have kept my tea cup, prepar∣ed in due order for you to see.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: It ought to have been a cup, taken in the morning fasting—the lady who is to have her fortune told, should only drink one cup in the morning and eat nothing with it —nor taste any food till four in the afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I have prepared it accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Let me see it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: Pray look out and see if any body be coming in— I should be very much ashamed to be caught in telling for∣tunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Well this is odd. (Looking attentively in the cup.) Here's a man who intends to have you. He is about forty four—a very methodical man. He is serious—and will have you. But here's a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: It is a letter, as plain as it can be.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: This is from a man about twenty six or twenty eight—His name begins with an A.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: (Looking sly.) Well what do you think of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: He does not seem to be quite so fond of you as the other—See he has a lady of his heart—See here—her name begins with E.— I suspect 'tis Emily Howard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: (Strikes the cup from her hand.) A fiddlestick. It is the silliest thing in the world to tell fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: What I told you madam is true—I am sorry it has put you out of humor, and I wish you good night.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—EMILY, Mrs. EASY and Miss HAWTHORNE.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: MRS. Easy, I am very happy to pay my respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Hey! my young lady—so compliasant to an old creature such as I—I thank you Emily.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: This young lady is troubled in her mind — some people say she is on the point of being married. Has she not reason to be afraid? Is not that a very dangerous, and a very important affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes, yes, somewhat dangerous and quite import∣ant. But a woman can manage her husband well enough, if she knows how.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Will you excuse me. Mrs. Easy!—I never wish to take one step in life but upon sure grounds. Was you happy in your marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes, my dear girl—I frankly answer yes. Other persons complained of my husband—but to me he was truly a kind man—Yes Emily I can say truly, that I was happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I suppose you are always happy in whatever situa∣tion you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Few men are so bad, as not to be good in some respects—Yes, I was happy my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Did your husband ever put on high airs of author∣ity?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Did he ever talk with passion, and be saucy to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Was he ever cross and ill humored?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Was he ever in a passion with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Did he ever leave you, to go into company abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Was he ever suspicious of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Was you ever afraid that he might leave you to distress and want?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Had he a great many faults then?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: And could you be happy with such a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: O admiration. Had I such a husband I must die out-right—Do you not think I should?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: This is quite beyond my comprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: I suppose it—but all men have their faults. If you cannot be happy with a man who has faults you can be happy with none.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Then it will be best for me to remain as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: You are a little simplicity, Emily. Tho my hus∣band had so many faults, and other people said he had more than ever I saw—Yet when he died I was very sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well, Mrs. Easy, will you tell me how one may manage with a husband who has faults? How shall a wo∣man make her husband treat her with respect?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy
SP.P: By never giving him any reason to despise her.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How shall she prevent his leaving her to want and distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: By not wantonly spending his estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How prevent his being cross and ill humored.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Set him an example of good humor and pleasant∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Em
SP.P: If he goes much into company abroad —

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: She must cure him by making him happiest at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: What if he be liable to sudden passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: Let him alone till his passion is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How shall she prevent his being suspicious of her.?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: By telling him every thing he wants to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: How shall she prevent his withdrawing his confi∣dence from her?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: By always telling him exact truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: If he has many faults and she cannot but know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Easy.
SP.P: She should count her own, and see if she has not more than he.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: You are a strange woman, Mrs. Easy. The women must all come to you to learn the matrimonial catechism—but all this will do me no good.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P:
Alone COULD Mrs. Easy be happy with such a
husband as she had. And I not be able to find a blessing with such a man as Mr. Allworthy—I'll let him know my sentiments are altered and be will fly to me like a bird.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Miss Emily, I must know my definitive sentence— suspence is so uncomfortable to me that I shall not long be able to endure it.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I must then accept your offers, on this supposition— that we both have many faults, and each must learn to bear with them.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: The best footing in the world in point of prudence —but my affection will not let me anticipate them on your part.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well am willing to contrive to be happy with as few faults as possible on either side.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Neither is that condition disagreeable—I believe we had better say nothing more against concord, and harmo∣ny, but let them take place between us if they will.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I shall not try to banish them.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: WELL I may now resign myself to despair, un∣less you will give up your pretentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Em
SP.P: A good friend is a treasure worth keeping. I have no tho'ts of parting with such a blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: SHALL we set on a supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I am perfectly indifferent about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy
SP.P: The ladies will want it; and they all will collect here in a few moments.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: You may do what you please—I feel very disa∣greeably.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Madam, you are disappointed and cannot conceal it—but I would take the methodical gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: I shall, but to marry when one is not perfectly satisfied with it, is not the thing—But one must do it, when they can do nothing better—I wish I had not been such a fool when I was young.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—HAWTHORNE, and EMILY, and all the ladies present.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: LADIES you are welcome; but pray do not ex∣pect me to be very cheerful.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My aunt, I hope will not blame me, for not resign∣ing the best part of my fortune to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Haw.
SP.P: No ladies— I blame none of you: I have no one to blame but myself. But let me, like all other criminals, caution you not to do as I have done, youth is the season of beauty, and of attention from the men — and I believe if a woman cannot suit herself with a partner then—there is very little prospect that she ever will.

DIV3.STAGE: [Exit Hawthorne, and after her all the ladies.]

DIV1.HEAD: The Discontented Wife. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE QUARRELS OF MARRIED PERSONS ARE GENERALLY FRIVOLOUS.
DIV1.P: IT is generally very idle for people in the vicinity, to interpose in the quarrels of married persons. Marriage obliges, and almost necessitates, a man and his wife, to be of a mind, in things of great consequence—Their quarrels arise from some tri∣fles: a mere momentary humor, or accidental word, and counter passions, have more influence in re∣conciling them, than their reason. Hence this important moral arises; that married persons never make complaints of each other abroad, and that their neighbors interpose in none of their differences—lest work be made for repentance.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: COL. FORTINBRASS—officer of the United States army, married in N. York.
MR. WILLIAMSON—a wealthy citizen and good husband.
MR. LEWISTON—a neighbor, friend to Mrs. Fortinbrass.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MRS. LYMAN—wife of a reputable citizen, friend of Mrs. Fortinbrass.
MRS. DELANO—formerly rival of Mrs. Fortinbrass.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mrs. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: O MY dear Mrs Fortinbrass, I am glad to meet you here—I am going to Philadelphia, and wished to see Mrs. Lyman before I went. But I am so happy as to see you here! I hope you and the Col en∣joy good health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Not very good, indeed I get very little rest anights—The Col. at present is from home—But how sweetly you look, what bright eyes, what rosy cheeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Will.
SP.P: Thanks to that Great Being who gives health and cheerfulness, I enjoy both in a great degree—The peace and satisfaction of my mind have done me more good than medicine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: And how sweetly dressed too: where did you get this delightful gown?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: My husband gave it me, it was his own choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Your husband gave it to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: Yes. I hope you do not think that I would have accepted it from any other man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Then your husband is good to you—Is he indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: I am almost angry with you—What a question! But I pardon you; for many have prophesied that I should be unhappy in my marriage—But what thanks do I owe to Heaven for my husband, whose kind∣ness and virtues exceed my most romantic expectations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Well, I believe you are one of the happy few—I am sick of marriage—only see how I look—this ordinary gown—But this is nothing could I enjoy peace at home—I had better been laid in my grave, than to have married Col. Fortinbrass.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: Mrs. Fortinbrass, I am surprised. You unhappy—and with Col. Fortinbrass too—so fine a person, so elegant in his dress and manners—Fifty girls in this ci∣ty were ready to die with envy when you married him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Could I▪ part with him now, they might have him very cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: But you surprise me, my dear friend—What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Matter enough, I think; he holds his sol∣dier frolics abroad, despises my company at home, gets me no new cloaths. When I reprove him, he will either look as surly as a bear, or get his old flax stringed fiddle and play a tune to my reproof.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: That vexes you I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: It does mortally, I have tho't a number of times that I should have died with vexation—But I could only retire, and weep in floods of tears—But hush, he is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Will.
SP.P: I withdraw a moment to talk with Mrs. Ly∣man. But will see you again in half an hour.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Col. FORTINBRASS.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Well sir, you got home very early last night. It was but one of the clock in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: I hoped, madam, to have met with a kind re∣ception from you. I do not think it was very late.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: But I know it was late—and it was a pretty fancy indeed, if one must marry and expect to find a friend in a husband, and have him leave one in utter contempt, and tarry out late.

DIV3.STAGE: [The Colonel takes up an old fiddle and plays.]

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum tum diddle de dum dum dum.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You pretend to have your soldier frolics— who knows what you are about when you are abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum dum, &c. (plays)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: No woman of spirit can bear such treatment, I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum dum diddle, &c. (plays)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You have not bought me a new gown this twelve month.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum dum, &c. (continues playing)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I won't bear this treatment—It is intolera∣ble.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum dum diddle, &c. (still continues)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: If ever there was a woman so abused by her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Tum dum diddle.

DIV3.STAGE: [He pursues her with his music till she is off the stage.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Fort.
SP.P: O MY dear Mrs. Lyman, I am undone— Never was any person so abused by her husband. I shall die— I shall die.

SP.SPEAKER: Lym.
SP.P: Fye, fye Mrs. Fortinbrass—do not disgrace your∣self and disgrace your husband, by these quarrels—but find means to make yourself and your husband easy. These proceedings are very dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I cannot bear it; I must give him my mind, if I die for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lym.
SP.P: You may do it and see what you will get by it—but I will not stay to hear you. [Exit Mrs. Lyman.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—COL. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. FORTINBRASS

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: WELL madam it is really a fine morning to∣day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: So it seems by your music—you are quite in∣spired it seems by the season.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: I love to sing when I feel cheerful—I have very fine success in fowling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I saw you have a large bunch of birds strung up by their bills—I wonder how you came to kill so many starlings. They are a lean kind of birds, and of little, or no use.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: No not starlings, child. They are thrushes my dear delicious as marrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Do you think me such a fool that I do not know a thrush from a starling.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: And do you think me such a sot that I don't know a starling, from a thrush?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You staid out very late, last night. Your eyes, and senses too, might be a little hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: What an impudent woman you are, to talk thus to your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: What an insolent coxcomb you are to treat a woman of spirit, and good family, in this manner.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: (Extremely agitated.) O torment! why did I marry? Can I bear such impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Yes, you insolent Dutchman—to behave with no more complaisance to a woman of spirit and good family. You are not fit for human society—Go abroad among the brutes. If you cannot behave yourself with more propriety, get out of this house, this instant, and as fast as you can. [The Colonel approaches slowly to the door, turne and speaks to his wife—looking dejected the whole time.]

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: Sylvia farewell—I have long borne with some ill qualities in you, on account of some others, which I ad∣mired and loved; but this last stroke is intolerable—Farewell Sylvia, I shall see you no more. Yet remember this house was mine—you have it but by marrying me—And now you order me from it. It is very well—I will go. And you shall have it to yourself.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mrs. FOTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN (enter∣ing here.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: O MY friend, I am the most miserable of women.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: What did your husband do, when you order∣ed him out of the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: He went softly away—and I said nothing. It has been three weeks that we have been much out of hu∣mour with each other. Now he has bid me a solemn farewell. O I am the most miserable of women! Why was I such a fool as to marry!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Well, and I cannot but think that you are partly to blame too—I have no desire to exculpate the col∣onel—why should you bluntly contradict him? That is unpolite to any body. Why insult him with his being a Dutchman▪ National reflections always wound deep. You knew that before you married him—and to order him out of a house which you acquired by marrying with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: If I have been to blame, I have been to blame. But I will ask your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lym.
SP.P: Well madam, I advise you to send a polite mes∣sage to the Colonel, and invite him to come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: So give up my will, and let him gain his point, a grand lesson for a lady of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Then get some friend to mention it to him, so as to save your pride in the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort
SP.P: After all, it will be a kind of submission, and that is a word which of all words I hate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: It is simply a compliance, and I trust you know what compliance is—when you trusted your life, your property, your honor, your happiness with your hus∣band, nay your very soul—did you think after that, that you must be ceremonious?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: But in that case there was no impropriety.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Neither is there here. Maids are bound to ceremony. But a married woman may do whatever she pleases, for the happiness of herself and her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You will not easily pursuade me to give up my will, and resentments, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: What then do you mean to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: To sue for a divorce, or seperate maintenance at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: You may intend to have your own way; but I do not mean to give you up so—there is my good friend Mr. Williamson, he says his heart has bled for you, when he knew the dissensions between you, and your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: If that be true it is more then I have done for myself, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Fortinbrass, say not that again, if you be insensible to the better affections of the heart, I shall despair of you entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You, or any one, may say then just what you please.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mr. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: LADIES, I respect you all most sincerely; but I mean to pay my attention particularly to Mrs. Fortinbrass.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Just as you please, Mr. Williamson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: I mean in regard of your affair with Col. Fort∣inbrass—I will not mortify you afresh by telling the sad story, but if I can be of any service to you by healing the unhappy wound, and restoring happiness, I shall greatly rejoice—will you be so kind as to tell me what your inten∣tions are?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: To sue for a divorce or a separate mainten∣ance at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Let me then ask you if you have not unnat∣ural relations who hate you, and rivals who owe you a mortal grudge, and indeed enemies of various kinds?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Yes, perhaps a hundred, who would rejoice to hear of my death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Consider then what you are about to do—will it not be the greatest gratification to your enemies, to see you abject, and miserable, worse than a widow, forsaken of all reputable company, and an object of general con∣tempt—how will your rivals exult over you? Would you do what would gratify their malice?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort
SP.P: No, I would sooner confound them forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Here is one of them coming now.—She'll tor∣ment you, you had better go out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: No, let her come. I cannot be more miser∣able than I am.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mrs. DELAND, Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mr. WILLIAMSON.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del,
SP.P: LADIES most welcome all of you; and in particular Mrs. Fortinbrass. Well madam how do ye do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Indifferently madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: Rather indifferently I suppose. The Col. they say has forsaken you. Well, this is odd that after you took so much pains to have him, you should lose him so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I expect no mercy from you Mrs. Delano.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: I love to show mercy as well as other per∣sons, to those who are proper subjects of it. But that can hardly be said of you—were I to take into the account, all the scandalous reports, you spread concerning me —the letters you forged—had the Col. remained with me he might have been a worthy-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: You love him now, I know you do? tho you have another husband—well you may have him, and wel∣come.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: No, madam, I am better provided for, and I am afraid he has caught ill habits by acquaintance—you wounded me once, very severely, but I am now cured, and have lived to see justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Forbear, my good lady, forbear, tho your wrongs may have been great.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: What I said was not out of malice, but to bring this lady to a sense of her duty—I will not add af∣fliction to the afflicted; but just mention the matter and leave this lady to her own reflections.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—Mr. WILLIAMSON and Mrs. FORTINBRASS.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Now Mrs. Fortinbrass—should you love to gratify this woman too, who is animated with such keen resentment against you—please your enemies, mortify your friends; and make your husband unhappy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: He should have taken care of that himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: And what shall be done with your sweet lit∣tle—son—that little cherub who bears such a lively resem∣blance of the Colonel. When you shall hear him sob, and cry; as he undoubtedly will; because papa does not come home—how will you bear it; Can you endure to see him an orphan, or will you give him up for ever; to a parent against whom you cherish the most implacable resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: O my heart, my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: While you have been on ill terms, he has not absented himself for nothing. He has been assembling a regiment, and he is going to the western army.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: He may find himself happier there than here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P:
It may be, but the probability is that the In∣dians will take him; and torture —fill his flesh full of pine splinters, and set them on fire—o ery way to tor∣ment him with relentless cruelty—can you bear this in res∣pect
of him—who once was the dearest object of your love?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: It was his business to have guarded against that; as well as mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wil.
SP.P: Well if you cannot hear any thing you must be left to the consequences. But he told me he was going to the army in three weeks—His old soldiers have all enrolled themselves and the new ones admire him—The president of the states has made him a general.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort
SP.P: (Looking up.) That's odd that he should be made a general. (Her countenance alters from the expres∣sion of discontent to curiosity.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.—Mr. LEWISTON, Mrs. FORTINBRASS and Mrs. LYMAN.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Lew.
SP.P: O MRS. Fortinbrass, this is of all things most extraordinary—Col. Fortinbrass is come with his reg∣iment, and in his new uniform of a general. He resem∣bles with his noble airs, and fine person— the heroes des∣cribed in poets who were tho't to be like the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I think it is odd enough that he should be made a general—if he would come home now, and submit and ask pardon—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Lew.
SP.P: You would not wish for such humiliation in your husband, would you degrade the man whom you are to love? more than this, if he can find that you will see him; he will come to see you this very day—and if he can reconcile matters at home, he means to resign his commission; if not he means to march in three days.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Go you wretch, don't go to be obstinate now, you have better clothes than these; put them on—and look as handsome as you can—receive him genteelly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I never shall be able to bear him again—But I want to see how he looks, since he has been made a gen∣eral.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Go forward, and one of the ladies shall help you to dress yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I go ladies, to obey you; but it will all be in vain I can never endure him unless he will make a proper submission. [Snaps her handkerchief as she goes out.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Mr. LEWISTON and Mrs. WILLIAMSON

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. L.
SP.P: WHAT do you think the creature will do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: I cannot conjecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. L.
SP.P: Nor I; but this I know that persons who have been so long tender to each other, cannot part very easily.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: I believe that; and do you think that if mar∣ried persons should sometimes hurt each others feelings, that, therefore, they must necessarily be miserable?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. L.
SP.P: No, not by any means, persons of quick sensi∣bility, and who have not been used to curbing their pas∣sions in their youth—may live years together before they will be perfect in matrimonial wisdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil
SP.P: There is something in those things similar to what we find in other parts of nature—It is as natural for human beings occasionally to be agitated with passion—as that there should be unsettled weather in the months of April and May—Those sudden gusts which for awhile de∣form the beautiful face of nature, are commonly succeeded by the most serene and delightful weather.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. L.
SP.P: You talk very sensibly but I long to have them meet; and then see how the creatures behave. Let us step aside when the Colonel comes in.

O alas! never was a person in such confusion bafore — what a figure he makes at the head of his regiment—He looks divinely—But if I receive him—I give all up & shall be ashamed to resent his conduct in time to come— (Goes and looks out.) —But O! how divinely he looks—what shall I do? I am ashamed to think how much I may be disposed to receive him. (Looks out.) But I must bear the test. (Returns and walks agitated across the stage—Col. Fortinbrass enters—she almost falls on her knees before him—He catches her and raises her.)

SP.SPEAKER: C. Fort.
SP.P: No, my dear girl no—no humiliations to me— Stand with me upon equal and just footing—The first thing you are to do is to go, and see my regiment—and then we will find, if we have not reason still to respect each other. Tarry till I return. (To the company on the stage.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—Mrs. LYMAN and Mrs. WILLIAMSON.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: This exceeds all my acquaintance—I'll nev∣er believe a woman again, who pretends to be affronted with her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: How did she behave herself?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: She fretted all the time we were dressing her —and protested she would sue for a divorce, and what not. But she looked out at the window, and saw her hus∣band at the head of his regiment—I verily tho't she would have fainted away—and when she saw him come into her presence—she was going to throw herself at his feet—But he said—No humiliation, my dear girl—and led her out to see his soldiers. But before they got to the door, the tears gushed from their eyes—The old veteran who had stood so many battles melted to the softness of a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: You had no trouble then to reconcile them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: No, they reconciled one another very suc∣cessfully—we shall see her with a different face soon.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—Mrs. WILLIAMSON, Mrs. FORTINBRASS, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: You may spare your observation; for she is coming now. [Enter Mrs Fortinbrass.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Lym.
SP.P: Mrs. Fortinbrass, I hope affairs go very well on your part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: I thank you ladies—I am well at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: How is the Colonel? General I meant to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: In fine health and spirits, and gives the ladies his hearty respects.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: You seem much altered, madam, all at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Altered did you say? I know nothing of it, but that I am very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: But to be sick of marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P:
But to be sick of marriage. Who sick of marriage? Not I—I ever considered it as the capital bles∣sing of my life—when does your sister intend to be mar∣ried?
—I should suppose she might know her mind in six o seven years.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: She is in no haste, she has been terrified by your example.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: By my example, that's strange—you know I always respect matrimony. If that be an obstacle, tell her from me that I would have her think better of it, better— I say.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: But who said to-day, that she was sick of marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Not I surely—I should be ashamed to have said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Alltogether.
SP.P: Yes, yes, yes, you did this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Ladies you must excuse me; I have had ill turns of late, my head is dizzy sometimes, and I do not appear to myself to be perfectly in my right mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: So it seems that the return of an absent hus∣band, will put a lady into a right mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Yes; and right spirits too—ladies, I see you are determined to vex me, but I mean to turn, and defy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Del.
SP.P: Well, how does Mr. Fortinbrass look since he has been made a general?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: Excellently madam; I wish your husband could be mae a general for your sake—I dare say you would think him better for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Del.
SP.P: It seems too that you are more polite than when you was here before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fort.
SP.P: We ought always to be improving. And if I make such progress in half an hour, I shall soon be per∣fect.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.P: Shall we wish her joy, she has a husband now as well as we?

SP.SPEAKER: Gen. Fort.
SP.P:
Ladies I wish you all joy—my house is again a grateful home—you shall all sup with me this evening, and I will send for your husbands—let us devote the hours to rejoicing—I mean to annihilate the contest between me and my wife's relations about certain matters of property —& then I doubt not we shall live in peace—I shall bid abieu to the pursuit of wealth and the wars—and shall de∣vote
myself to that most rational and perfect of all enjoy∣ments, the felicity of domestic life.

DIV3.STAGE: [IF in this Dialogue the Scenes in which Fortinbrass appears, be left out—except the last; that being put into the mouth of Mrs. Fortinbrass, as a message to the ladies—and if Mr. Williamson's part be put to Mrs. Williamson, and Mr. Lewiston's part to Mrs. Lewiston, it will be fitted to young ladies]

DIV1.HEAD: The Father of a Family. A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
SOCIAL CONFIDENCE IS NECESSARY TO THE HAPPINESS OF FAMILIES.
DIV1.P: IT is very pernicious to families, when parents form designs which produce mistrust among their children —or children pursue schemes of their own, without the intelligence of their parents. It is common∣monly the case, that persons devoted to celibacy, know not the social principles of a family—and from that cause become troublesome inmates. Of maidens we say nothing accusatively —but if old bachelors say our charge is grievous, let them mar∣ry, and that will confute it—and let the maids all say—amen.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. ROBERTSON—the Father of a family.
AIMWELL—a brother's son, brought up with Mr. Robertson.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: WIDOW HERBERT—a woman, who boards Sophia.

DIV1.P: SCENE.—A merchant's house in the city of New-Haven.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I CAN beat you, Albin, two rubbers out of three all day long.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Why did you not beat me then just now?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Because that fellow (pointing to Aimwell) always looks over my shoulder, and talks about the game.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: He did the same to me, but it did not disturb me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Well, let us take the other rubber now.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I am almost tired of cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: That is, because you have beat, and want to have the credit of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: (to his father) Sir, shall we play here?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I think you had better defer it—I do not love to see people play when they are angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: OH dear! this execrable gout is coming on again. I am good for nothing. I am an old man in the midst of my days.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: When you was about twenty three years old, you used to say, that you would never marry, because married men would soon grow old—Now you are half the time laid up with the gout, while I have no sign of bodily decay—tho three years older than you—have not a gray hair on my head, nor a wrinkle in my face—no gout or rheumatism, as you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: You need not have any bodily torments—your children will give you torment sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (looking about) Whre is my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: He stole out, just now, and watched your eyes, that you might not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: He has no reason to be afraid of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: He is engaged in some scheme which he knows you will not approve. He has of late been out much anights.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (sighing) That is but too true.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Why need you trouble yourself about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (wakling about) O thou too tender heart of a father, canst thou not calm thyself one moment? How anxious I feel! could I only know that he was in good company, I might then enjoy some comfort—Brother, you had better go to bed. [Exit Major.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: HERE I will try to compose myself till my son comes home. [Albin enters in a stopped hat and speaks, looking at his own toes.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: So I lost my visit to night because the widow said she had a fainting fit & was sick—An't I a fool to love a little puny girl who will faint away, and be sick, and all that— She is an exccellent girl however, and that's the reason why I love her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (suddenly) Albin!

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: (starting) Sir I did not know you was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Who is that who is so sick?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I wish sir you would excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I shall not, tell me for what purpose you have been abroad so much of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Sir, I went—I went sir, to visit, Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: And who is Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Sophia Clifford sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Where does she live?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: At the widow Herbert's.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: A fine place for you to go a courting—The best furniture in the house, is an old maple table and a few old chairs bottomed with straw.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: The widow is poor but she is honest, and Sophia is a genteel girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P:
What do you mean to do with her? I will not suf∣fer you to delude her into vicious ways, or if you mean to
amuse her a while and then forsake her—That would be mean, and cruel.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: O sir, she is a sweet little angel as ever was—no body can do an unbecoming thing in her presence. Now, sir; since you know it, I wish you would go, and see her; and if you talk with her one half hour, and do not approve of my choice, I shall wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I will see her that I may understand this affair— But do not expect that I will encourage you in any of your foolish ways. (Exit Albin)

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: WILL you sit, madam Herbert?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I want to know something about Sophia▪ the girl that lives with you. I have heard of her; but since I have heard of her, I am more at a loss what to think of her than before.

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: What makes you think of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I am afraid of unwarrantable connections between my son, and her.

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: O, thank you sir, my house is as honest a house as any in this city.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Be not affronted widow, I am a widower you see —We will not be upon ill terms; does my son visit this girl?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: Yes, sir, often.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: How does e past his time with her?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: Sometimes he talks about common matters, sometimes he reads very pretty things to her out of books, and one time, but I chid him for that, he made a pair of verses about Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: You know how it is, widow, you and I have been courting before now—Does he ever talk to her, in a manner which you should think lly to affect the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: I have tho't that if I were as young as I once was, and he had taked I should have been af∣fected—and I once saw , when he seemed to be very earnest with her, she puts her hands over her eyes, and I saw the tears slip thro between her fingers, and trickle down her arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Do you know any thing of her family?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: She says she lately lost her father, and I don't say much to her about her family, for if I do, it makes her cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: And do you suppose Sophia to be a good girl?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: Yes, sir, that I do; she has been with me but six weeks waiting, as she says, for some money coming to her mother—And I would keep her if she never paid a farthing for her board, for she is always so pleasant, and when my work drives me, she will work upon the hard, coarse cloth, till her fingers bleed—I love her, sir, as if she was my own child—good night sir, I have no children of my own, but I hope my little Sophia will stay with me and be a comfort to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Stay widow, a moment; I will walk with you, and talk more about Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: W. Her.
SP.P: O Sir you are very kind to take notice of a poor old widow—If I had been young and worth twenty thousand pound, I should not have wondered to have heard you spoke up. [They withdraw.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: IT is all out about my attentions to Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: I tho't it could not be kept a secret long.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: The Major has told all the story to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: There is no keeping a secret in a house where there is an old Bachelor putting his nose in every man's dish. But I cannot talk of it now. [Exit Aimwell.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—FATHER and ALBIN.
DIV3.STAGE: (As the Father is sitting in a chair Albin comes up to his elbow—speaks anxiously—The father answers coldly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: HAVE you seen her Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes, I have seen her—what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: How do you like her sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Aye that's to the point to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Is she not beautiful?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes she is very beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Do you believe her sensible?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes I believe she is quite sensible.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Do you not think she is good tempered?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes, by her looks, she is a good tempered girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Do you not believe she is virtuous?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes I am apt to think she is virtuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Is she not genteel?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes her manners are very genteel.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: How did she converse?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Finely, indeed very finely.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Then what objection can you have to my acquaint∣ance with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: She is not fit for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Who then is fit for me? beautiful, good tempered, sensible, genteel, and converses finely; and yet not fit for me. Do sir tell me who is fit for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: A lady of fortune, of great relations, who will help you to get places in the government.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Then, I suppose, some time or other, you will mar∣ry me to some fat, clumsy, awkward squab of an heiress— I shall hate her, and kill her with grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: However that may be, my family must not be degraded—on the pain of my displeasure, you must quit this girl, and renounce her forever. [Exit Father.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I shall be able to renounce my life as soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Your Father would have had me gone to bed, but I did not choose it, so since I sat up; I tho't I would talk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I do not wish to hear you, you will only torment me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Your father will have you talk with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Talk what you please; but I have only one word to say. Sophia shall be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: A hopeful youth. You are nineteen years old— What will you do with this girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Courtship, it is said, is the happiest part of life— If so, let it begin early, and last long—What will I do with this girl? I will marry her, when it is convenient.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Your Father will disinherit you. You, your wife, and children must starve.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I know my Father's temper very well. Were my family in want, and my little children were to go, and spread out their little hands to him; it would melt him to pity, and he would relieve them at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Your father is a fool—He lets his children know that he loves them. There never was such a match in any family.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb
SP.P: Then this will be the first—it will be a great cu∣riosity

SP.SPEAKER: Maj
SP.P: And heiress of nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Who has taught me to despise all things but vir∣tue?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj
SP.P: Poor people always abound in children. If you do marry Sophia▪ I hope you will have a dozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Four dozen at least, uncle, if they resemble Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj
SP.P: If you have ver so many, you shall never name one afe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb
SP.P: Not I Your name is Benedict—I would as soon call one Sharah, Meshech and Abednego.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: By heavens! this is insufferable. I had rather you had died—I had rather when we stormed Stoney-Point, that one of the enemy had skewered you with his bayonet, and dropped you in the ditch among the dead. Leave my presence, you saucebox, in a moment.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—FATHER and CECILIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: TELL Clairet to bring my supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I will go and get it myself; it will be a pleasure to me. (Major goes out)

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: What a lovely daughter that is—I intend she shall be married and live with me; for I shall never be able to part with her, because she is the very image of my lost wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Your supper, sir, will be ready in a few moments.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Stay Cecilia now—Have you ever thought of that manner of life, which would be agreeable to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cel.
SP.P: No farther than that it is very agreeable to live with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: But you should have a friend to protect you when I am gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I am not in the least anxious about that.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: There is no need of affected modesty—if you pre∣fer any gentleman, I shall be happy to complete your fel∣icity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (After a long pause.) My brother's situation affrights me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Your brother is a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Perhaps if I speak my mind you will think me no less unreasonable than he!

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: If your modesty will not permit you, let me de∣declare for you. The Major has given me hints about Aimwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (Rising suddenly.) O dear sir, believe not a word he says. He is always trying to make mischief—Excuse me sir, I must be absent a moment.

DIV3.STAGE: [Goes out weeping, and wiping her eyes.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: How unhappy this is! I have lost her confidence, certainly; I am afraid I shall never see the happiness of one of my children. [Exit Father.]

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: AIMWELL, will reward you well, if you do one article of business for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I have got a warrant from Squire Smart to carry Sophia out of town. s a vagrant—If you will see it execu∣ted, I will make my will in your favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: I would do it, if I tho't it just.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: You will think it just I dare say—fifteen thousand pounds—and that ine girl, Cecilia, into the bargain—you must find it to just. But you will not speak of my project to Al.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: I will not. [Exit Major.]

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P:
I AM on the verge of distraction and despair—I will
carry Sophia away to the farms which will soon be mine, in New-Jersey.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: What, even if she be not willing?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I warrant I will make her willing. At any rate she shall go—I will assure to myself all that I hold valuable in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: You are rushing on your own destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: You are scrupulous beyond measure, and a little piece of a coward—But I wish my letters from Danbury would ative—Those might save me the trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: alone. SEE two men resolved on this poor girl's de∣struction—The Major would carry her out of town as a vagrant, and ruin her character—Albin would seize her and run away with her, and ruin her that way—There is no way to save her that I can think of; but to put her un∣der Cecilia's protection—and then if she proves a bad girl Cecilia will be subected—I must try to persuade Cecilia, tho it would be dangerous for her. What strange crea∣tures we men are; we persuade women to imprudent things, and then blame them for it. [Cecilia enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Aim
SP.P: My excellent Cecilia, I believe you must give ref∣uge to the unfortunate Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: O that must never be done—She may be a bad girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: I believe she is very honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Ah but what proof have you?—You must not in∣troduce her. (Aimwell goes out into the street, returns in a moment, introducing Sophia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: Here she is—If you can believe her a bad girl, turn her out in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: O Aimwell what have you done—I hope you will own that I have been kind enough to you now; that by your means I lie at the mercy of all my enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: MY good lady who ever you are have pity upon me. (Taking her by the hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Amiable and unfortunate girl, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: One of whom you would not have been ashamed in my better days—But my father is dead, I came here to re∣ceive a sum of money for my mother—and what miseries have I not endured. O that I had never seen your bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: My brother loves you with the tenderest affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: That I believe, and it is the source of my misery— He contemplates to run away with me, and that cruel Major, what have I do done to him, that he should perse∣cute me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: My heart bleeds for your distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: You won't let Albin carry me off, or any of the ugly officers take me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: No my sweet girl I will not, you have melted my heart within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: You are my guardian angel, my generous Cecilia. Your goodness shall be rewarded, if the prayers of the af∣flicted have any avail.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Compose yourself, my dear lady, nothing shall hurt you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I feel a heavy sensation; I am afraid I shall faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: No you are only sleepy—You shall take a little re∣pose in your chair. (Cecilia lays a pillow in the back of a chair and covers Sophia with a shaw!—Sophia sleeps covered.)

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Don't let any man come into the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I will not. (Exit Cecilia)

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P:
I Have eluded Cecilia sweetly — she made fast one door; but forgot there was another—Now is the time to carry her off, but I will see her first, and not carry off a wrong girl for they may mean to cheat me. (Advances on tiptoe lifts up the shawl stands and looks with astonishment on Soph∣ia sleeping.) Yes it is she and how delightful she looks when sleeping—I am filled with rapture and astonishment—can I violate that sweet temple of beauty? (pauses) Can I resist her reasons, or her intreaties when she shall refuse to go— Albin, you have undertaken what you dare not not exe∣cute— (Sophia moves as if distressed in sleep and says) "Al∣bin carry me away, no that is not like Albin." (Albin starts and runs to the edge of the curtain) Yes it is like Albin and
Albin is a wicked fellow—O how her presence strikes me with veneration! I cannot touch her, to do her harm— Now if she should wake and catch me here▪ how angry she would be. But I never shall forget how sweetly she look when asleep. (Exit softly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I AM now glad I received this girl, and I begin to think that happiness consists in doing good.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: (waking) My good protectress, how long have I been asleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Not more than fifteen or twenty minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Has there not been a man in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Certainly not.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I tho't I heard one step across the floor; but was so overcome with sleep that I could not move.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You must have dreamed it; for I locked the door and put the key in my own pocket.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.—ALBIN, SOPHIA and CECILIA. Albin runs in and offers to catch Sophia's hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: SOPHIA my life my— (she refuses him her hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Albin, how dare you to come into my presence, after the odious scheme you had formed?

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: How! I do not comprehend this—perhaps Albin may be capable of his resentments too.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: You may resent my conduct in what manner you please—you intended to have carried me off, whether I would or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: But I do not intend it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: No matter for that, he who has once form∣ed an ill design against a woman, should be trusted no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Well, I suppose I have done wrong, but I ask par∣don.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I pardon the past. But I mean to trust you no more—I forbid you my presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I must intreat you to revoke the harshness of that sentence. My heart after admitting you to its affections, can never admit an inferior; and I must be miserable for life—I will for the future treat you on the strictest rules of honor, you may depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I have no evidence but your own testimony, and you have always been unfaithful, so you must depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I have imagined an injury against you, and would you destroy me entirely? You are more severe, than vir∣tuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Sophia you must pardon my brother. He was driv∣en to the borders of dsepair—I risked my honor to save you from odious persecution—I have saved you, you must not destroy my brother—you will make me miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: For your sake I forgive him; you shall be his sure∣ty that he will not attempt the like again.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: I will not even imagine it—may I presume to take this hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Yes it is your's again, and when I forgive, I do it heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Sweet Sophia—every moment I see new cause to admire you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Did my Father know your true character—he could not oppose your introduction into the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: ALAS! what shall I do? My son flies my presence—Cecilia distrusts me—Aimwell is shy of me—I almost repent my treating my son so severely respecting Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Repent! That is a pretty fancy, and so encourage them in their impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: What would you do were you in my case?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I would discard that villain of a son, forever—That little saucy minx of a daugher—I'd take away all her fine cloaths, confine her to her chamber, and feed her on water-gruel. I'd give that young knave a dressing, whom you have brought up. They should obey me, or I would make them all skip—that I would.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P:
Your advice does me some good—It is so absurd
it diverts me—I want to know what my happiness would be if I had disinherited my son—starved my daughter—and banished the son of my dearest friend, or what would my neighbors think of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Oh you dread to lose your children, and be tho't a cruel father.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I own it. If my children can live without me, I cannot live without them.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: There it is now. I thought you had been more of a man—are you not ashamed? you have no notion of that lively resentment which becomes a Father, whose authority is insulted.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: First attain the honor of being a father, and then judge of his duties—are you not ashamed? You would desolate my house, as effectually as the plague.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I suppose I shall see you kissing, and forgiving them all in a few days.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I hope they will prove themselves innocent; I wish it might be this hour—I could not imagine a greater happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: I did not intend to have told you, but I'll art your dull blood—the knave you bro't up is courting your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
