SP.P: Not Cecilia, is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: Yes! I have catched them several times in such a fondling way as made me sick, perfectly sick. (He spits.)

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Lover's caresses are apt to be a little ickish to an indifferent observer but more to an envious one—how is it, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: She has sitten up a great many nights, pretending to work—but there is very little work done. What do you think of that, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: It is just as I would have it be. It is the best news I ever heard from you in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: You will do nothing for the honor of the family— but I have—I have got a warrant, and Aimwell is to exe∣cute it—to take up this girl as a vagrant, and cart her out of town.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: You have done a base action—but Aimwell is com∣ing; I will stop the process this moment. [Exit Maj.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: AIMWELL, what have you done? To execute a warrant against an innocent person—I should have been glad of your fondness for Cecilia, but for this base action— I cannot consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: Then this warrant will ruin me. The detestable scroll— [throws it under his feet] I will kick it to perdition. [kicks it off the stage.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Hold—you have not executed it—I am glad of that—give it to me; I will see what shall be done with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Aim.
SP.P: There it is—I am glad to be rid of it, and will tell the Major you have got it. [Exit Aimwell.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—FATHER, SOPHIA and CECILIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: CECILIA, tell Sophia to come to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Sophia sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Yes, you impudent girl, I know you have her here; tell her to come to me. (to Sophia) Sophia I have it in my power to treat you with severity, but I had rather use other methods—If you will give up my son I will make you a rich girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I cannot, sir, be guilty of falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: You ought not to interfere in the rights of my family—you are determined to marry my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Not till you consent to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: But you will not give him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Because I have promised that I would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Here Sophia, give up my son, and take this. Here is enough to buy you a first rate husband at Danbury (puts a purse into her hands, and she lets it fall.)

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Not for the universe, would I ever give up the man of my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Then the warrant must have its course.

DIV3.STAGE: [Takes the warrant out and appears to be going]

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P:
(catching his arm) O dear sir, I implore your pity; tho I cannot give up your son — you know the tenderness of youthful bosoms—would you have given up your wife, in all the bloom of youth? Leave me not to disgrace—and
the odious pursuit of laws—most humbly do I implore your compassion, but cannot give up my friend.

LG.L: "If ever a fond inclination,
"Arose in your bosom to rob you of rest—
"Reflect with a little compassion,
"On those soft pains you felt in your breast,
"Where, where, where, where, could I shun him,
"Or would I, how could I, deny his request—
"Kneeling before you,
"Let me implore you,
"O is there no language can move!
"Where, where, where, where, could I shun him,
"For hard is the contest 'twixt duty and love."

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—FATHER, ALBIN and MAYOR.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: NOTHING can compensate a man for the loss of an excellent wife—since the death of my dear Cecilia— happiness has forsaken my house—I took in my brother to divert my melancholy—but be only sows dissention be∣tween me and my children. He has no idea of the family state—my prudent wife foresaw my miseries, and ad∣vised me, that was all I could hear of her last broken ac∣cents, to marry the "general's sister"—what general I know not. But could I find out whom my wife meant, I would marry again, and see if I could not restore peace to my family. [Albin enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Dear sir, I have a letter, which came by the post this day, and it concerns you as well as me. Shall I read it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: By all means. (Albin reads.)

LETTER.P:
I SEND you the intelligence which you desired
me to procure—by the records of Danbury church, it ap∣pears that John Clifford, was married to Anne Waterbu∣ry, sister of Capt. Waterbury, afterwards general—the 27th of January 1768. Sophia their third child, for they lost their two first—was baptized June 4th 1775—they are a family not of ample fortune, but decent estate, of eminent good sense, of the most distinguished virtues— Sophia sustains an excellent character, in this place—If you can obtain her you will be happy.

CLOSER.SIGNED: I am with all imaginable respect, yours, JOSEPH TRUEMAN.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. John Clifford, Sophia's Father, died universally regretted, Sept. 29th 1791—the widow who is general Wa∣terbury's sister, is yet alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (lapping him on the shoulders) Albin my boy? This is excellent—you carefully enquired out the character and con∣nections of your virtuous mistress. Few men have so much prudence at three times your age—this Anne Waterbury was my first love, we separated on account of a violent quarrel between our families; but on a promise that if ever we were at liberty we would meet again—so Anne Wat∣erbury that was is now my promised wife.

(Turning to Albin.) So Albin, if you will accept of the widow Clifford for a mother, Sophia is yours forever; Aimwell is the person I wish Cecilia to marry—all comes exactly to rights—let friendship and love once more reign thro the whole family. (Enter Sophia and Cecilia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Maj.
SP.P: So things are come to a fine pass, making love and marrying are become the general business of the house. This is no place for me, Ill get away as fast as I can, I shall be glad to get out of a family where things are car∣ried contrary to every principle of nature, and common sense. (Exit Major.)

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P:
Come my children let me indulge my joy; you have behaved well, I acknowledge it with sincere delight: it is one of the greatest of earthly blessings to have virtu∣ous children; Aimwell and Cecilia, you need no more fear my displeasure—Sophia, you are my daughter now, and dear to my heart—let us forget our errors, and par∣take the delights of virtue—now are we—my children, dearest of my earthly treasures, now are we happily united.
And we will be separated no more, nor shall any sow dis∣trust and jealously between us.

LG.L: What anxious cares a Father's mind employ;
Yet when those cares succeed how great his joy.

DIV3.STAGE: (Father leads—Albin leads off Sophia—Aimwell conducts Cecilia—they leave the stage in the highest transports of joy.)

DIV1.HEAD: The Bottle Conjuror. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
DISPLAYING THE WEAKNESS OF THOSE WHO BELIEVE IN FORTUNE-TELLERS.
DIV1.P: THE rage of curiosity, enquiring into future events, has been a vice of mankind in every age. There is more wickedness in this vice, than every one is aware of. It implies impatience, under the pres∣ent dispensations of Divine Providence, and dis∣trust for the future—It often excites delusive hopes— at other times, fills the mind with needless anguish and terror—And it greatly injures society, by sup∣porting a number of idle, unprincipled wretches, who make a fortune, in earnest, from the purses of the credulous.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: SHERIFF—ordered by the Justice to take Sidrophel.
SUITOR—to Miss Firebrand, enquiring his fortune.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MISS FIREBRAND—courted by the suitor, who was con∣sulting the conjuror.

DIV1.P: [☞ IF in this dialogue, the scene of Miss Firebrand and Si∣drophel be left out; and what the Mother says be continued under the name of the Father; it may be performed by men only.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I BEGIN to be ashamed of myself that there is so much roguery in the world, and, as yet, I have had no hand in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Sir, you seem to be very anxious and pensive— Have you met with any thing disagreeable?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I am in deep speculation on a very important mat∣ter—I wish, like thousands of my fellows in this world, to get money without earning it. But hitherto, I can hit on no expedient for the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Sir, I wonder at that very much—I have tho't you had better set up for a conjuror.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: A conjuror! Who would be fool enough to believe any thing of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Can you be so ignorant of human kind? Do you not know, that if one man has courage to cheat, there will be thousands who stand ready to believe?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I can make no calculations on the stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: That is a matter of no kind of consequence. Oth∣er conjurors know as little of that as you. Only tell some∣thing extraordinary—and you will have people enough to believe it

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: By what means shall I begin the business?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P:
Only look here—Take this bottle and fill it with any kind of liquor—and call it Elixir Planetarium—and give out that he, who tastes this liquor, immediately be∣comes sensible of the influence of the planets; and that you
can tell the fortunes of all who apply to you. You will find multitudes ready to believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: There is sense in what you say—I will get all mat∣ters ready, and do you spread a number of surprising stories among the people and prepare them for the sport.,

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Then you shall let me share half of the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Yes; but do you be filling their minds with strange stories without delay. [Exit Sidrophel.]

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: HAVE you seen any thing of a roan mare who strayed away, or was stolen from my pasture yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: What were her marks?

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: She had three white feet, trotted very square; and had a blaze in her forehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: I have not seen such a mare—but I believe my master can tell you of her—He understands such things well.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: They say he understands the art of conjuring; and can find los things.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: He has got the true Elixir Planetarium a liquor which distills from the moon—and is squeezed out of the moss which grows on the tops of old "ruined castles and moss grown steeples." It resembles some of the finer wines —but the taste of it is very fine—And if any one tastes it, it makes him sensible of the influence of the stars, he can tell peoples fortune's—declare the place of lost goods—and indeed every thing one wants to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: And how came your master by this liquor?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: He has a bottle of it which was owned by Peter the Hermit, who preached up the Crusades for the recove∣ry of Jerusalem. It descended from him to Dr. Faustus— and from him to the famous Radcliffe of London—and it comes by inheritance to my master, who is the seventh son of a seventh son.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: That's very strange I'll say for't. And can't he tell what has become of my mare?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: I am confident he can, for he can tell almost ev∣ery thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Do you know of particular cases in which he has told the truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P:
Yes, there was a girl in our neighborhood had a sweeheart, who was tho't to love her, very much. But
she said—Now my market is made—and he grew sluttish, and careless and fancy. My master told her fortune, that she would grow careless and he would be sick of her and leave her—and that she would be miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: How did the matter end?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph
SP.P: Just as my master told in every particular. You would be surprized to find how exact he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Why that is good guessing I count—But one in∣stance not enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: There was a young man, who courted a very in∣dustrious girl—He disliked her and left her, because she had a hard hand, and the ends of her fingers were rough by being pricked with a needle; and the mark of a thimble spoiled the beauty of one of her fingers—after he had left her he came to have his fortune told.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Immediately after leaving this girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: No, but he was then courting another, whose hands were as soft as paste—and there was not the least mark of a needle, thimble, or any blemish to be seen on her hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Could your master tell his fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Yes, he told him that he would marry an idle wife who would dissipate his fortune. And it turned out just so, in every particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: There is reason in that—I guess your master is no common conjuror.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: He is an extraordinary man—One more instance I will tell, which must surprize you—For, I assure you, that bottle of my master's is brimful of wisdom—A young lady of our village trusted a gentleman his mere word for the security of her reputation—She came to my master to tell her fortune—He told her that the wretch would nev∣er marry her, and it turned out just so.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: How under the heavens could he know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: He would know it above the heavens. Assoon as he tastes the Elixir Planetarium he becomes acquainted with the whole circuit of the stars—with all ther aspects and in∣fluence on the earth—and I have often heard him say that if a woman trust her reputation, to the mere word of a man —eight times out of twelve she will repent her confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: I long to enquire of him about my roan mare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Then I'll call him immediately.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—SIDROPHEL and FARMER.
DIV3.STAGE: (The conjuror enters in a great wig, long gown, staff and bottle.)

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: THEY say you tell of things lost and stolen. Can you tell me of my roan mare?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: As far as the influence of the planets goes; but we have nothing to do with the black art.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: I've lost as good a mare as man could wish to own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: From whence was your mare taken?

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: From my pasture, I saw fresh tracks in the dew, about day light.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: (takes his bottle and looks wise.) I perceive that your horse was taken out of the pasture just at morning—And did you search all the public roads?

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Yes, we did, and she could neither be heard, nor seen any where—There is no account of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I perceive that your mare has got into some buy place. (looks very wise and important.)

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: That may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Are there not girls in your neighborhood who are courted?

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Yes sir, three, or four.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: And do their suitors live remote from the public road?

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: Yes, two or three of them live very remote from public ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Well sir I see how this matter is—The planet Ve∣nus rules in the evening; that sen the young lads in quest of the girls—In the latter part of the night the influence of Mercury became predominant—that planet impels to thiev∣ing—going hme the young fellows stole your mare. They have left her that ye place and there you will find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: What is to pay sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid
SP.P: About fifteen shillings, if I ask any thing, or you may give me what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Farm.
SP.P: There sir, I think is just the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid
SP.P: Well sir, step into the other room, and take a drink with . ( Sidrophel and Farmer.)

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: I HOPE you won't tell Mr. Small thought about me—If the stars should let you know, don't tell him any thing about my being so passionate—I hope to manage the matter to my advantage, for he has been pretty attentive to me and I don't wish him to find it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: And have not you other vices too?

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: I don't love to get up early in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: You don't love housework neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: There is some truth in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Well if he marries you there is danger, that he will have an idle passionate wife and a bad economist.

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: That he may find out—Now it is my desire that he may not know of it—Could you cast a spell too, to prevent his finding out my being given to tattling, and in∣juring people's characters?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid
SP.P: Why, I am afraid, there is no art can tame a wan∣ton tongue—I fear the power of all the planets would not reach to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: O sir, I had no thought that you should confine my tongue, I would not have you do that for the world —But prevent the gentleman's hearing any thing bad of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Well this matter belongs to Mercury, he has in∣fluence over all stratagems. When Mercury rules I'll try what can be done. And the price is just the same, for preventing a things being known as to discover what is unknown—I have fifteen shilling's for every trip to the stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Fire.
SP.P: Well if you can conceal all my faults, I would not grudge ten times the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P:
IT is a grief to me to see how easily human be∣ings are deceived—Multitudes give money to conjurors,
and fortunetellers freely, who would never give a farthing for any honest purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sher.
SP.P: Why sir, we must take mankind as we find them, and do them all the good we can. I know nothing more humane than to bear men's vices if we must, and cure them if we can.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: But since I am come into office I will turn over a new leaf in this neighborhood—The people shall not go after conjurors and witch-men. I'll prosecute such fellows as vagrants to the utmost rigor of law—They shall have something else to do than to show magic lanthorns, and set up conjuring bottles. Such fools defy the whole com∣monwealth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sher.
SP.P: How much influence they have I cannot say, nor how you will prevent them.

SP.SPEAKER: Hol.
SP.P: I'll apprehend this same Sidrophel, by warrant— when we have him under authority we'll get the whole matter out of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sher.
SP.P: Sir excuse me, I am apt to be nervous. If I should see a ghost, or a devil, it would fright me to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Are you a fool? How many ghosts and devils can he cork up in his old junk? Do you suppose it would hold as many as Mary Magdalen's? You shall serve the warrant or be broke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sher.
SP.P: You may procure me to be broke, but your wor∣ship should consider that he can turn himself into all sorts of shapes—and if he should turn himself into a dead horse without a head, stretch his nose out half a yard long, or swell out his eyes as big as two warming pans, I should be so frighted that I should not get over it in a mouth; and folks say he can do this, or any thing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: For shame to believe such nonsense. Take this warrant, and execute it, or it will be the worse for you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—HOLDFAST, followed by FARMER, MILLER, FATHER and SUITOR, with a mob, armed with clubs.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: WHY do you follow me thus? What's your will?

SP.SPEAKER: Far.
SP.P: Our Bottleman is as good a man as you, Mr Jus∣tice. He told me how to find old Roan. If you offer to meddle with him. I'll burn your house over your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P:
Shame neighbor, how foolishly you talk—to ex∣pose
your life for a wretched juggler. Have you any rea∣son?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.P: Mr. Justice, you have got to be a great man since you got your commission. Will you take up our Bottle∣man? If you do, (shaking his club) I'll open my mill-dam and drown all your flax.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: I want to know my children's fortunes—if you take up our bottle prophet and put him into jail, I'll raise a mob, and give you a new suit of tar and feathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Suit.
SP.P: I want to know if Miss Firebrand will have me— and if you offer to take up our Bottleman, I'll way lay you and knock your brains out. You may put the Doctor, the music master, all into jail, with all the school masters in town—you may burn the meetinghouse, and all the school houses in town; but if you touch our Bottleman you touch my heart's blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—SIDROPHEL, MILLER, FATHER, MOTHER and SUITOR.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: YOU do well, fellow citizens▪ to consult the stars. They know every thing that is done in this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.P: I knew a miller sir, that fixed a bag below the box which contains the meal that is grinding, in such a man∣ner, as to catch meal from the box—and he called this practice making presents to his Peggy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Well sir, and what is your will?

SP.SPEAKER: Mil.
SP.P: I wish to know whether this miller will ever be detected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P:
(tasting his bottle and looking wise) This is a matter
of stealing—it belongs to Mercury—yes—this Mercury tells, that the rogue is yourself. Going home you will find a man who has Peggy and all the presents you have given her in the mouth of his bag. [The miller is going away, but he calls after him.] Stop sir, and pay your fifteen shil∣lings, o I will bring you out in some of your other tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath
SP.P: I have a son; I wish very much to know his for∣tune—Something makes me anxious about him. He is a likely well made felow; and I want to know whether I had best send him to college, and make a learned man of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: How does he like instrustion at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath
SP.P: He would like it pretty well, I believe, if we could ever get a school master that was worth the money—But he is dissatisfied with all we have had yet—and indeed ac∣cording to his account, they were wretched fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Does he drink hard?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath
SP.P: Not very; I never knew him drunk more than four or five times in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid
SP.P: How is he with respect to the women?

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: Pretty well—he is often playing with the girls whom I hire to do my work; but he is rather bashful with your genteel women, your fine ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: (tasting his bottle) Well, this is a matter of learn∣ing—It depends on the Sun—by the the antients called Apollo, the God of Wisdom. He finds much fault with his school masters.—He hates learning then. At College he'll kick up a rumpus ad disturb the government. He has been drunk several time —He will be a capital hand for high goes. He plays with hired maids, and is abashed and confounded among modest women—This is the opin∣on which I have drawn from the Sun; that he will be a rake, a dirty low rake.

SP.SPEAKER: Fath.
SP.P: (pays cheerfuly) I do not grudge the money —my wife I hope will be easy on that score. [Exit Father.]

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Sir, I have two daughters, and of very different manners▪ I should be glad to know their fortunes The eldest is given to scandal, and is nice about her company, to a very great exreme—There are none but ip tops that can speak to her. But I'm a plain woman; she has not birth, and certainly not fortune nor accomplishments to boast of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: (tasting his bottle) Venus has the charge of these matters; and madam Venus says; the queen of beauty declares; that this daughter of yours must be an old maid —for it has lately been ordained, in the court of celestial beauty, that every girl (now a juster law was never made) that every girl that is given to scandal and ill nature, and dissimulation, shall be an old maid.—That the good tem∣pered, tender, agreeable girls, who at the same time are sociable and discreet, shall marry young, genteel, handsome lads, who will be fond husbands even to old age.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Then there will be a reformation among the women soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Certainly, it begins to operate already.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: My other girl is handsome, lively, good tem∣pered, fond of good books, and good men; neat in her dress, sociable, and tender; yet she is a good prudent girl—She has the name of a very prudent girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I predict her fortune will be very good. She will be courted early in life, marry a likely man who will sup∣port her genteelly and live very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Well (taking money and paying cheerfully) I do not grudge the money, now I shall know what to do with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Suit.
SP.P: Sir, I am courting a maiden lady of fortune, who is past fifty, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph,
SP.P: SIR the sheriff is coming, to serve a warrant on you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: (putting on his visor aside) Now let him come if he dares. (The conjuror comes forward—The sheriff comes on with his warrant, is about to clap Sidrophel on the shoulder when he displays his visor, breathing from his mouth.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Thou enemy of the arts and antichrist of the sci∣ences, avaunt, begone.

SP.SPEAKER: Sher.
SP.P: (in a terrible fright.) O mercy, mercy, mercy on us, O terrible oh, dreadful oh! (Flies off the stage and Sid∣rophel and Ralph pursues him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: How do you do sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Well, and earty what do you want of me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Nothing very special; but as I was walking with some people across the plain, with several young ladies— I tho it my duty to call on you, upon some serious bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: What do you wish to know sir? whether you shall meet with success with the ladies. Is that it sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: No, sir, by no means, but as I came along I saw your barn and stable all in a blaze and I knew your best horse to be in the stable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: You villain why did you not tell me before.; they are all in a blaze before this time—Now they are all in ashes before this time—Run Ralph run. (they run out in haste.) (Holdfast enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: WHAT have you done with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: We shall now have him fast enough—for in fact his stable is on fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Here he has left all his tools behind him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: He has; there's his visor, his bottle, staff and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: And this is that which put the Sheriff in such a terrible fright.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Yes, but is perfectly harmless now—And here's the bottle—Let us taste—It did not poison him neither will it poison us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Let us drink it off—or take a genteel sip at least. Do you suppose, we shall understand the stars—It may make us see stars if it be too strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: We will not drink the whole. (Sets the bottle down.) Now let us fill it with about 150 drops of laudanum and that will give him a decent nap. (Drops Laudanum from a vial into the bottle.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: That will be very dextrous—Now I trust Mr. Conjuror will find his match. And we shall accomplish by art, what we could not accomplish by open means, thro the madness of the mob—But do you stay here, and amuse him when he returns.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: (to Sidrophel.) HAVE you lost any valuable prop∣erty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: I have not lost any thing of great consequence, tho my stable was indeed on fire, but in such a manner as ea∣sily to be extingushed—But you did not help us to put it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly
SP.P: I have long since much used myself to Philosophy— and am not moved with the accidents of this life. But can you tell my fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: Your fortune I suspect is to be hanged, for you are a rogue in grain You told me my stables were on fire, but never ent the least assistance to put it out. I suspect you set the fire yourself

SP.SPEAKER: Sly
SP.P: One who knows the plane's as well as you. should not suspect; he might know—Now calculate upon the influ∣ence of the planets, and if you can furnish any proof by means of them, I shall be hanged no doubt: but if you will not calculate for me, you may go to sleep.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—SUITOR and SIDROPHEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Suit.
SP.P: Sir, we we were broken off before, by the cry of the fire—Tell me now, sir, what will be the consequence if I marry Miss Firebrand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sid.
SP.P: (tasting his bottle) Why sir, this is the oddest love affair that ever I had any concern with. Venus has noth∣ing to do with it. The queen of love is quite out of the question Mercury has a hand in it, as it is a matter of gain. You will make yourself rich by it—But then Mars, the fiery planet, has a hand in it—There will be wars (he nods) and fightings between you—yes, yes, yes—you will —you'll quarrel—yes—O dear, how sleepy I am—I think you'll quarrel—sir—

DIV3.STAGE: [He sinks down and is soon fast asleep]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V —HOLDFAST, SHERIFF, and assistants; and SLYBOOTS.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Here he is, Mr. Sheriff; and here is his bottle, and his formidable visor which affrighted you. How vain all your fears were you may now see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly
SP.P: If he knew the stars could he not have known what we were about to do with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hold
SP.P: No doubt, and from this you may see how cred∣ulous those people are who believe in people who have a present interest to deceive them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sly.
SP.P: Alas, my formidable astronomer, man familiar with the stars, O Lucifer how art thou fallen—Up and take a sip of the Elixir Planetarium, and tell us all tt is do∣ing among the stars—Thou art overcome by yboots— how weak is human wisdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Hold.
SP.P: Here Mr. Sheriff take this mittmus, and for the present commit him to jail.

DIV1.HEAD: The Apparition. A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
VICE, IN GENERAL, IS THE CAUSE OF SUPER∣STITION.
DIV1.P: WE say, in general, because sometimes superstition arises from weakness of mind, or accidental cau∣ses.—But, in general, the mind which is conscious of guilt, is, by that very sensation, prepared to see ghosts, devils, and furies, and all the armies of ter∣ror. It is probable that Brutus had never seen Caesar's ghost at Emhia, had he not been conscious to himself that he was the assassin and murderer of Caesar. It is easy to see, from these observations, how necessary it is, that we keep our minds free from guilt; that we may enjoy contentment and happiness.

LIST.HEAD: Two young gentlemen of the country.
WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: ROSINA—a girl extremely fond of amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: WELL, you will allow that I contrived the entertainment, we have had this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Was it not agrreeable?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Yes, while it lasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: And it is quite agreeable to think of it, when it is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: It is common for me to feel dull after a frolic.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I think girls we have a chearful prospect. I never saw our young beaux behave half so well, as they did this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I have often supposed the girls here had a melan∣choly view of time to come—our young sparks were so dull and numpish—but they shone out this evening quite plausibly. Yet after all I feel dull and heavy, and heavy I must feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: You are a heavy, dumpish, creature, I know; I hope some of the rest of the girls will come in and relieve me. [Enter Rhoda]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—RHODA and ROSINA.
DIV3.STAGE: (Almeria is pensive thro this whole scene.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: WHAT ails Almeria? She is as dull as a block.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: I am afraid you will not find me any better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: What ails you? Has the dance tired you out. It never tires me. I could dance forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: It is not the dance that tires me. The reflections of my mind are disagreeable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Now Almeria thinks that we never had so fine a prospect of having a set of agreeable young gentlemen about us, as at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: That prospect gives me very little comfort now.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Why now?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: Because I fear, if they be worthy of our regards, that we have behaved in such a manner as to be unworthy of theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Why unworthy of theirs?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: Because Almeria, Levania, and myself, as well as you, came out this evening with an express promise to our parents that we would be back again by ten—They know not where we are, and even now it is almost two in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: And why did you not think of that in the time of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: The music, the dance, the refreshment, so exhilirat∣ed my spirits, that I found it next to impossible to get away —and when the time was now elapsed, the shower detained us; as the time was past I thought we might as well be killed for a great fault as a small one — so I concluded to stay.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—LEVANIA, ALMERIA, ROSINA and RHODA.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: DO you not feel very disagreeably, now the dance is over?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: She expected Mr. Lightfoot would have remained —Her comfort is departed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: It would not have been in his power to have af∣forded me much consolation.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: What do you suppose our parents think of us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: I know not; but must suppose they are very unea∣sy — I dare say mine have not slept a wink this night.— They are always uneasy, when I stay out late, and they know not what has become of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And what account can we give of ourselves, on our return?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: What account ladies? I wonder you should be puz∣zled about that. I can manage that matter very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I wonder how?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I am surprized that you can be so dull—I can fix the whole business, as nicely as can be. Only tell them that there has fallen a shower this night, that it began to rain in the place where we were, at half past nine—and never left raining till past two in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: That I suppose we must tell, or meet with a very disagreeable reception. Tho I must confess the story is bad enough, take it lie and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: That is the most plausible story we can tell, I sup∣pose whether it be true or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Rhod.
SP.P: I shall tell my parents the whole truth, be the con∣sequence what it may—I shall have nothing to do with your fictitious stories; for we may depend on it that the black man will have us, if we tell such abominable lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Why Rhoda! what do you mean? You talk enough to fright one.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: I talk just as I think, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: There is another thing to think of which is as per∣plexing as any thing can be. There has no one invited us to stay here. How shall we get any rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I'll manage that matter too. I will go to the 'Squire's daughter, and see how we can be accommodated: pick up all your things, and have them ready; and if we cannot rest here, we will all set out together a little before day, so as to get home, before the people are up in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: A pretty figure we shall make, but for that matter, no body will see us. (Exeunt omnes)

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: NOW let us consider what is to be done with these girls. Will you see them home?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Not I, I have tired myself already, with dancing and waiting on the misses.

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: But it would be unpolite to let them go home alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Why, they came out alone; and they may return alone—No one invited them here.

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: Then I shall not trouble myself with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Nor I, for they stole away from their parents; and if we go home with them, their parents will believe that we enticed them away, and we shall get a bad name.

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: I am astonished that the girls should not think of that, how they expose themselves by such things—I should be afraid to marry such a girl, for fear she should run away from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I leave them to you. You may be 'squire to them all if you please. (Exit Philander)

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: ARE all the young ladies gone yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: No; Rosina, and they who came with her, are in the ball room now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why have you not the complaisance to wait on them home?

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: They stole away from their parents; and now if we wait on them home, it will be tho't that we seduced them away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What a reflection for a young man—had you been sixty years old, I should not have wondered to hear you make it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stre.
SP.P: I am ten times more interested in the virtue of young girls than any man of sixty—When I marry I shall wish to have a wife that won't run away.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: IS not the company all gone yet? I am tired and wish to go to rest. Have you asked any of them to tarry here to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: Not one, I did not know how you would like it, as I understand my Papa leaves all these things to you in his absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: Are they in the back parlour yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
No, I believe they are gone into the ball room— But they cannot go away, for it is tremendous dark; and
the moon does not rise till a quarter past three—There has been a shower too! and the roads are all full of water.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: And why did not some of the young gentlmen wait on these girls home?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Because they knew they run away from their parents; and they were afraid to go home with them lest it should be tho't that they seduced them away.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: That is quite curious—but a young man of twen∣ty five is always more rigid in his ideas of women's mor∣als, than a man of sixty five.

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: (starting up and speaking quick) And don't you know the reason of that ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: Why what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: The young men suffer by the faults of the girls. The old ones are not afraid of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's a deep observation for you miss; where did you learn all this wisdom?

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: I knew our Pat would start to hear me say so— But I heard Pâ say so himself once; but Pat don't like to hear of it, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: How came there to be such a collection of young people here to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: It was all Rosina's contrivance, she loves frolicks, and is a perfect witch at intrigue to get young people to∣gether in the absence of the elder ones; that they may take the more liberty together.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: I fear the 'Squire's displeasure—were this house mie I should not like so much company in my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He will not like it. He says the amusements of young people should not exclude the observation of the elder—Because the observations of the elder persons in∣spire the young ones with a sense of decency—and the aged by sympathy enjoy over again the delights of youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: That I suppose contributed to the happiness of both—I've heard him say that in Switzerland they dance after prayers in the evening, and the elder people wait on the young ones—I don't like this creeping into houses, in the absence of their owners—A shyness between the elder people, and the younger ones, denotes vulgarism in man∣ners and a low state of society.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What will you do with them—will you turn these four girls out of doors?

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: No, give them some buttered rolls and beer, and then put them to bed in the chamber where the 'Squire commonly sleeps—So I will go to rest; and you may go to the ball-room and see how the girls are to be disposed of.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—MARTHA, ROSINA, ALMERIA, RHODA, and LEVANIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: SINCE the ladies are willing to stay we will lodge them in the haunted chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: The haunted chamber did you say? I should not sleep a wink.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: It is only a notion about its being haunted—It is as handsome a room as any in the whole house—The 'Squire sleeps there when at home—and his man George in the lit∣tle room adjoining—There are two beds perfectly neat, and well aired—just sufficient for you four ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: But for heaven's sake don't put us to bed in a haunt∣ed chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why, I tell you it is nothing but a notion.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: How do you know it is nothing but a notion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My mother always used to sleep there; she was a Church of England woman, and always said her prayers by book—she had a reading desk over the Sofa against the inner wall, where she used to kneel and say her prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: What connection has that with the chamber's being haunted?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Only since my mother's death a vapory old wom∣an who has lived with us, says that between day-light and dark, she has seen my mother in that chamber, reading her prayers, just as if alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And did none of the rest of the family see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Never. My Sir. always sleeps there, when at home. My mamma has been dead about eighteen months— and my papa says there is no place so pleasant to him, as where she used to be—If she comes he says he should be glad to see her—for as she never did any thing, but good, in her life time—he cannot think she would hurt any person now she's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: And is not any one of the family afraid to lodge there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
No, no more than any where else—It is only by way of joke that we call it the haunted chamber—You may
stay here Ladies till I get a light—It will be perfectly safe for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: WELL what will you do ladies? Will you sleep in the haunted chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: I am not afraid, for I am determined to tell no lies —What do you say Almeria? That was a pretty lie you contried to tell your parents when you went home.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I don't like sleeping in a haunted chamber very well —we may possibly get a fright.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: I suspect there may be some truth in the story ab∣out the old lady's appearance. I have heard of a number of such things in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: And so have I; but I never believed them. What is the reason, that people of the best sense, and best under∣standing, never see such things? But they are commonly seen by nervous, hypocondriac, or half crazy persons. I do not say such things never were; but I believe most stor∣ies of that kind are without foundation.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I do not know what to think of such things; but I know it is natural for me to be afraid; and I own I do now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: I wish I never had thought of going from home this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: O, you are a faint hearted creature as ever exist∣ed—You are not capable of doing any thing that is ingeni∣ous—I am not yet twenty years old—and I have contrived up more than a hundred evening parties already—I love amusements. Life is insipid without them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: And so it is a pretty amusement to lodge in a haunted chamber—I guess you will meet with something to try your high spirits yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I protest I am not in the least afraid. Let old grand mother come if she will, and say her prayers—If she be a good woman—we shall sleep the safer for that. Come, come, let's go.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: I feel afraid—I do not wish to go—I do not love to sleep in a haunted chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: Nor I, and am willing to own it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: O for shame girls, what cowards you are, afraid of nothing—come—come along, or I will leave you here in the dark. [Exit all the Ladies.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: WELL Smiley, where's your Doll?

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: I have put it where you cannot find it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I shall get it yet—and cut its head off.

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: O you cruel, barbarous wretch, to go to murder my poor baby, little innocent, that never did any harm in its life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I set my black cat to day on your white one, and she has stript her ears all into fiddlestrings; and one of these days I intend to kill her. (Exit Simon.)

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: I TELL you what Patty, our Simon is a rogue— he's always setting his black cat on my white one; and he says he means to kill my cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He shall not kill your cat. If he does he shall be turned out of doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: Then he is always plagning my babies. He says he'll get my prettiest Doll; and cut off its head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Simon had better mind his manners, or he'll be turned out of his place, when papa comes home.

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: I do think pâ will do right to turn him off if he does suffer by it, he is so forever playing the rogue.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—ROSINA, and her associates enter, screaming out with a fright.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: O MERCY help us, I never was so frighted in my life—the chamber is certainly haunted.

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: There are more than a thousand evil spirits in it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: And what a shocking noise they made? I never heard any thing before so terrible. Dear me, what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: Did you see that great something all in white—It was as big as a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: And there was something all in black. It seemed to be as big as a horse; and it had eyes like balls of fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: That was old Satan himself, I do believe; I never saw any thing so dreadful.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: And there were a thousand little white creatures that flew all about the chamber like lightening—it was the dreadfullest sight I ever saw—I never believed such things before.

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: These are serious matters ladies—and we must think of our bad actions, and be sorry, else we know not what will become of us.—I am sorry now, ladies, that I ever did any thing but what was strictly honest, we had better own the whole truth, and not tell any lies about our going out, else the black creature we saw will have us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: Yes, you know I told you so—I believe that it was he whom we saw, that it was old Satan himself—and we had better take care of ourselves—did you hear what noise he made when he trotted away? He made a noise as loud as a horse treating on a barn floor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: O dear! I shall always be afraid to go out a nights after this. (Pomposa enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pomp.
SP.P: Ladies how came you to disturb me with your noise? I have to rise early, and work hard; and I think it unkind, that when you have your lodging given you, you should disturb the whole family with your noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: We could not help it—you put us to bed in a haunted chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Pomp.
SP.P: But you have not been to bed, you are in your proper dress now—you sit up I believe on purpose to make a noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P:
No, Miss Martha gave us a candle, and we attempt∣ed to go into the chamber, and the candle burnt blue and almost went out—and I was going to take a pin, and pick open the wick; on a sudden I heard the dreadfullest noise that ever I heard in my life, and I saw something all in white, nearly as large as a man, fly off one way; and an∣other all black, which the ladies say looked as big as a horse, trotted off another way, and made a noise as loud as a horse stepping on a barn floor. The candle burnt dim and blue, and there was a strong smell of brimstone, all the while, and no one could know how many white crea∣tures were seen flying about the chamber like light∣ning.
How came you to put the ladies to bed in the chamber if you knew it to be haunted?

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: I knew nothing of the matter, nor ever believed it to be haunted—Ladies, are you not deceived?

SP.SPEAKER: Rho.
SP.P: The candle burnt very dim and blue, but we could see.

SP.SPEAKER: Lev.
SP.P: O yes, we could distinguish objects, and colors: I could see the great black creature, and the white one, and the smaller ones, all flying about: It was a dreadful sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Alm.
SP.P: I saw them plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: So did I!

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: All this is perfectly astonishing to me. I never heard of any such thing before, much less believed it.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—The same Ladies—SMILINDA enters, cry∣ing out.

SP.SPEAKER: Smil
SP.P: They shan't kill my cat! They shan't kill my cat! You won't let them kill my cat, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why who is going to kill your cat?

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: Simon says he'll kill my cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No my dear, he shall not kill her; but why does he say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Smil.
SP.P: Why, I took my white cat with all her sweet lit∣tle white kittens and I put all nine of them into Pa's bed, you can't think how pretty they looked all nine of them together—Then Simon went and got his great awful black cat, and shod her feet all round with walnut shells, stick∣ing them on with wax. And then he sent him right into the chamber amongst my cat and kittens, and at it they went, fighting, and frighted the ladies almost out of their wits, and now Simon says he'll kill my cat, because she scared the ladies, and his cat scared them full as much as mine— For he made an awful noise trotting away on his four shoes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pom.
SP.P: There ladies the matter is all out now—I advise you to go home and never steal away from your parents any more, nor frame any lies to excuse the matter; for a guilty CONSIENCE can turn nutshells into horse shoes, and cats into devils, and even do stranger things than all that.

DIV1.HEAD: The Wooden Boy. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE FOLLY OF LOCAL PREJUDICES.
DIV1.P: PERHAPS there is not a prejudice in human beings more unfriendly to society than that which improperly called local prejudice. A remarkable instance of this we have between cits and clowns—In the exer∣cise of this prejudice it is difficult to say which dis∣covers the most impenetrable stupidity. The cits commonly, however, are most insolent: the clowns have, perhaps, the most settled malice. Differing districts of the same nation often carry it almost to open hostility—How can men so far forget, that they are all of the same species, and have the same feelings?

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: MR. FREEMAN, OR JOHN HICKORY, a polite young gentleman, affecting to be a rustic.
JACK BATTLEDOOR—a boxer, affecting to be a high fellow.
CHRISTOPHER—a waiter in a boarding school.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: MYRA—a miss, favorite of Harry Plume.
SISTERS—of Mr. Freeman who appear but do not speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I WONDER what the marvellous cause can be that our young fellows do not study the art of dress!

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I think the art of boxing of much greater conse∣quence.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Dress recommends us to the ladies, dear creatures; my heart is charmed with them; tho people laugh at me, for taking notice of them because I am so young.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: But you can learn push, parry, quart and tierce, I mean to learn the art of fencing before I make preten∣sions to the ladies, and then if a man rivals me, I'll call him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I guess I'm not far from being a man, for when the miss Linnets sung last evening—they are sweet little an∣gels you know—I felt my heart go pi a pat as plain as day light. If I be not pretty near a man, I wonder what in the name of beauty, that could mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I care not, I love to throw every boy in the school of my age; and beat every one of my size in boxing—then, if I like any of the girls, I can defend myself in posses∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: But to make the girls like you, that is a serious matter, to captive their little tender souls, then you may keep them forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I would rather undertake to knock down a boy of twice my size, than to flatter a girl, or even to coax her to walk with me half a mile.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: You and I shall not agree in our notions—But do you know that we are to have a new student, in our school, to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I heard of it—They say his name is John Hick∣ory, and that he comes from the town of Brushwood, a rare wooden fellow—I dare say we shall pick fun out of him. (Enter Hotspur.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Well boys, they say we shall have a queer fel∣low come into school to day—We shall have music with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I wonder you should not have the prudence to acquaint yourself with the sweet little angels, and lrn genteel manners, as I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: If he comes I guess I shall box him, or at least I shall challenge him to wrestle with me at the first dash, that's my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I'll try, and see how he'll bear a joke. Thy say he dresses very queerly, all out of fashion. We shall joke him all to rags.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I wonder he should not dress himself when he comes to school, because that's a matter of importance.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I mean to buy me a jest book, and learn to joke by rule—It will cost only one dollar, and wit, you know, is worth every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Better lay it out in pomatum to keep your hair slick; and give it an agreeable smell; that will make the young ladies like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: When I get all the wit in the world, the ladies will like me for my wit; and then I shall be as smart as any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I am determined to learn boxing and the back sword; for if you and I travel together, as we may; when you affront a man with your wit, then I shall have to fight him.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Rare work you'll make of it, and I shall have to follow you in order to make peace. So we have business planned out for the rest of our lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: We will contrive some way to make fun of neigh∣bor Hickory—I love to take a fellow, who can't say his soul is his own, and give him a hearty sweat.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Now I had rather please one girl, than plague ten boys, and there is more amusement in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: NOTHING gives a greater lustre to learning than prudence and good morals. I cannot join you in af∣flicting our new companion, it can only render us odious.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: You never had any spirit for fun more than my grandmother—Always preaching your grum morals, what do you say Jack, shall we give up to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Not till he has had a spice of my jokes; I mean to try titles with him for the greatest wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: If he can give me a fall, or beat me in boxing, then I'll allow him to be a good fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: I'm ashamed of you both—forever in riots and mischief—a terror to the neighborhood. You'll sooner be in prison than in Congress, at this rate of proceeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: What a preacher! Let's collect money to buy him a new black coat—and he shall hold forth to the school.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: You will need no preacher. Soon the consequen∣ces of your folly will give you tormenting conviction, very soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Think I'll give back for you—I'll only go deeper —I'll get a blanket, and toss Mr. Wooden head in a blan∣ket. [Exit Martin, and after him the rest.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: SIR can you introduce me into the school?

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: No! (in a surly tone.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Why not? (complaisantly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: I have no time to wait on such wooden headed fellows—You came from the town of Brushwood—I must attend to my business.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Sir it will take you but a moment to introduce me.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: I cannot spend my time to wait on you—You have no more manners than a bear—What sort of people live, where you came from?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: A very rough unsociable people I must say to their dishonor—They will refuse to direct a stranger on his way —ask the town he came from, and tell him he has no more manners than a bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: That is pretty much as they do here.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Will you please to direct me into the common room?

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: You must first cross the yard—then turn over to the left—then you must come to the right again—then you must go back again to the left—then come to the right, and take a winding course up the back stairs into the com∣mon room.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: It is impossible to find the way by these directions. Here, I'll give you this if you will show me the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: I will wait on you sir. (Looks wishfully at the mon∣ey) But I must ask leave of absence of the master of the kitchen. [Exit Christopher.]

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: WELL, Sir what's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: John Hickory sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: What town did you come from?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Brushwood; a very remote part of the state.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: You are the fellow I have been hearing of a num∣ber of days past—they told me there was a strange, wood∣enheaded fellow coming from Brushwood, a dark obscure hole, and that he had no more manners than a bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Well what do you think of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Think of you—Why as to your own proper self, you look passably well—But then how you dress, all as far from the fashion as from Nova Scotia to Georgia—What do you mean by wearing that old bayonet-hat—Your coat is half a yard too short—oh! fun indeed! this is pretty! what a coat!—and then your hair tied up with a leather— whang — You like old Jeremy—fact!—Why sir, what sort of people are they at Brushwood?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: They are a very droll people it would make you laugh to see their manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Why, how are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick
SP.P: O they are so ridiculous, they say you love fun— it would make you die with laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I long to hear then—Let us have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P:
The first thing these coarse, rough people do, when they see a stranger—is to ask him what is his name—where
he came from—they tell him he is a fellow they have heard of before—that he is a strange wondenheaded fellow, with no more manners than a bear—then they examine his per∣son, and tell him he looks passably, but his dress is out of fashion—his hat is not right, and his coat is half a yard too long or too short—they find fault with the tying of his hair, and ask what sort of people they were in the town from whence he came.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: You lie. Those are not the manners of the peo∣ple at Brushwood.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: They are sir, and you may enquire of any person you please—They are the manners of all people who have no sense of propriety.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Very pretty indeed! and so I have no sense of pro∣priety!

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: I have never said that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: But you told the manners of the people of Brush∣wood, to be just like mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: If they be alike, you would not have me tell a lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: You are a saucy fellow; and I dare you out to box with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: There are two things more which the people at Brushwood, are very apt to do —If they do not like what a man says to them, they tell him he lies, and challenge him to box.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I won't bear this—you mean to impose upon me, I know you do—I'll knock you down.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: Stop your fire skull; what are you about to do? Fight a scholar before he enters the school—And for what? Has he ever injured you? It is not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: He has insulted me, and I won't bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: How insulted you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: He described the manners of the people of Brush∣wood to be just like mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: What then? one unmannerly fellow is just like an∣other.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: O let him alone if he has a mind to fight, let him fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: But he shall use fair play.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Fighting is fighting after all. I am not much concerned about the manner of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Yes I suppose in your Town they use the Indian hug, and strike a fellow after he is down.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: If the business is to be civil, it is best not to fight at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: That is because you are a coward. Yes, because you are a coward, I say, you refuse to fight. (with vehem∣ence.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: No sr, I do not refuse—but as you are the chal∣lenger, you must let me have the choice of weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: That's certainly fair—you can have no objection to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Then when I fight, I always fight with a large lemon in my fist—look you here, this is the way I fight, if I fight at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Battle.
SP.P: What is that for?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: The business of fighting, you see, is to hurt one another—if you bruise any one, the juice gets into the wound, and the smart it intolerable—and if you strike them in the face, the juice gets into the eyes, and the an∣guish is inconceivable. Here sir, (offers him a couple of lemons) take a couple and prepare yourself. We must hurt one another very much, before we have done—I mean to fight as long as I can move a finger. I hope if I hurt you ever so much, (civily) you will not take it ill

SP.SPEAKER: Battle.
SP.P: (looking at the lemons) 'Twould be a pity—really 'twould be a pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: What is a pity?

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: To bruise these lemons all up in fighting, it will spoil them entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Would it not spoil a man's face as much. But that is no matter—it is my way of fighting; and I have a right to chuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I think I don't want to fight much now.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: That's because you are a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Why I think—I think, I'm dry, and I want a drink of punch—had we not better make these lemons into punch, I'm very fond of punch.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: With all my heart; I love punch for that matter, as well as I love fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: I like it, so lay the lemons aside for a moment and we will have a drink of punch.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P:
[clapping Hickory on the shoulder] On my word I ask pardon for being so rough with you at first. I begin to think
you are a clever fellow. There's Hotspur a coming—don't say a word to him, that we have made all up.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—HOTSPUR, entering—the others as in the last scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Where's our new genius—Well my friend, did you come here to buy wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: I have come, I believe, to a bad market, for I do not find you have any to sell.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: He's sharp, you see, very sharp. He lives upon razors, don't you think he does?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: You had better not meddle with me then, for I have just this moment finished my dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot
SP.P: You came from Brushwood, I think, where foxes are plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Yes sir, and when I dine on razors, I have fox-brains for sauce—that makes me very keen, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: And so you mean to deal out your fox-wit by whole∣sale among us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: There is no need of that; a very small portion will serve for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I fancy you have been used to fox hunting; do yo mean to pursue it here?

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: No, I'm hunting for fools, and have had great luck—the game is plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: You will find one if you look in the glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Then I won't look, for I am satisfied with what I see already.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: How his wit bites; he stings close; he has been a pepper merchant, you may depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: Yes, and have enough of it yet to season a dozen such fellows as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: You are a proper blackguard—I am ashamed to talk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: A cur is always ashamed when he is beat.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot
SP.P: I'll be revenged on you for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: O shame on you—You began the attack, and are only angry because yau are out witted.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I'll go and call a number of boys, and I'll be re∣venged on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P:
How common it is for boys, who begin with joking, soon to get angry—I thing we may fairly draw the conse∣quence
from this; that judgment is much better than wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: AH how do ye do, my pretty Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P: You are not to be very conversant with me sir, till you behave yourself better.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Why, have I done you any harm?

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P: No, but I am told that you this day contrived to insult a new scholar, just as he was entering the school.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: That does not concern you that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P: It concerns me to keep such rude, unmannerly wretches at a due distance, I hope, you will not have ad∣mittance, where we dance this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: You are always very particular about your com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P: I wish every girl were as particular, then we should cure you of your high-goes—that is to say of your low frolics.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat
SP.P: Madam, if you are out of temper, it is not worth my while to stay here? (Exit Battle.)

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: YOUR servant Miss—I am happy in hoping for the pleasure of dancing with you, this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Myra.
SP.P: Sir if it be agreeable to you, and the company choose partners I have no objection.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: For one thing Miss you must suffer me to blame you a little gently—I saw you walking with Jack Battle∣door; he has not the best character in the school.

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P: O never fear my growing fond of his company—he seized my arm, 'tis true, but I obliged him soon to quit it —I do not like him, his manner is quite too rough.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Shall I conduct you home.

SP.SPEAKER: Myr.
SP.P:
You may if it be agreeable—tho it is but a little way —it will not be unpleasant to have company—yet now I
wish you to stay here and prevent the boys from insult∣ing Mr. Freeman. [Plume takes his leave of Myra very gen∣teelly—comes to the middle of the stage and sings.]

LG.L: sings. 'Tis the loveliest season of life,
When the spirits so merrily flow.
Our heart quickly rises with joy,
And is suddenly melted at woe.
Our minds are as simple as doves,
Our hearts yet not hardened with crimes,
Admit the first dartings of love,
And have their sweet meltings betimes.
Why, Myra came tripping to me,
So livelily over the green,
Thro all our fair village, than I,
Not a happier lad could be seen.
But when I walked o'er the green furrow,
Deeply musing on every charm,
I saw my sweet maiden with sorrow,
With another lad, locked in her arm.
Yet surely I welcome the joy,
Altho it be mixed with much pain.
The sensible heart, touched with love,
Never wished to be senseless again.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Well, Harry, wont you join us, we mean to have a high go?

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I am always afraid of you, you carry matters to such a violent extreme.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot
SP.P: You are a soft hearted thing, just fit to please the girls; and for nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: What marvellous plan have you on foot, that you urge me so much, to take a part in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: We have a scheme to take John Hickory, and toss him in a blanket.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: Have your rough play to yourself, I will have nothing to do with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Go, then, and tie yourself to the girls apron-strings; and let them coax, and wheedle, and befool you forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Plume.
SP.P: I have no taste for such rough play—It always ends in something disagreeable. As for my misses, they will soften, and polish my manners; and teach me to be a gen∣tleman. [Exit Plume.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—HOTSPUR, BATTLEDOOR, (entering here) with other boys and MARTIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: COME lads; see John Hickory cut capors in the air—We mean to toss him in a blanket.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You are forever inventing mischief. What has John Hickory done to you, that you shall bear malice against him?

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: He is a new scholar you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The very reason why he should he treated kindly —If he be not polite at present it is his unhappiness not his fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: We know more than he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Give credit to your knowledge then, and behave yourselves well.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Wonderfully wise to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ignorant people have some excuse for bad morals —but to those who profess to be the knowing ones—noth∣ing can be more infamous, than to despise the manners of civil life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: It always is the custom among scholars to play the rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: For that very reason seminaries of learning become odious. If men professing learning behave worse than they, who inhabit the woods—who can wonder that men hate the idea of a scholar—by such methods too, they are bred up to be the pests of human society—and the more learned the more pernicious they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: But seminaries of learning are the resorts of polite∣ness— the seats of the muses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: They ought to be; but such fellows as you give them the character of the seats of illiberality, and vice. If we find in colleges and acadamies, the rough stoic, the contemptuous cynic, the coarsest pedants, and the sons of riot, and debauchery, who can wonder if the public con∣ceives an aversion to such societies?

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: A fig for your morals—There are your high fel∣lows in all the seminaries of learning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, a worthy object to be sure. To study one, two▪ three, or four years, in some seminary of learning—to qualify ourselves, to get drunk as brutally as porters, and grooms—to introduce ourselves to vicious women, who af∣ter all prefer the assassin and street robber—and to ac∣quire an aversion to modest ladies, to be embarrassed, and know not how to speak to them. One need not reside in a college to learn these things—They may be learned in tav∣erns, and gaming houses to perfection.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Come on, boys—down with this preacher—Does he think we came here to hear sermons of terror? Let us all fall on, have him in the blanket, and give him a shak∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Stand off you villains; if you attack me, I shall defend myself. [Hickory enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: Well he is a great heavy lubber, we will let him alone; and take Hickory; he is the very man we want.

SP.SPEAKER: Hick.
SP.P: What do you mean, by this rude assault on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: Silence ye young villains—Let this young gentle∣man alone—unhand him. There now, be easy; or I will bring every soul o you before the government.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: I SEE we are likely to have no fun to day—I will go and see some of the misses—I do that when I can find nothing better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: What would you have better, than to recommend yourself to the best part of the human species?

SP.SPEAKER: Hot▪
SP.P: Why do not our instructors then let the masters and misses perform their excercses togeher—or why in schools where they study together, do they make them sit in different parts of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: It is to save them the pain of being corrected in the presence of each other—to preserve their delicacy, and ncrease their muual espect—There is nthing which makes the intercours of men and women so happy as pre∣serving mutual respect ad esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: On my word, I believe you are right, for I have found when we had been from the misses all day—and had a nice genteel dance after school—it was the finest pleas∣ure, I ever experienced in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's always the case—The more decent and proper we are in conversation with women, the more we enjoy heir society, which is in fact, and truth, the greatest blessing of human life

SP.SPEAKER: Bat
SP.P: That's what I have not tho't of so much before— But there seems to be good sense and reason in what you say.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.—TALBOT, (entering) HOTSPUR, BATTLEDOOR, and MARTIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Tal.
SP.P: YOUNG men you are very fortunate indeed, that you did not meddle with Hickory, for he is indeed a very genteel young man—He lived in Brushwood but one fort∣night—as he knew you to be saucy, he contrived this way to mortify you; so he makes you the fools of the play. His real name is Freeman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, boys you will be mortified with a witness.— The wooden boy you laughed at is realy as genteel a lad as any in the school, and has permission to invite the young gentlemen and ladies to a dance after school.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: O I shall die to appear before him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: I must excuse myself—How he must despise me— I may as well be annihilated as to appear before him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I have often told you, young gentlemen, that you would bring yourselves io disgrace by such proceedings— But see, he is coming with his two sisters—sweet girls as ever lived. He looks like a Wooden Boy to be sure.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.—Mr. FREEMAN entering with his two Sisters, richly dressed.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: GENTMEMEN, I have the honor to invite you to dance with my sisters, and a number of the other misses after school; at the house of Mrs. Careful, the Governess.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: Mr. Freeman I ask a thousand pardons—if I had but known you I should not—

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: No matter, it afforded me some amusement—no matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: If you will only pardon my jokes. I was wrong, perfectly wrong, I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I think sir, your jokes were quite harmless. Gen∣tlemen I shall wait on you at four. [Exit Freeman.]

DIV3.STAGE: (Battledoor and Hotspur walk across the stage, with their heads down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hot.
SP.P: My jokes quite harmless—That is worse than all the rest—He must think meanly of me, and cannot think otherwise. In fact, I feel very small.

SP.SPEAKER: Bat.
SP.P: And I too, as small as a mouse—I wish I had been in France before ever I heard of the Wooden Boy.

LG.HEAD: MARTIN Epiloguizes.
LG.L: We see, in contests of the prize of wit;
The biter oft by his own malice bit.
In circles, boasting of politeness, find
Low manners the disgrace of human kind.
Ignorance in colleges may find a place;
And profligacy in a man of grace.
Cits think that Clowns are brutes, and Clowns again,
Esteem poor Cits the dullest sons of men.
The town Belle sneers at every rural lass—
The lass despising madam, lets her pass.
Thus mutual prejudice, and malice reign;
And all the joys of social life profane.
Yet banish prejudice, and love revives,
And social bliss, in fields, or cities, lives.

DIV1.HEAD: Bernard of Berlin. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE ABSURDITY OF PROFUSENESS.
DIV1.P: THERE is in many persons of some plausible qual∣ities, a great vanity of spending money profusely. It is lavished away on parasites and flatterers, who give their patron nothing but empty praise.— And it is commonly the case, that they who help a man to spend his estate profusely, are the first to desert him in distress, if not upbraid him with his folly.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: BERNARD OF BERLIN—a man of excessive hospitality.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: WHO lives in this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: Nobody lives here.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: Is not the house inhabited?

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: Here my master starves, with his wife, and fam∣ily, and myself.—We are starved to death all of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: You have no regard to decency, to be starved to death, and yet walking about and transacting business.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: We are in no danger of being called to an ac∣count—We have no business to follow, and are grown by starving so thin and so pale, that were we examined on the qualifications of ghosts, there would not be a wretch of us all, but would pass muster.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: You have lost your manners as well as your flesh— Who stays in this house? I ask again.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris
SP.P: Bernard, sir my master Bernard.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: Has he no other name but my master Bernard?

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: Why sir there are a number of Bernard's in this town, there is one who was a man of figure—Is that the man you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: Describe his particular quality or business.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: There are two Bernards noted men in this city. One is a poet and a man of wit—He is as social a fellow as eve you saw, he'd entertain you with his fine verses.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: The Bernard, I want, is the Bernard who gives such good dinners. I have heard an exellent character of him —I am tired, faint, and hungry, coming off from a journey, and have a better relish for a good sirlin of beef, than for the finest verses in the world. Will you tell me at last what your masters' name is.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P:
Why sir, he has been so popular in his day, that
they called him Bernard of Berlin—No man has ever given better dinners—But he can give them no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: Why, if that be the case, I will dine at the tavern. But, I respect his memory, and will call and see him after dinner. (Exit Bryssen—Bernard enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: THERE is a man knocking, introduce him. (Chris∣tiern introduces him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: Sir, here is a note which is become due.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Due to whom? (Exit Christiern.)

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: To a neighbor here in Berlin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Go to my steward.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: He has already put me off, from day to day— The holder of the note wants the money, and must be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Persuade him to wait till tomorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: I cannot sir. It must be put in suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Eye, you may ruin a responsible man by sending him at once to prison. Here take this (gives him money) and ask him to wat a month longer, not ruin me and my whole family.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: You talk enough to break one's heart. (Chinking the money) I will try to persuade him. But with a little exertion you can pay this other.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I cannot answer that neither. Can you nor put it off till next week?

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: Perhaps I may by some persuading, for which I ought to be payed. But here is another.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: O conscience, what? another!

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: Yes, another; and he says he must have speedy payment. The sum is less than either of the others—I hope you will pay this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I cannot pay that nether — But how came I over head and ears in debt? Is it possible that my steward has done his duty, Brusch—Tell Widdel to step here in a mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: Pay this last note by to morrow or it will be put in suit, (Goes out surlily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: HOW came my state so deranged! Why did you not tell me of it?
