SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I did a great many times, but you put me off.— You told me I was honest, and that you would look into it another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: You must sell off some of my land.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid
SP.P: It is all sold, except one little dark spot in the cor∣ner of Silesia, hardly fit for a coblers stall. This will hardly satisfy your present creditors; what is to be done for the future I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: But there was not a village from Berlin to Dant∣zick, that I had not a farm in, or near it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: True—but when it cost you 1000 acres for a feast, or you gave away 10000 in a breath—had you possessed all Europe, in one farm, it soon would have been gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: What you say is reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: If you suspect my honesty, or truth, I'll settle my accompts in presence of a magistrate—But I must tell you▪ that your feasts, revels, illuminations▪ balls, and what not, at such an excessive charge, have often made me retire to a corner and weep.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Prithee say no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Then, what fellows those were who praised you.— Count Bernard! the noble Bernard; and Bernard of Ber∣lin; who had every man's hand, head and heart at his ser∣vice—now your fortune is gone they are as still as flies af∣ter a summer's storm.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Finish your discourse—I will apply to my friends— I have mines in their hearts, and treasures in their inmost souls—I can get favors from my friends as easily as I can speak the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I wish you may find it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Never mind it▪ Widdel, my wants are my blessings —You shall see that I am rich in friends, tho I be low in cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I have the warmest wishes for your success.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Here▪ Brusch, come in an instant. Go to Count Anspach; ask him to lend me 200 pounds; to Goltz, and ask him for 150; to Srsmund, the miser; ask him for 100; to Keenspruck▪ the architect: ask him to lend me 50. for he has had many a good job by my means—I ad∣vanced to the city magistrates £ 3000 in a time of diffi∣culty; I shall ask £. 1000 of them▪

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I wish you may be succesful, but I greatly fear you will not. [Exit Widdel.—Gertrude enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: DEAR sir, what are we to dine upon to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Upon victuals, what do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: But the cook says there is not a mouthful of any kind of provisions in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: We shall have plenty in a few minutes. I have sen my servant to borrow money of my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: If that be the case we may fast and reckon upon fasting—we will lay i up against a fast day comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: What, my dear, we will not be uncharitable to∣wards our friends—They cannot be so ungenerous as not to relieve our wants.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: Heaven bless your hopes, my husband, and render them successful: but much I fear, that we must keep lent, for many days to come, in spite of all our friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: O woman—woman! how suspicious you are—I wonder you had faith enough to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: I should not, if I had dreamt of starving in con∣sequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Well, well—I'll expedite the servants, and get a supply, the moment my money arrives. [Exit Gertrude.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Anspach enters, then Brusch.—ANSPACH and BRUSCH.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: MY master Bernard wishes your health and prosperity.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: Here, take a glass of my bell wine, you are wel∣come above all men—Here take another glass—How does that complete gentleman your master do, whom I love as my life?

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Very well, as to health, very well indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: And what hast thou got under thy cloak? Some genteel present from your master. I dreamt last night he gave me a silver tankard.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: I have no silver tankard sir, for you.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P:
Something more elegant. Your master shows
his genteel taste always in his presents—a pair of diamond buckles, perhaps. O, I love him as my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: No sir he is in want: he sends this empty box for you to fil. He asks 200 pounds, not doubting but you'll supply him.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: Ah! not doubting—Why I told him when I dined with him last, I was afraid he spent too fast on his capital.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: And then came to supper to tell him to spend less.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: Liberty was always his fault. But you are an arch fellow—you know these times.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: What of the times sir?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: That no-body pretends in these times to lend money upon friendship, without security.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: My master has lent you three times the sum with∣out security.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: Yes, and I took it because I wanted it. But I tho't him imprudent, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Shall I say that to my master?

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: No, take this piece; and say I was not at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Thank you sir, I will not tell a scandalous lie for three shillings. [Exit C. Anspach.—Goltz enters]

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: ILLUSTRIOUS magistrate, that gentleman, Bernard of Berlin, sends to know of your health.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: Ha, has he sent to me, and what has he sent? He is the genteelest man on earth in sending a present.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: O sir, he will make no more presents He sends this empty box for you to fill—He desires you to lead him 150 pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: He is only merry, he has ten times that sum to spare!

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: No sir, he is in present want; or he would never have troubled his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: Hah! in present want do you say? How then will he be able to pay?

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: He was kind to you, in difficulties; and expected a return.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: What a perfect fool, and scoundrel I was; that no more than three days ago, I made a purchase that swept off every stiver of my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Then you will not upply him.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: Why just before you came in I was going to send to my lord Bernard, to borrow, which I scarce would have done for the worth of all Germany. Give him my most sin∣cere respects; tell him my utter inability; and beg him to conceive in the fairest manner of my intentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Shall I tell him you will not?

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: No, sir, tell him I cannot, and that it is a mortal affliction to me. (Exit. Goltz▪)

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: (alone) And is this the return you make for all my master's kindess to you—Well there remains old Strass∣mund the miser. I will see what I can do with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: MASTER Bernard sends his respects to you sir, and asks the loan of a hundred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Strass.
SP.P: How came he to think of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Why he sent to lord Anspach, and Goltz; but they proved of base temper; they gave him no relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Strass.
SP.P: And so he sends to me the last of all—I was the first man that received a present of him; the first who was invited to dinner by him; and now that he should send to me the last— I will not lend him a farthing—I am down∣right affronted with him. Exit Strassmund,

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: There is no one who now remains but old Keen∣spruck the architect—whom my master took out of prison; and gave him many a fine job—I will try him, and then I have executed my master's orders. [Keenspruck enters.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—BRUSCH and KEENSPRUCK.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: MASTER Bernard sends to you sir, his most sincere respects.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: What job does he want me to do now? I'll not do another so cheap as I did the last; but I don't per∣fectly understand you—I am hard of hearing, you know. Come close to me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Master Bernard is in want of cash, which is the worst situation in the world for building.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P:
Hah! the situation—Don't he like the situation of the building. Then let him build somewhere else. There
is room enough in the world to build upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: He does not want to build r. He has built too much already —He wants to borrow fifty pounds of you —and if it please you, I call upon you for it by his order.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: The order please me? Let him please himself about the order—If he does not like the Ionic or Tuscan orders which are very plain; let him take the Corinthian, which is very grand.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: My master does not want to build. He has built too much already. He wants to borrow money; he has a number of little debts which he wishes to square off.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Square roof. It seems he don't like a square roof— He may have a bevil if he pleases, or a common pitched roof.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: It is no such thing—Sir, my master is a little out of cash at present—he wants fifty pounds, if you will do it for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Do it for him, yes if he will pay me well—But I must have the dimensions of the building, before I can tell what to charge for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: You know what I mean well enough, you old knave. (In a low voice.)

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: Aye, who is a knave? Not I, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Will you come, and dine with my master imme∣diately?

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: O yes by all means; the gentleman is very kind— (Brusch goes out, Keenspruck looks after him, then walks across the stage and speaks.) Thanks to my old deaf ear, I have escaped—He was so anxious and so uneasy: I knew the dog wanted to borrow money by his phiz.

DIV3.STAGE: [Exit, and assoon as he is out Bernard enters, and soon after his daughter.]

SP.SPEAKER: Cath.
SP.P: MY mother sends to you to know if you are like∣ly to have any thing for dinner to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Bern.
SP.P: Then tell her not to be anxious; we shall have it soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cath.
SP.P: She seems almost out of patience; and if any com∣pany comes in, we have nothing in the world to set before them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: I am not anxious about that. If they furnish mon∣ey, then we can furnish them a dinner. Or otherwise we make them welcome to the best we have—If we have no∣thing I mean to invite them all to dine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cath.
SP.P: O dear sir do not expose us in that manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Yes, by all means, and let them see how olks live who live upon nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cath.
SP.P: O sir, I should be so mortified I should leave the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: You must not be affrighted at that; we may all soon he obliged to leave the house.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.— Bernard enters, then Widdel. BERNARD, WIDDEL and BRUSCH.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: WHAT not one of them lend me a farthing?

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: Not one upon my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Go immediately and invite every one of them to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Brusch.
SP.P: I could not have tho't there had been so much ingratitude in mankind—I tho't they might have some sense of obligation; but he who is smitten of the disease of poverty is shunned of the human species.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I have long known it to be so. The warmest trencher friends, when a man is in distress, would deny him even the crumbs of charity. [Scruter enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: (surlily) THE last note I had against you sir is put in suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: It is just as agreeable to me as any way—Let my creditors take all I possess, if they will be content with that.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: If you remain here in Berlin they will not be con∣tent till they have you in prison. [Exit Scruter.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ger
SP.P: MY dear, you must take care of yourself—I have found out that tomorrow they mean to put u in jail.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: There is a great favor my dea▪ I repected they would have done it to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: I tremble for the consequences. We must flee immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Will you go with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: It is my design to live and die with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Let me have my wife; and they may take my for∣tune▪ I shall be richer than they all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ger.
SP.P: Sir, you are still a gentlema; and the more is the pity that you will not have a fortune. [Exit Gertrude.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—PACH, GOLTZ, STRAMD, SCRUTER, and KSPRUCK, all come in together.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: I HAVE done myself the honor to wait on you according to your obliging commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz.
SP.P: I thank you for your invitation. You are a com∣pleat gentleman, not to flatter a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Strass
SP.P: I am sorry you did not send first to me to borrow money—I cannot get it over.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: I love to be invited to dinner▪ it saves all the ex∣pense, and trouble, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Scru.
SP.P: I suppose your good ear was offered to this invi∣tation—I wnder, far the advantage of it, that I never tho't of being deaf of one ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen
SP.P: You can be deaf of both ears; when you find it to advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Strass
SP.P: Neighbor Bernard you have invited us to dinner, but you show us nothing of dinner yet—To be a little free, what are we to have for dinner to day.— (Bernard goes to a table which is coveed with a clean cloth uncovers it, and discov∣ers the table laid with a ragged table-cloth, broken dishes, knives, forks, &c and not a mouthful of victuals.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Just what you gentleman helped me to—Had I ob∣tained any thing, you should have been welcome; but since I obtained nothing you are as welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: C. Ans.
SP.P: I think you treat us very scandalously, master Bernard.

SP.SPEAKER: Goltz
SP.P: You might be ashamed to treat gentlemen in this manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Strass▪
SP.P: I shall not consider you after dinner▪ as I ∣ed to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Keen.
SP.P: I shall turn a deaf ear as I do on all such occa∣sions.— They all go out angrily and hastily—he hurls the dishes &c. and kicks the table after them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: Adieu my dear friends adieu, love you as my eyes love smoke, or as my mouth warm water▪—You in∣gy, deceitful, worthless vermin▪ begone! (After he has clear∣ed the stage he returns to the middle of the stage—and speaks.) Now I could curse these detested Parasites; is there lanuage strong enough to do it in—The sum of all my curses is that they may be as they are—that's bad enough.

DIV3.STAGE: [Bryssen enters with Bernard's wife and friends.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.P: HAVE I one friend left?

SP.SPEAKER: Brys.
SP.P: Yes, you have one, who knew you not, except in fame, till this day —I heard of your affairs, and pity you most sincerely. I live in Silesia near the little farm which you have left. It is worth near five hundred pounds— You may make a safe retreat to this little spot—where if you cannot live in splendor—you may be honest and inde∣pendent of every man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Bernard shall seek Silesia's gres and find,
The fiercest brute more friendly than mankind.
SP.P: I will go with my wife and daughter. You, Widdel, and Brusch may if you please go with me—I have been ex∣tremely mortified, and mankind seem excessively cruel— But how can I justly blame them for not taking care of me; when it is evident, that I did not take care of myself?

DIV1.HEAD: The Rogue proved honest▪ A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE EXCELLENCE OF THE GENERAL PRINCI∣PLE OF A FREE COMMONWEALTH.
DIV1.P: A SENSE of liberty infuses life and activity thro a whole commonwealth—And not only are particular laws a security to the citizen, but a greater securi∣ty arises from the general principle of liberty— That in every instance will cause the presumption to be made in favor of the accused citizen; that he is innocent, and that the sufferings of the innocent will by that means be prevented—Happy above all people are they of the United States, if they know their own good.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: ESQ. RIGHTWAYS—a justice of the peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: SISTER I wish you to lend your attention to me a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: As long as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: Have you heard any thing bad of me in this neighborhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Certainly your character is given out as extreme∣ly bad; and you are threatened with a prosecution for several very high crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I hope that gives you no uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: It certainly does, and I can scarcely sleep because of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I am sorry if it affects you so disagreeably, it cer∣tainly gives me very little disturbance.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I am astonished at your calmness; for I am told, there is one prosecuion against you for false coinage, an∣other for highway robbery, and another for forgery—They say the proofs are all flagrant against you, and you cannot escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I defy them all to hurt me; and yet I do not sup∣pose that one of them owes me any malice. Just so prone are human kind to believe every thing that is bad concern∣ing a man who falls into distress in his affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: But by what means do you expect to support your∣self, when so many false accusations ga her round? by what means will you be extricated?

SP.SPEAKER: Jam
SP.P: I suppose twenty witnesses might be brought who ou I swear against me and yet all be honest and believe they swore to the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P:
My brother, you don't say so, I almost think you
guilty myself how could it be, unless you have been very wcked▪ you never can clear yourself of them; and how do you expect it?

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I have no money to defend myself with▪ I cannot a present procure a single witness in my favor—All my dependence is upon the author of all truth; and the testi∣mony of my own conscience, and they being on my side, are all the witnesses I need.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I wish you may find it so, in the conclusion of your affairs—but I am on the rack with anxiety day and right on your account.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: Be quiet my sister—Never believe that he who brings the righteous into affliction; has not power to bring them out again. (Exit Jamison.)

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: SERVANT, Miss Clara, your servant—where is your brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: He has this moment gone out.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Why miss Clara, there is an old racket in this neigh∣borhood about your brother, what has he done?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: He has always been an honest man from a child▪ the kindest brother that lives to his sisters, the most dutiful son to his parents, whom he his with the tenderest care supported in their feeble, and decriped state. And now he has the tears of the poor, since he has fallen into distress, witnessing in his favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Why I was at the alehouse last evening and they called him all the rascals in the world, I tho't if half they said was true, I would not give one of my old boots for his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: They talk frightfully about him I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Well and can't he have them up for it, I'd bring 'em corum nobus—If they talked so about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: He is more anxious, lest he should be prosecuted himself, than how he shall prosecute others.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Well this is a proper harum scarum world, all things go hoity toity, head over heels. I have hitherto taught my children to be honest and trust providence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Well, I hope you do not mean to teach them otherwise in time to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P:
I have been thinking whether men get any thing by being honest, or whether some men did not cry up
honesty that they might the better cheat their neighbors— I have lost many a hundred pounds by being honest, and among great folks it is a of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Yes, and perhaps gained thousands by it at other times—Do you suppose that you should have been worth what you are if you had not had a reputation for being honest?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Aye there you have it now, you are a cunning little puss. (claps her on the shoulder) I love to hear you talk dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: My clothes don't want brushing sir; or if they do we will not trouble you to do it, I mean to be honest, tho my brother be ever so unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Por
SP.P: But supposing now, just for the notion on' that what we call vice had been called virtue, and what we call virtue had been called vice?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Supposing what we call white had been called black and what we call black had been called white— would it have altered the nature of those colors?

SP.SPEAKER: Port.
SP.P: But then would we not have been as much pleas∣ed with black, as we are with white? there, I guess I've got you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No sir, supposing ratsbane had been called butter, then we might eat it on bread without harm—or suppos∣ing butter were called ratsbane, then it would poison us, would it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: That's sly now—and I will own you have got some wit—but supposing that no man had any thing of his own but every thing was earned by every body, and every body had aright to it—all things in common.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Why then some would do nothing but live on the earnings of other people, while only a few would have to maintain all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Why girl you reason away stoutly now—can you tell me girl why a woman is called the weaker vessel—it is not because she is naturally more shallow—that is a little too bad too—I mean whether she has not naturally less understanding than a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I suppose sir, that a great iron pot, will bear a stouter blow than a china bowl, but I do not know that of consequence it is more valuable—or in fact worth more.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: People will have their different fancies about that— you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Well sir, from certain circumstances I judge that men are weaker than women, and have less understand∣ing—are not all the whims and extravagances of learning invented by men—the ideal system—denial of providence, atheism, or putting nature instead of God▪ Mischance agen∣cy, scepticism concerning morals &c. which have de∣ranged society and corrupted mankind. Are they not all inventions of men? Women in general despise such notions—and they refer all their ideas to use and benefit— they value no learning but which is profitable—and refer all study to its moral use. I appeal to facts for this. Is it any sign of weakness in their understanding?

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Why ah—hem—ah—as for that—hem—I hardly know what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: However I will be candid—I will allow men have as much sense as women—but I detest all principles that weaken the obligations of morality—our happiness depends on right conduct, and however calumiated my brother is, I would have him be strictly honest—nor make use of any art or evasion, to avoid suffering—He had better follow truth even if he suffers for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: BUT then as to that master you are right; you don't approve that girls should have much learning, it nonsuits their understanding. [Exit Poterson]

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Your understanding (curtsying) was never non∣suited that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: But then it is my opinion, that women should learn to spin, and knit, to mend clothes; and darn stock∣ings.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: So it is mine. They ought to learn all those matters—I will put it stronger, they ought to be very at∣tentive and diligent in these things—But if they have as much learning besides, as they have opportunity to ac∣quire; I do not suppose it does them any harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: I think that women have no business with much learning—they had better keep to their kniting, patching, and mending, &c. and washing dishes &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P:
Sir, I suppose you do not know it. Such observa∣tions hurt the tender feelings of my sex—we have as lively a taste for knowledge as you—It becomes us as well—What
or has befallen the authoress of the Coquette? Or did Montague disgrace her self by her Letters? Would not many men be proud to write ke Pilenia?

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: They had better mind their own business.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: How would you like it sir, if the women should say of you that it would have been better for you, if you had been confined all your days to the spade and plough, instead of pettifogging and setting neighbors to quarrel— or what would some Doctors of Theology say, if we had said concerning them, that it were well if they had mend∣ed shoes instead of making sermons. I respect the pro∣fession of the law too much; and certainly I respect the re∣ligious profession too much, to make any such observations. Yet I do not know but such observations are altogether as good natured, and as just, as those which are thrown out by some men against the education of women.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Well, I know this▪ your brother is a villain, & I intend to prosecute him to the utmost rigor of the law. I guess his sisters won't get him out of my hands▪

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I do not know that they will, but I guess they will try.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: WELL Mr. Ready-cash—what's your com∣plaint against young Jamison.

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: Why he passed a number of counterfeited bank notes, here to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: And do you believe he counterfeited them him∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: Yes; for they were all altered with a pen, and every body knows that he is in very low circumstances as to estates—and there is a great probability that he did it for his own benefit.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Well, and have you no further evidence against him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: Yes, he urged me very much to take them, and I thought he appeared very uneasy because I did not take them readily.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: But you took them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: Yes, I took them, and passed them to his credit▪ but they are certainly counterfeits—I paid him some in hard cash for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Well, mind this, if you mean to get recomence, you must swear plumpy—perhaps the Justice won't lit you much about your oath—and as you really believe that he did counterfeit the bills, you may swear plumply

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: WELL, Miss Muslin, I understand you have some∣thing against young Jamison he is an anointed rogue I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, sir, he called upon me the other day with an order in his brother's name, saying, that his brother had given him power of attorney to draw in his absence —he got the goods; now since he is uneasy in his circumstances I felt concerned about it; and called upon him to show the evidence of his right, and his power to draw in his brother's name; he could not show any, and pretended he had lost the paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Aye he is rogue enough, but I shall catch him yet, lawyers are the only men for such matters. These facts you can attest to because you must be sworn to your dep∣osition.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Aye, I know that, and I have asserted nothing but what I can prove—I observed him well he lookod con∣cerned and uneasy, and he has for these many days: and I guess by that, he has some schemes on foot which are not right.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Do you know any thing about Jamison's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Yes, they say she is confederate with him in all his villanies. (Exit Muslin.)

SP.SPEAKER: Non
SP.P: SO madam, how does Jamison do to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jam▪
SP.P: He is very well sir — but none the better for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: None the better for me? but I intend he shall be— I intend to cure him of his vices, and then he will be a better man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jam.
SP.P: That he will be persecuted by you with all possible malice, I doubt not; but I believe he will triumph over you all finally.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Why do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Jam.
SP.P: Because I believe he is a very honest man, nay I know he is so.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: But the proofs against him are very pointed—Cer∣tainly you cannot get over them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jam.
SP.P: It is possible to make truth appear what it is —but you will not be able to make it appear otherwise by all your craft.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: If that be the, case what is all the artifice of our pro∣fession good for?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jam.
SP.P: Good for nothing, I suppose—but when you deal honestly, you, like all other men, appear respectable— I hope you will lay that to heart. [Exit Mrs. Jamison.]

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: AYE, Mc. Mullock, you are a principal witness against Jamison.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: Yez zur, please your honor—I swore against him, may't please your honor with all ray might—I could not have swore stronger if I had been to die for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Now your oath may be depended on a substantial evidence, because you was an eye-witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: O yes, may it please your honor, I was an eye-wit∣ness—for our Nab saw it with her own eyes; and she told me first of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: But that will weaken your testimony if you own that Nab saw it; and not yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: Aye but, Nab sir is my own flesh, and Nab's eyes are my eyes, may please your honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Aye but that won't do—you cannot swear to that which was seen by another person.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: I know I can sir —I can swear to any thing I please —I'll lay a mug on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: I mean you cannot with truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: Aye that another matter — you did not say about my swearing to the truth—you only asked me if I could swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Well I've got your deposition—are you ready to swear to it, be it what it may?

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: O yes I could swear all day, if you will pay me r't—But a man's a fool to swear without pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Be ready then when you're called.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: DO you mean to take Mc. Mullock's oath against my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Yes, why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: You know he cannot be depended on. He may be an honest man or may not be; but he is a stranger among us, and we know nothing of his character.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: We don't know it is a bad one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: And we don't know it is a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: That's nothing; if no exception can be made against a witness, his testimony is good in law.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: I know better—It is not in all cases; because when a man's character is unknown there can be no depen∣dance on his veracity.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: Do you think you know law better than I?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: I know that is no law which is not agreeable to reason—and certainly it is not agreeable to reason to take the oath of a foreigner, an unknown person, against a citizen of known established good character.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: These are fine times indeed; when women must meddle with laws.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—JUSTICE RIGHTWAYS, NONSUIT, JAMISON, READY-CASH, MLIN and Mc. MULLOCK.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: MR. Attorney—Where are the depositions which have been sworn to?

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: They are here, the very same, which your wor∣ship has perused so carefully, before you appeared to be sat∣isfied with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Why yes—it appears to me that there is suffi∣cient cause for committing him—What have you to say for yourself Jamison? Have you any objection to the stae of e evidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: Nothing sir, yet I know my own innocence—I have two good witnesses on my side—My own consciece, and he who gave it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: What signifies it for him to speak of his witnesses, his conscience, and all that, when the facts are so plain against him? I move for his commitment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: I think I have a right to expect he will be com∣mitted without delay for trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I cannot but expect will be? for I am sure, if I lose my debt, he ought to be punished for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mc.
SP.P: Aye indeed may it please your worship—if he be not trounced for't, the next time I go abroad, I shall not dare to stir a foot from home—I should expect he would rob me of my money if I had not a farthing in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I beg your worship will let me have one hour's respite; perhaps some witness may arrive who may make my innocence appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Can you specify any one?

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: Indeed I cannot sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Then I do not se any cause for delaying pro∣cedings—It may be a more fetch to gain time to effect a rescue—or something of that sort—Make out his mittimus Mr▪ Attorney and let the constable take him to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I see nothing now but I must suffer. It will be the work of providence. f I escape —for if I be committed —then there is no money nor power among my friends to procure one witness in my favor—yet I know myself inno∣cent.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: I wish you would make that fellow hold his tongue —I desire to know what all this is to the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Silence, Jamison, silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jam.
SP.P: PERMIT me Mr. Justice to intercede my husban—You must know that it must be a terrible event to my family; if he should be taken from it. What is more distressing than the state of a woman, left with a family of small children, without a protector? And what would add to my distress is that I have my husband's fath∣er, and mother, aged people to look after, who cannot help themselves. Tho I cannot at present give any partic∣ular reason, yet I beseech your worship to give my hs∣band the respite of one half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: They give no reason, they mean to raise a mob and rescue him, or some way effect his escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Ready.
SP.P: I cannot think he ought to be respited.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: I shall not consent to it, Mr. Justice—and if you respite him, I'll complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Order, I say, order—I hope you won't interfere in my department—I must say, notwithstanding there is no reason given for it specially, that the respite of half an hour ought to be granted—No one knows what may come of it—Perhaps some person in that time may appear in his favor—You ought to esteem yourselves happy to be born in a commonwealth, where the rights of citizens are held sacred; and where it is so difficult to restrain any one of his liberty. I grant the privilege to this man now. It is the privilege of you all▪ that your liberties are held thus sacred. You ought to love your country and laws, else you are the most ungrateful people in the world. On this principle, upon which our whole government rests — that the liberty of the citizen is sacred—I grant this prisoner another half hour for his defence.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—MISS CLARA, RIGHTWAYS, BETTY, and MUSLIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: I COME, oh I am out of breath, oh my brother is nor committed.

SP.SPEAKER: Right
SP.P: What's your will miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Here sir, this I got sworn to before Justice Quick∣sight, and here's the girl who will attest it before you to the same purpose—She saw the instance in which it is said that Jamison was guilty of robbery—Was eye witness to the whole affair, it was mere accident that I found her— She mentioned something about a young man's being ac∣cused of robbery—I told her it was my brother—She then related the circumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: What do you say, Betty Laundress, I think your name is.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P:
Why, I saw a man go up to Mr. Jamison, hold a pistol to his breast and demand his money—Mr. Jamison delivered, but the robber had only turned a corner not ten yards distance, before the robber's feet slipped, and I saw Mr. Jamison catch a pistol, which the robber dropped in his
fall, and sprang on the robber, and redemanded the money and got it.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: This you can swear to.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: Yes, sir, I saw the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: What did you do with the money? just now you complained you had none.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I bought some medicines for my poor aged father who is very sick.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: There for miss Muslin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mus.
SP.P: Betty, hold your tongue about me, or I never will employ you in my business again.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: I shall not say any harm of you madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Say away Betty, you have as good a right to speak as any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Betty.
SP.P: I heard master Jamison had got into difficulty— thought it might do some good to give his sisters these pa∣pers, which I nd in the pockets of one of his waistcoats, which he sent me to wash.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: Here sir is the power which my brother, who is gone to the West Indies, gave to him to transact any matter of trade for him and in his name, see.

SP.SPEAKER: Righ.
SP.P: Very good, this is very good, but as to the coinage, how will you clear yourself of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: I know not yet, I know I am innocent.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.—Mrs. ROBERTS, RIGHTWAYS, CLARA, NONSUIT and JAMISON.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: SIR let me speak a word with the justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Speak madam if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: There Squire Firm-trust, and my brother had been playing at whist and they changed accidentally two papers which had bank notes in them, and my brother took up a paper in which the notes were all counterfeit. The Squire has rode 150 miles in days and half, in order to rectify the mistake—Here the true notes are for the banker.

SP.SPEAKER: Clara.
SP.P: What say you now, Mr. Nonsuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: This comes of giving girls learning, they take the business of the law all out of our hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. R.
SP.P: A great evil no doubt to defend the innocent; we have done nothing these three days but pick up evidence in favor of our brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Jam.
SP.P: Heaven bless you my good girls. (bowing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Right.
SP.P: Now learn my friends to revere the ways of providence, which bring unexpected relief to oppressed in∣nocence, by which honesty is safe, and render your fer∣vent thanks for your constitution of government, which considers the liberty of a citizen as his most sacred treasure.

DIV1.HEAD: The Little Box. A DRAMATIC DIALOGUE, IN THREE ACTS.
MODERATION IS NECESSARY IN POLITICS— FOR JUSTICE WILL HAVE ITS PROPER TIME.
DIV1.P: THERE is the assemblage of all the virtues in a true politician. He is impartial with regard to parties, and his connections with foreign powers— He respects religion and those who administer its ordinances—He is not moved by violent attachment or aversion to individuals—He treats none with contempt; for they who make no great show in the eyes of the public, may have strong connections with the essential interests of the State—He is not bigotted to his own opinions.—In one word, no man can be a thorough politician, but an able, and good man.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: TIMOCLES—Grand Secretary of the State of Syracuse.
HAMILCAR—his rival in party and politics.
HIERO—an old politician, uncle to Timocles.
A PARASITE—one who affects the character.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: PARTY rage is indeed a dreadful passion.— My whole life has been devoted to the state. I have equally opposed the influence of Carthage, and Rome, and have met with no reward but persecution.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Timocles is against you, he represents you as a person endeavoring to overturn the state, and place yourself at the head of affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: What pretet have they against me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: That you are a stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: So much is true, that when my infant mind first knew reflection; twas in the arms of a Carthaginian, who named me after his general; yet Syracuse, my native state, was always the object of my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I wish they who oppose you had half of your zeal for the public good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: Love for the state is certainly my ruling passion. I love money; but I have neglected my private fortune for the state. I have often wished to marry the delicious girl, who has honored me with her affections, but the busi∣ness of the state has wholly engrossed my attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I observed you one day talking to yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: And listened like a rogue I suppose to hear what I said.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Yes, and I expected to have heard the name of the fair Philesia—but I heard you say, O Syracuse! charm∣ing Syracuse, my dear native city. Shall the Carthagin∣ians insult over thee? Shall the Romans ru thee with a rod of iron? No I will redeem thy prosperity with all that is dear to me, with the last drop of my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P:
Such are my constant thoughts, if I do not always
thick publicly—use your influence my worthy friend to mitigate the public rage against me, and set mine actions in a proper light. (Exit Hamilcar.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: GUARD against traitors—every man in the in∣terest of Carthage is a traitor. We had better fall into the hands of Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I cannot understand your politics; if the state must be subject to foreign power, it is of little consequence into whose hands she falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: So the government must never act with vigor. I should have had Hamilcar's head before this day, were it not that some are always pretending the benefits of mod∣eration.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: And what good from his death will accrue to the public.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: It will be the means of saving the state. He is in the interest of the farmers, and favors the party of Carthage —he opposes the land tax and is for laying heavier duties on impored goods.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen.
SP.P: He is a villain. He opposes the senate, and keeps up the low people.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: He may be honest tho he differ from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I can never believe it. He opposes every measure to avor the Romans, and would make us a colony of Carthage.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Would not your measures, for the same reason, make us a colony of Rome—I cannot see.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I can; you never fully considered the business; he shall be impeached, and his credit forever destroyed in this state.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen
SP.P: The laboring people must never get head. It makes them so saucy—They are so uppish, that it is time they were taken down a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: They would take you down, if they know what a speech you made against them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen.
SP.P: Let them find it out if they can—If they do, a lit∣tle electioneering honey will sweeten all again.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: That is as I say.—Push the matter for the mer∣cantile interest—Then see if our bunkers can raise them∣selves to the highest places in government.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen.
SP.P: Don't let that get abroad— (to Hiero.) Come home with me and I will show you more of the villany of Ham∣ilcar.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Illustrious Secretary; We hope that your health is as good, as your merits are great.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: My merits are not of the size which your praises represent them to be—But I hope my actions have been of some use to the public.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Immense! prodigious! infinite! There is no cal∣culating the benefits of your administration.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Why sir, I have been guilty of several errors in government.

SP.SPEAKER: Par
SP.P: Not one upon my honor—Those things which the public has charged on you as mistakes are the most glori∣ous acts of your official ability.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: There are many who complain of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Not a man of any consequence; you possess the hearts of all our people.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: You flatter me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I flatter—Your actions are above flattery, your deeds are as great as your genius is sublime, and that we know is superior to any thing else, done by man. For since the days of Saturn, since the golden age▪ there has not been such an administration as yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I am happy if my conduct meets the public ap∣probation—then if I push the affair against Hamilcar, I shall certainly succeed. (Exit Timocles.)

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Blast him, a villain, if I do not think that so much praise deserved an invitation to dine. But one may go hungry forever, for any thing that is to be expected from his administration. I have a great mind to change sides, and see whether there be any thing to eat among those in the opposition. (Exit Parasite.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: MOST noble secretary, I wish your health forever and ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Let us hear the omens of our future prosperity; what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: I have attended to the office of augur to day with great care—I was never more desirous or more careful to know the will of the Gods.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What is it then, my reverend priest?

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: Every thing tells the coalition of parties and the safety of the state—not human craft but divine providence discovers itself—the merchants and ploughmen will soon agree, and there will be rejoicing thro all Sicily.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What are the signs of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: I saw three hawks pass by a flock of doves in peace —trees were struck with lightning, then soft music was heard, and shepherds danced in the shade—the tygers and the lambs played together—gamecocks refused to fight and picked the grain together in peace—every thing portends peace and harmony.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Thou art a false prophet—you have been bribed by the Carthaginians—This is no time for coalition—it is time for every man to rise and crush opposition, and banish every moderate man from the state.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: I a false prophet Timocles! was I false when I foretold that you would be a great man, and throw the state into parties? Nor am I a false prophet now—when I predict that your measures will turn to peace—you will be violent, cruel and revengeful—but the more violent the sooner your influence ends, and the state is in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: No man can conduct the measures of government properly, when priests meddle with every thing—I wish there were a particular law to punish every meddler of the sacred order.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: When you set new measures on foot, you ask our prayers for success—that makes us of your party; and if we pray and preach as you would have us; all is right— but if we differ from you then we are knaves, and ought to be hanged—But as priests are so dependent, if they be dishonest it is because the people love to have it so, for the maxim is true, like people, like priest.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Let us hear no more of your false prophecies, but go home, parson, and kiss your wife, and mind your do∣mestic pleasures. If I find you meddling with politics again I will commit you to jail.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P:
Do what you will, the counsel of the Gods will
take place—The events predicted will come, and the more violent you are, the sooner you will bring them about.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—The PARASITE and TIMOCLES.
DIV3.STAGE: (Timocles stands at the edge of the curtain at one entrance— the Parasite enters at the other, & does not see Timocles.)

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: NOW let my heart be joyful, my stomach exult, my palate be delighted; and my appetite rejoice. Never I be∣lieve did there exist a man who took more pleasure in eat∣ing and drinking, than myself. And here in this Little Box (looks at it in his hand) is the resource of eating for∣ever—Never more shall this body, mine own dear, dear flesh, know the torture of emptiness, and famine. Never shall these dainty ribs know the judgment of leanness. This Box supplies me with good eating forever. The present administration is a dry, lean, administration—I gave the prime minister to day a bushel of praise, but he never gave me a mouthful of dinner. His party must soon fall. A starving government never prospers—But this Box—O! this Box, this lovely, sweet Box, (kisses the Box) this is my farm, my plantation, my trade, my shop, my magazine of riches. Never was man more lucky than I, to find this Box. It will afford me the means of eating forever and ever—This day destruction falls on all sorts of provisions. Wo to spare-ribs and hams of bacon. Wo to roast pullets, sirloins of beef, and mince-pies. Wo to gravy sauces, pickles and mangoes. Wo to vegitables, and eatables of all kinds.—Hoh! (He sees Timocles and stops short.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: What, wretch, is this thy tone? This morning the government was perfectly sublime, now it starves its cit∣izens. Would it could starve you and all your race to death. Know, if I hear again of your railing against the government, I will put you in prison, and you shall be hanged. [Timocles goes out.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—HIERO and PARASITE.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: THAT Blunderbuss is gone. He took fire at what I said and in the spirit of true party rage threatened all the opposition. But this Box he searces not—nor dreams that it contains his te.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Let me see it. (Takes the Box and examines it at∣tentively.) Astonishing! Let no man know this mystery till you hear from me—Good heaven! the fate of Sicily is certainly contained in this Little Box.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: But must I starve, who bear on my shoulders the fate of the whole nation? I have thro the whole city, done errands for some, flattered others, threatend more, for a man is apt to be cross when he is hungry; and have not broke bread these fifteen hours. I shall be tired of carry∣ing the weight of the whole ation, if I be kept so short.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Well sir, come with me—as far as food will go, I will support the main pillar of the Commonwealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Say what they will, the weight of the public lies on my shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: There let it rest for the present, but we shall soon find means to take it off—Now let me lead you to my pan∣try, and leave you there; and let all kinds of provision sur∣render to you at discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Illustrious hero! Glorious patriot, I revere thy virtues—I will always be of this party in the time to come; for the other is a dry faction, and must finally starve its supporters.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Live here at large—But excuse me after leading you in—while I receive other compny.

DIV3.STAGE: [Conducts him out, and returns with Hirax]

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: MY worthy friend, what think you of the present administration?

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I dare not speak sir, and scarcely dare to think.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir
SP.P: That is giving a character of them very pointed— Now I think Timocles honest, but at the same time a very infatuated man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I perceive it, and know that he may be very much mortified—But have you consulted the Omens?

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: I have with great care.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: What do they portend?

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: Peace and harmony to the whole nation. I tod Timocles of it to day but he was angry and threatens to imprison me, and hang me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Under what pretence?

SP.SPEAKER: Hir
SP.P: That one of the religious profession must not med∣le with politics.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: A religious officer is a citizen—and is never blamed if he favor the right party—But they whom priests oppose always dislike it; because the religious profession carries weight with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: In a time of peace, and in a government establish∣ed by the clearest law—can it do good to carry matters with such violence?

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: It cannot—it is like overcharging the Balista—It hurts the army that uses it, more than the enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: And what do you suppose is the point of prudence for one of the religious profession in statematters?

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Why if he thinks it will do good, let him declare his opinion honestly—if he thinks it will not, let him keep the matter to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: If any enquire of him the will of the Gods, what must he do?

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Tell it exactly according to the best of his discern∣ment, whether they like it or not; for a priest loses all his importance when he becomes a nose of wax for every man to stretch or shorten at his pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Hir.
SP.P: Happily you agree with me I must go to the au∣gury again, and, depend on it, I shall declare my real sen∣timents. [Exit Hirax]

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: NOW I shall be decisie▪ You will not interfere.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I shall make no promises.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Hamilcar is coming to trial—he is impeached—his trial is voted—the Archon approves it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: You do as you please, but I dislike your measures.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Bold enough in fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Bold and just. Nothing is more improper for a minister of state than such fiery proceedings. Politics should have no passions, but be conducted with a simple view to the public good.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: A citizen should love the state warmly.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero
SP.P: Warmly as you please, but with discretion: he loves not the state who destroys one half of its people— Hamilcar opposes you, and defends the farmers—are we not all one nation? What benefit is there to show malice, or favor, either to Carthage, or Rome? A nation should stand on the broad basis of its own independence, and virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Hamilcar if he be let alone will destroy the state.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: That is, he opposes you—who will speak the things best in the world, if for speaking, he must lose his head? Men should say and do what they please within the law; without this there is no liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: He is attached to Carthage.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I doubt it. But if he be, you are as much at∣tached to Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I am determined to humble the landed interest, and get the law passed to tax corn two sesterces on a bushel enacted—you had better be quiet, I shall spare none who oppose me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Then your reign is short I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Well I begin to be confirmed in my principles of government. I have been for the mercantile interest while they gave me good dinners; but now they give me none.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: You seem to have found quite a deliberate rea∣son for deserting them.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Yes, I think for the future I shall be firmly attach∣ed to the interest of the farmers; they raise the grain; there is provision made for bread, pudding and pye-crust; they raise the grass and from grass comes milk, of which we make syllabubs, whipt creams, and custards—beef also is the produce of the farm—I determine from this time to attach myself to the interest of the farmers. And why cannot I do some thing for the public?—the public say I'm lazy. But I can carry news from place to place, and tell all the stories of the day; and when the candidates kiss the freeholders wives with pieces of gold in their mouths I can make as good a story of it as any man. But my little box, my precious treasure. What future feasts am I to derive from this little box. (Parasite goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: MY son, I must, from the tenderness of a moth∣er's heart, say something concerning your conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Women are naturally so timid that they are poor counsellors in political affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: If I know politics less I have more experience of hu∣man life, and manners, than you. I have seen the fall of seven ministers of state, and I have ever observed it to be in conse∣quence of heat, and violence in their measures.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: They were unskilful as well as violent.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: A ship is never safe with a mad pilot—I speak in the bitterness of a mother's heart, I pretend not to dictate measures; but entreat you to consider whether you be right—Your ruin, my son, is at hand; for heaven's sake desist—I am overwhelmed with grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim
SP.P: In other matters I could respect you; but here—

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: I meddle not with state affairs—But I have seen so many men ruin themselves by violet measures that I tremble every moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim▪
SP.P: Leave all those matters to me; I shall manage them successfully. (Sebaste withdraws.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I HEAR you have told, thro the city, that you have power to bring me down when ever you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: If I have said so it is no more than the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: And that I am a niggard, and tho you treated me very politely, that I had not the complaisance to invite you to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: If I said that too, I said no more than the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: If you said that you are yet not worthy my notice. Where is the wonderful Box which contains the fae of Sicily

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I have a Box which contains the fate of Sicily— Look here, and judge for yousef (Lawyer enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: A fig! It is nothing but your box of tooth powder, what a miracle! well I suppose I understand you now— you say the fate of Sicily depends on this box. If your teeth be kept clean you will devour all the provisions of the whole island—if they fail the island may yet be sup∣plied. (Parasite pouts his lips at him) Were it not that I des∣pise you; and think it a disgrace to have any competition with you; I would make you smart for this, you dotard. (Parasite is moving away) Take that and begone.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—HAMILCAR, TIMOCLES, SENATOR, LAWYER, and HIERO.
DIV3.STAGE: (Hamilcar enters guarded by two soldiers; Hiero enters after him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: YOU see me now condemned to death, on the impeachment of Timocles—the witnesses, lawyers, judg∣es, were all his creatures. Never was a more dangerous precedent. Yet I chuse to die, that all the citizens may see, what a despotic secretary can do with the most inno∣cent man.

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: There are certain cases not designed in the ordi∣nary courts; and must consequently be managed by the prime minister of the time. But I could wish the mode of these trials were altered, that they might at least have the appearance of equity—For next to the substance of justice, the appearance is of importance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: I have fought ten times with the Romans in pitch∣ed battles; and twenty times with the Carthaginians. My main principle of politics has been to equalize the taxes among the citizens. Party zeal now disposes of my life, and the same fate avails you all, should the current of party turn against you—all depends on Timocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Law.
SP.P: I could not prevent it—a defence would have been followed by an impeachment. But it is no uncom∣mon thing for a criminal, to complain of his accusers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sen.
SP.P: Delay not, Timocles, as it belongs to you to read his sentence and order his execution. Delays may give room to excite the compassion of the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: See a grave Senator thirsting for my blood, be∣cause Timocles will have it shed. I only wish that I had died before I saw any thing so shameful, and could have departed with some pride on account of my nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: My friend Hamilcar is condemned on a trial, short, violent, partial, and unjust. Let me but know the articles of impeachment.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: (reads) 1. Being a foreigner he assumed an office. 2. He was under the influence of Carthage. 3. Was the author of a law to promote confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero
SP.P: I can prove all those articles false.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—PHILESIA is introduced suddenly, and breaks off the dialogue—She curtifies to the floor to Timocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: ILLUSTRIOUS Secretary, let the prayers of innocence and truth prevail—Spare a man who possesses a mind rich with all that is honorable, and just.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Justice must prevail, justice rules all.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: At least indulge to hearts, which have ever cherish∣ed virtue, more than life, the sad consolation, of mingling the tears of their last adieus—Let Hamilcar with one keeper only withdraw a moment with me,

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: There must not be any delay to the course of justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: Excellent woman—beseech him not, he has a heart insensible to pity—I de with honor, I mean in heart and principle—we shall meet in the Elysian fields, and be assured nothing but Elysium itself could compensate the want of your society—adieu Philesia, took for a better hus∣band than I could be—aad may the gods make you hap∣py. (She withdraws with her eyes covered, and leaning on Hiero, who instantly returns.)

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: I say I can prove every one of these articles to be false, and would have done it before the court if you had given opportunity—did he make a law to promote confu∣sion? It was only to equalize the taxes between the mer∣chants and the plowmen. May not any man originate a law in an orderly way? You say he is under the influence of Carthage—it was but three days ago that he gave the money he had prepared for his own wedding, in bounties to soldiers to fight against Carthage—truly it is capital for a foreigner to assume an offie; but Hamilcar is not a foreigner.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: I say he is a foreigner▪ and shall be executed imme∣diately. (Pulls out a paper and begins to read) The court finding Hamilcar guy— (Gycerie enters suddenly and seizes his hand which holds the paper.)

SP.SPEAKER: Glye.
SP.P: Monster of cruelty desist; it is not enough that every thing is subject to thy power, must thy malice be sa∣tiated with the blood of innocence? He is no more a for∣eigner than thyself.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Guards seize this woman, and keep her at a dis∣tance.

SP.SPEAKER: Glyc.
SP.P: My brother is innocent, you won't let me tell how.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Silence woman, or I shall order you to prison immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: Cease my dear sister, it will be of no avail—let him execute his bloody work—be virtuous, my dear sister, & we shall meet in Elysium. [The soldier holds her arm while she hides her eyes with the other, and leans her elbow on Hiero's shoulder—Timocles reads.]

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: The court finding Hamilcar guilty of the crimes recorded against him in this proceedings of this court, do order the execution of the said Hamilcar, to be first scourg∣ed with rods without the walls of the city—and then be suspended on the cross—Go, officers, see this executed im∣mediately. [Officers march.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero
SP.P: Say rash man!

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Proceed guards, and do your duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: [rushing in.] Rash man! he is your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: You lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I'll prove it on my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Guards, halt, reconduct the prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Listen noble secretary to reason—have a little patience. Parasite where is your box?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: This little box, O my sweet box, many good din∣ners I shall have by means of this box.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero
SP.P: Hush your nonsense and open the box.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Take it, and open it yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: Here, according to the custom of this city, on the birth of a pair of twins a plate of brass was engraven with their names, and put into a little box, and given to the nurse in record of their birth▪ [shows the plate in the bottom of the box] see here, the figure of two i f and er little hands cleched together, their names below "Tim∣ocles▪ and Erastus" The nurs Athea had this, when the city was tkn by the Carthaginians, 35 year , and it was kept by her.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P:
I was then a prisoner, and the ony Syrausian
she knew in her captivity—I saw her, when she was dy∣ing, and she gave the box to me, and it has bro't me sever∣al good dinners, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: How do you know Erastus and Hamilcar to be the same?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: When the nurse Althea expected to die; she pro∣cured another little plate to be engraved showing the time when the Carthagenian who took him, charged his name to Hamilcar calling him after the name of his gen∣eral —bu how he came here, I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ham.
SP.P: I made my escape when the fleet lay at Agrig∣entum. I swam in the night to the rock Lebeta, and was received by a shepherd▪ who afterwards conducted me to this place—I was so well treated by the shepherd, and farmers, that I have loved them ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Do you Parasite remember the birth of the twins; my mother always told me I was a twin; and that my mate was carried off by the Carthaginians? I am full of astonishment—I am petrifyed with surprize. I sy do you remember the birth of the twins, and the giving of the box?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: I remember it well —my brother was as grand as Hercules, to think that he had a pair of such fine boys. He made a great sacrifice to the household gods, and a great feast—I remember it—the mince pies were admira∣ble; the sausages were delicious, and as for the gravy sauce that did beat all.

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P: Infamous Parasite—it is all a cheat, and a lie— you only mean to impose on my influence.

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero.
SP.P: No, this Parasite, is Parasite no more—he is your uncle; I, your father, and he, were brothers of the sme father and mother—he is your uncle, and a sensible man; he lived at Athens and coming home was afraid of being too well known, as his principles were so opposie to yours, therefore assumed the ridiculous character of a Par∣asite—we all know what he has said to be true. And here I present you with a sister, your own sister Glycerie.

DIV3.STAGE: [Timocles takes her hand and kisses it with affection]

SP.SPEAKER: Tim.
SP.P:
I yield—I have been wrong, what wonders there are in divine providence—I foresee what the good priest told me of. Coalition of parties, and the tranquility of the state. What will be the joy of my mother to discov∣er her children, to see my sister and both her twin boys.
How will she weep for joy, over her long lost children; and to see my brothe married to his dear Philesi. My first work shall be to redress the wrongs of all. But let me now, my dear brother, unburden my heart, and present you to my mother. [Goes out and embraces his brother with one arm, while his sister hangs on the other.]

SP.SPEAKER: Hiero
SP.L: This scene in future times shall grace the stage,
And hold forth useful truths to every age;
That party spirit is the bane of peace;
The root of evil and its vast increase;
That howsoe'er our private tho'ts may jarr;
The public interest is a patriot's care.
Would he not have the public building fall,
One view, one law, one LOVE, must bind us all.

DIV1.HEAD: The Inquisitor. A TRAGI-COMIC DIALOGUE, IN FIVE ACTS.
HONESTY WITHOUT LEARNING, IS BETTER THAN LEARNING WITHOUT HONESTY.
DIV1.P: THO every rational man must discern the value of learning—when rightly used; yet if a man abuses his learning to the injury of his fellow men—he degrades himself below the most illiterate person in the world—The greatest simplicity of ideas, unit∣ed with common sense, and fidelity in business, may make useful men—The Popes, and Inquisitors, tho ornamented with the highest polish of learning, excite our odium▪ while a simple▪ honest, farmer, mechanic, or sailor—may even be an agreeable companion, and useful friend.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.ITEM: PHERON—prince of Abyssinia—prisoner in the Inquisition.
LT. BOWLING—a sailor, prisoner in the Inquisition, remark∣able for his honesty.
A GRENADIER—a patrole soldier of the Inquisition.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: ILISSA—daughter of the prince of Abyssinia.
MRS. MONROE—wife of the English resident.
MISS MONROE—daughter of the English resident.

DIV1.P: SCENE—An apartment in the prison of the Inquisition.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: I AM much obliged to you for this honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: I should not have troubled your eminence this evening, after the fatiguing day you have had, were it not on business of importance.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: The commands of the English shall always meet with ready attention—They are powerful by sea; and our nation needs their assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: The court of London enquires after the prince of Abyssinia—It is said that he is sent to the Inquisition.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: The Prince of Abyssinia!

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: The Prince of Abyssinia—a territory twenty times as large as Portugal, is now confined here.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: Let that remain a secret, or the demand for his ransom will be enormous—I tho't him a person of rank, but had no idea of his being a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: Let him be treated honorably for England's sake, and the court will reward you. (Exit Monroe)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—INQUISITOR, alone.
DIV3.P:
WHAT evil genius directed me to the office of Inquis∣itor to reign in this court of infernal torments? Me, whom nature formed of the softest mould, and poured the milk of humanity, and the honey of kindness, into all my veins. How happy was I when in my little retired village—I ex∣horted the old men to contentment▪ and the young men to matrimony, and felt the consciousness of doing good—The church to reward my services, has made me wretched— Detestable preferments, by which I ratify acts which my soul abhors, and reign like satan supreme in the egions
of misery. (Walks backward and forward disturbed.) But why do I not fly from this detested place? Alas the charm∣ing Ilissa; can any thing be more charming? Hardly can the purest saints in heaven exceed her in beauty; or in dignity of manners—I must remain in horrid office till she can escape with me—O love! immortal songs have al∣ready celebrated thy power, tho ever hast blessed heaven, and hast conquered hell—But this is thy last effort to pen∣etrate the gloom of the inquisition—I live only to admire and hope for Ilissa. (Enter Father Joseph.)

SP.SPEAKER: F. Jo.
SP.P: I ASK pardon of your eminence—I hope I did not interrupt your devotions.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: I had done sir before you came in.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Jo.
SP.P: How go the affairs of the faith—were the prison∣ers condemned as usual?

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: Yes. The Consistory ordered punishment as follows— Four renegado Moors were sent to the gallies, two Jews to the mines, the English sailor remanded to prison—who has been chastized for speaking disrespectfully of St. Dominic.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Jo.
SP.P: And what became of that genteel looking man, and his daughter? The daughter sir is innocence itself.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: She certainly is, and the father has so much conde∣scension and docility about him; that we cannot find the shadow of a charge against him.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Jo.
SP.P: Then he was dismissed, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: No, it was ordered that he should be retained in prison; and his daughter kept at the Inquisitor's house— and that they should not be treated with any great degree of severity.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Jo.
SP.P: That daughter of his is a delicate little piece.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: Fye, I wonder Father Joseph, you will let your fan∣cy run upon such subjects—you should not let vain tho'ts lodge in your mind—I expect soon that you will quarrel with your vow of celibacy.

SP.SPEAKER: F. J.o
SP.P: I should now if I dared— But I am all submis∣sion to the church—Yet I do not see why people should take vows contrary to the order of universal nature.

SP.SPEAKER: In.
SP.P: Silence, Father Joseph, or you will be called to an account—Let us go and see what other business must be attended to this night. (Ex Inquisitor and F. Joseph.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.— (The curtain draws and discovers Pheron on a little bed—Ilissa sitting by the bed and raising his head on a pillow with her arm.) ILISSA and PHERON.

SP.SPEAKER: Ilissa.
SP.P: MERCY ye kind heavens! grant mercy to poor beings miserable beyond expression—Let not my good re lose his reason—sir, my dear sir, speak, my dear papa, speak to me, do you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Know you; yes. You are one of the spirits of the just made perfect—you are in a state of complete hap∣piness.

SP.SPEAKER: Ilissa.
SP.P: Alas! I fear his reason is gone forever—and what will become of me—My dear, most dear father, my life my happiness, pray, dear sir, wake up. Do you know yourself, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: A poor creature; but honest—The devil and the Inquisitor. O, I had a dreadful struggle, tried above an hour to tie me on a wheel of fire that keeps rolling, and rolling to all eternity—But a sweet little angel came and took me away and laid me in her lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Ilissa.
SP.P: Merciful heavens restore him, or let me die with him. (The Doctor enters.) O dear sir, I am extremely glad to see you,

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: And how, my sweet lady, does your father now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ilissa.
SP.P: O sir, I cannot tell; he seems to be disordered in his mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: (examining his patient) Why, truly, madam, his fever is not very high—his disorder arises from fatigue and anxiety of mind. I have given him about 30 drops of Laudanum; and that makes him sleepy. He will wake soon; and may be a little wild at first; but he will soon recover.

SP.SPEAKER: Ilissa.
SP.P: He will wake soon! The idea makes my heart spring with joy—Yet to what can he awake but to new scenes of miseries. (Curtain closes and hides the stage.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—PHERON and BOWLING.
DIV3.STAGE: (The curtain opens and discovers a sailor, hand cuffed and fet∣tered, lying on a mattrass. Pheron by a little table reading the Epistles of John.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: HOW wide from their principles are many who are called Christians! their religion breathes pure benevo∣lence; and yet they persecute each other—why am I in prison? and in danger of severe sufferings—see, here— [reads] "whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer—we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren. Whoso shutteth the bowels of compassion from his brother in need, how dwelleth the love of God in him—my dear children, let us not love, only in word and tongue; but in deed and in truth."

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: (starting up.) That's good doctrine, as true as my christian name—what book is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: The Epistles of John—it contains many beauti∣ful sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: What you read, is right up, and right down good — had some folks minded that, I should not have been con∣fined here; nor would they have given me such an infer∣nal toasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Then you have studied the maxims of religion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Not much master, I have been rather too busy for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: You took so much notice of what I read; that made me ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow▪
SP.P: Yes, my father, who was as good a sailor as ever sepped between stem and stern, taught me and my broth∣ers religon.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: I should be glad to hear a sailor's theory of relig∣ion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: This my father used to tell us always, and he told us it on his dying day—My boys, perform your duties well in this life, and in the next life you'll be promoted, and put into a good mess.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Did that have any great effect upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I never have forgot it; and I dare say I never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Why did it make so strong an impression?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: 'Twas my own father sir, and would he deceive his sons, as he was just going out of the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: And did it have as great effect on your brothers?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: There were four of us, you see, the four Bowlings, the youngest is now thirty one years old—and not one of them has been bro't before the mast yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: It is a short and simple religion—and does it keep you from evil in general?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Why sir, I do my duty—swear but little—and the bad girls, I never see them at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: And do you forsake the women altogether?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: O no master—there's black Moll of Wapping that I love as I do my eyes—Her skin is not so white nor so smooth as some, but she is a fine vessel for all that—she's good spunk—I pledge you that master.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: If she be fond of you, I hope she does not know, that you are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I hope she does not, poor Moll, 'twould break her heart if she did—I was to have gone home at Christmas, and the parson was to have given us the grand reef that would have made us man and wife, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: O master Bowling that goes near your heart— come take a glass of my wine—and here's a health to black Moll, hoping you will get the grand reef yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: O master, (wiping his eyes with his arm) your hon∣or I know is good—When I think of poor Moll, I have a great stomach to cry—but I keep it down—It shall never be said that Tom Bowling cried for a girl—tho I have a stomach for it, and hardly can keep it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: With such an honest and humane heart, who put you here, Mr. Bowling?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: The people of this place—because when they prai∣sed St. Dominic—I was mad, and tho I do not swear oft∣en, I swore them and damned his Saint off the reel—for I hate cruelty—then they sent me here, and gave me an in∣fernal toasting, such, as when pay-day comes, they will have to take themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P:
We often bring ourselves into difficulty by too free
use of our tongues—but we will say no more of that, we are companions in affliction. Let us be friends Mr. Bow∣ling; and we may be of use to each other to get out of this place.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I hope to see that day—If I can get aboard my frigate again—I will bring her up the Quay, so as to bear on this place, then I'll pour in my broadside upon them, and dash them all to dust—Then, I'll tell them that's Tom Bowling, and get away as fast as I can.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—PHERON and MONROE.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: SIR, whoever you are, you come to visit me in a horrid place.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: I bear with me the commands and respect of the English nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Of what extent they may be to me is unknown.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: I can do all the English nation can do—without interfering in the government of Portugal—and I have a personal curiosity to know why you are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: Religion is assigned as the cause, but how I have offended them, I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: It is presumed that you are the prince and appar∣ent heir of the whole empire of Abyssinia.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
SP.P: That is the precise truh. The Abyssinians are a most inoffensive people—They are Christians, on the in∣struction, and principles, of the apostle John.

SP.SPEAKER: Mon.
SP.P: Your religion is then, very simple and benevolent.

SP.SPEAKER: Pher.
